courses.name: Intermediate Photography
courses.description: More advanced photography methods; independent work; large format and studio lighting techniques; conceptual approaches to the medium.

courses.name: Color Photography
courses.description: Basic principles of digital manipulation along with concepts surrounding color photography. Instruction includes post-processing workflow, basic Photoshop manipulation, and color photography history and theory. Course elements include shooting assignments, Photoshop exercises, critiques, and a final project. No previous experience necessary.

courses.name: Studio Practice
courses.description: Exploration of varied techniques and strategies geared toward the development of an individualized and self-directed studio practice.
courses.prereqs: junior standing in the major or consent of instructor

courses.name: Contemporary Art Survey
courses.description: Forms and concerns of art from the 1960s to the present, introduced in slide lecture format.

courses.name: Critical Methods for Contemporary Art
courses.description: Introduction to basic key terms, concepts, and analytical categories of theoretical discourses relevant to an informed and critical engagement with contemporary art.

courses.name: Senior Critique
courses.description: Students complete a body of work to be shown in the senior exhibition, develop their critical skills, and learn to give articulate verbal and written expression to the concerns their art explores.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.description: Variable content, seminar-based course. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

courses.name: Studio/Seminar
courses.description: Variable content course with both seminar and studio components. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

courses.name: Studio
courses.description: Variable content, studio-based course. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

courses.name: Special Topics in Art
courses.description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: For advanced majors pursuing projects outside the context of regularly offered courses.
courses.prereqs: consent of department chair and director of undergraduate studies

courses.name: Graduate Critique
courses.description: Advanced studio course for MFA candidates.

courses.name: Visual Artist's Writing Practicum
courses.description: Course explores a wide range of approaches artists use in writing about their work and in using writing as part of their work. Graduate students in departments other than Art Theory and Practice may enroll only with permission of the instructor.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar
courses.description: Variable content, seminar-based course. May be repeated for credit with different topic.  Graduate students in departments other than Art Theory and Practice may enroll only with permission of the instructor.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Course may be repeated, up to a maximum of six credits. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation.  SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Topics in Asian American Social and Cultural Analysis
courses.description: Issues and themes in Asian American society and culture. Recent topics include the Arab American studies, student protests, and minority conservatisms. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Introduction to Asian American Studies
courses.description: Origins of the field, emerging trajectories, core concepts, theories and methodologies. Analyzes race, gender, immigration, diaspora, class, labor, and sexuality as primary subjects of the field.

courses.name: Introduction to Asian American History
courses.description: Introduction to the history of Asians in the United States, with a focus on their impact on American society as well as their experiences within the United States. ASIAN_AM 214-0 and HISTORY 214-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global Asians
courses.description: Survey of Asian diasporas in the United States and elsewhere in the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing causes of migration, process of settlement, relations with other ethnic groups, and construction of diasporic identities. ASIAN_AM 216-0 and HISTORY 216-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Asian/Black Historical Relations in the U.S.
courses.description: Comparative historical analysis of relations of these groups in the United States, including racialized and sexualized discourses structuring interracial relations and social, political, and economic location. Slavery, immigration, model minority myth, cross-racial politics. AF_AM_ST 218-0 and ASIAN_AM 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Topics in History
courses.description: Exploration of theme, event, region, or historical period, with emphasis on historical interpretation. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Communities
courses.description: Critical examination of post-1965 Asian American communities in light of demographic, social, racial, and economic trends in the United States and Asia.

courses.name: Language in Asian America
courses.description: Survey of linguistic anthropological topics relevant to Asian American communities, including bilingualism, code switching, language socialization, language shift, style, sociolinguistic variation, indexicality, media, and semiotics. ANTHRO 235-0 and ASIAN_AM 235-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Asian Americans and Popular Culture
courses.description: Examination of the varied roles of Asian Americans in U.S. popular culture, from representations to cultural production, historically and today.

courses.name: The Mixed Race Experience
courses.description: Exploration of demographic trends in interracial and interethnic marriages to highlight the complexity of the American experience. Special attention to mixed-race experiences portrayed in film and novels. AF_AM_ST 251-0 and ASIAN_AM 251-0 are taught together; students may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Introduction to Asian American Literature
courses.description: Introduction to Asian American literature from the late 19th century to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. ASIAN_AM 275-0 and ENGLISH 275-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Topics in Literary and Cultural Studies
courses.description: Close study of Asian American literary and cultural texts within a theme, genre, or other organizing criterion. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Social and Cultural Analysis
courses.description: Detailed exploration of an issue and its ramifications in Asian American society and culture. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Asian American Women's History
courses.description: Exploration of race, gender, and the contours of US history from the perspective of Asian American women's experiences. Considers migration, exclusion, labor, marriage, family, sexuality, and cross-racial alliances. ASIAN_AM 304-0 and HISTORY 304-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Contemporary Asian Black Relations
courses.description: Divides between these groups, as well as areas of positive cross-cultural collaboration. Historical analysis of reparations, the 1992 Los Angeles riots, and affirmative action. Cross-racial exchange in youth expressions, popular culture, hip-hop. AF_AM_ST 310-0 and ASIAN_AM 310-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in History
courses.description: Close study of Asian American history within a theme, event, or other organizing criterion, with emphasis on primary documents, historical interpretation, and research. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Asian American Religions
courses.description: Analysis of the role of religion in Asian American communities; how experiences as immigrants and as racial and ethnic minorities shape religious practices, communities, theologies, and identities.

courses.name: Studies in Race, Gender, and Sexuality
courses.description: Exploration of the intersections of gender, race, and sexuality, the construction of masculinity and femininity, and the role of gender and sexuality in the life experiences of Asian Americans. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Language, Race, and Ethnicity in the U.S.
courses.description: Analysis of connections between language ideologies, language use, and meanings of race and ethnicity. Bilingualism, immigration, identity, accented English, African American English, language policy, English only movement, education, social change. ASIAN_AM 365-0 and ANTHRO 365-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Studies in Diaspora
courses.description: Exploration of the ideas of diaspora and homeland and their implications for rethinking immigration and migration as they relate to the experiences of Asian Americans. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Literary and Cultural Studies
courses.description: Close study of Asian American literary and cultural texts within a theme, genre, or other organizing criterion, with an emphasis on theory and its application. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: The American Century in Asia
courses.description: Examination of US-Asia connections through history and representations of US wars in cultural and historical texts.

courses.name: Studies in Arts and Performance
courses.description: Analysis of Asian American contributions to the art and culture of the United States. Exploration of the dynamics of race, gender, and class in Asian American dance, theater, and film. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Seminar in Asian American Studies
courses.description: Seminar on a topic in areas related to Asian American social structure and culture. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study In Asian American Studies
courses.description: Readings and conferences on special subjects for students pursuing areas of interest in Asian American studies.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to topics in Chinese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to Modern Chinese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to topics in the history of cultural production in modern China between the 19th century and present day. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Modern Chinese Popular Culture I
courses.description: Introduction to the history of modern Chinese popular cultural production between the mid-19th century and 1949. The course is designed around the introduction and adaptation of four media technologies: photography, film, mass print culture, and sound recording. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Modern Chinese Popular Culture II
courses.description: Introduction to popular cultural production in Mainland China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong between 1949 and the present. ASIAN_LC 204-0 is recommended.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to topics in Japanese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to Premodern Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Japanese literature and culture from the earliest writings to the dawn of the modern era (8th-19th c.): poetry, narrative fiction, essays, diaries, theater. Focus is on reading literary texts in historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Culture Introduction to Japanese literature, thought, and culture from the mid-19th to mid-20th century: fiction, poetry, theater, essays. Focus is on reading literary texts in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to Contemporary Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Culture Introduction to Japanese literature, thought, and culture from the mid-20th to early 21st century: fiction, poetry, theater, essays, animation, manga. Focus is on reading literary texts in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to Japanese Film, Media, and Visual Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Japanese media and visual culture.  Topics may include: pre-modern visual narrative, pre-modern print culture, cinema, animation, manga, video games. Focus is on reading media and visual culture in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Korean Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to topics in Korean literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in South Asian Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to topics in South Asian literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: South Asian Popular Cultures
courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the intersecting worlds of popular literature, digital media, folk arts, performance, and politics of South Asia with a focus on the relationship between artistic expression, social reform and political change. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: South Asian Cinemas
courses.description: Narrative and aesthetic approaches to understanding popular cinemas in South Asia with special attention to historical, local, and global contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Asian Languages and Cultures
courses.description: Content and prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: West-Bound: The Fantastic Worlds of Xiyou Ji, Journey to the West
courses.description: West-Bound: The Fantastic Worlds of Xiyou Ji, Journey to the West.NPEP course.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Chinese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  One  200-level Chinese literary and culture  studies course is recommended.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Japanese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  One 200-level Japanese literary and culture studies course is recommended.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Premodern Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth examination of specialized topics in premodern Japanese literature and culture. Emphasis on reading, evaluating, and applying scholarship in Japanese studies to inform analysis of primary texts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Modern and Contemporary Japanese Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced study in topics related to Japanese literature and culture from the late 19th century to the present.  Topics may include, but are not limited to: significant cultural movements in specific historical periods, wartime literature and culture, minority literatures, and major authors and texts. Focus is on interpreting literature and culture in relation to historical contexts and theoretical concerns. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Korean Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Korean literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. ASIAN_LC 240 is recommended.  No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in South Asian Languages and Cultures
courses.description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in South Asian Literature and Culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. Includes a research component. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.  One 200-level South Asian  literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Literary Cultures in South Asia
courses.description: Advanced study of specific literary cultures in South Asia, and their impacts on South Asian history and contemporary society. Topics vary in historical, regional, and thematic scope. No prerequisite, but a 200-level ASIAN_LC topics courses is recommended. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.  One 200-level South Asian  literary and culture studies course is  recommended. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Religious and Textual Traditions in South Asia
courses.description: Explores the close relationship between religious practice and belief and literary traditions (Hindu, Muslim, Buddhist, etc.) in South Asia from classical to contemporary periods. Topics vary; may be repeated for credit with a change in topic. One 200-level South Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

courses.name: South Asian Societies
courses.description: This class will examine how significant moments of social and political transformation (such as colonialism, Partition, and the growth of the South Asian diaspora) has been engaged in literature and popular culture. Content varies; a 200-level course in an area of South Asian literature and culture is recommended. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Asian Languages and Cultures
courses.description: Content and prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Advanced Studies in Asian Film, Media, and Visual Culture
courses.description: Advanced topics in Asian film, media, and visual culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: ASIAN_LC 202-0 or ASIAN_LC 204-0 or ASIAN_LC 205-0 or ASIAN_LC 224-0 or ASIAN_LC 265-0 (C- or better); or consent of instructor

courses.name: Asian Environmental Humanities
courses.description: Topics in the study of environment and culture in Asian contexts. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with change of topic.  One 200-level Asian LC course is recommended.

courses.name: Space and Place in Asian Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate course examining representations of space and place in Asian cultural contexts, with focus on application of theoretical methods to primary texts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Genre in Asian Literatures
courses.description: Advanced undergraduate course examining the place of genre in Asian literary traditions. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Senior capstone research course for majors; topics vary.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: The independent study is designed for advanced undergraduates interested in studying topics not otherwise covered in normal ALC courses.
courses.prereqs: consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor

courses.name: Topical Seminar in Asian Humanities
courses.description: Content and prerequisites vary.

courses.name: Modern Cosmology
courses.description: Modern views on the structure of the universe, its past, present, and future. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

courses.name: Modern Cosmology
courses.description: Modern views on the structure of the universe, its past, present, and future. This course is designed for non-science majors and has no math prerequisite.

courses.name: Milky Way Galaxy
courses.description: Structure of the galaxy, star formation, interstellar clouds and dust, star clusters, neutron stars and black holes, the galactic center. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

courses.name: Solar System
courses.description: The planets and their moons, the sun, comets, asteroids. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

courses.name: A Brief Journey through the Invisible Universe
courses.description: A conceptual course exploring the world of the invisible radio universe. The topics include: the historical development of the radio sky, the connection between cosmic rays and the radio sky, how radio telescopes work and numerous discoveries made over the last 90 years (pulsars, quasars, the Big Bang cosmic microwave background radiation, organic molecules, the shadow of a supermassive black hole), and the physics of radio astronomy.

courses.name: Introduction to Astrobiology
courses.description: The modern scientific perspective on the question of life elsewhere in the universe. The prospects for life on Mars. The discovery of extrasolar planets and the search for extrasolar biospheres.

courses.name: Highlights of Astronomy
courses.description: Acquaints students with modern ideas about the solar system, stars, galaxies, and the universe. Emphasizes fundamental principles and underlying concepts.

courses.name: Highlights of Astronomy
courses.description: Structure of the galaxy, star formation, interstellar clouds and dust, star clusters, neutron stars and black holes, the galactic center. This course is designed for non-science majors.

courses.name: Introduction to Astrophysics I: Life Cycle of Stars and Planets
courses.description: The course will explore the origin and evolution of star/planet systems, focusing on underlying physical processes and observational techniques. We will discuss the recent discovery of thousands of planets orbiting stars other than our Sun - a.k.a. "exoplanets". We will also discuss stellar remnant black holes. (
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2 (concurrent registration in PHYSICS 135-2 is acceptable. Students who have taken ASTRON 220-0 should not take this course and take ASTRON 220-2 instead)

courses.name: Introduction to Astrophysics II: Galactic Evolution and Cosmology
courses.description: The course will explore modern cosmology, including dark matter, the Big Bang, curved space-time, the origin and evolution of the first stars and galaxies, cosmic acceleration, and dark energy. In all cases, the focus will be on the underlying physical processes and the observational techniques used. (
courses.prereqs: ASTRON 220-1 or all of PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3.)

courses.name: Basics of Radio Astronomy
courses.description: Radio astronomy is the study of natural radio emission from the sky, providing important clues about the history of the universe. Topics include how a radio telescope receives invisible signals, how dramatically the radio sky differs from the optical sky, and interferometry.
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, PHYSICS 135-3 (or equivalent) or PHYSICS 332-0; MATH 220-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Planetary Astrophysics
courses.description: Methods of exoplanet detection. The observed architecture of exoplanetary systems. Formation and evolution of planetary systems. Modeling exoplanet interiors and atmospheres. Exoplanet habitability and the search for bio-signatures.

courses.name: Observational Astrophysics
courses.description: Geometric optics applied to design of optical and x-ray telescopes; diffraction and the Airy disk; radio and optical interferometry and aperture synthesis; adaptive optics; recent developments in detector technology; quantum and thermal noise in astronomy. Independent research projects using the CCD camera and 18-inch refractor in Dearborn Observatory. Offered alternate years.

courses.name: Stellar Astrophysics
courses.description: Physics of stellar interiors, stellar atmospheres, and star formation. Specific topics include simple stellar models, nuclear energy generation, overview of evolutionary phases, white dwarfs, neutron stars, interstellar gas and dust grains, gravitational collapse.

courses.name: Extragalactic Astrophysics and Cosmology
courses.description: Big bang cosmology, thermal history of the universe, primordial nucleosynthesis, microwave background, dark matter, largescale structure, galaxy formation, spiral and elliptical galaxies, groups and clusters of galaxies.

courses.name: Astrophysics ISP
courses.description: Stellar structure and evolution: nucleosynthesis, supernova phenomena, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Limited to students enrolled in ISP or with consent of the physics department.

courses.name: Current Topics in Astronomy
courses.description: Explores in detail an area of current research interest in astrophysics. Contact the department or instructor for specifics. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Prerequisites vary.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Opportunity to study an advanced subject under the individual direction of a faculty member. Open to all advanced students. Consent of instructor required.

courses.name: Basics of Radio Astronomy
courses.description: Survey of radio astronomy, emphasizing technical aspects; radiation, antennas, receivers, radio spectroscopy, interferometer arrays and aperture synthesis; radio emission mechanisms and cosmic rays.

courses.name: Astrophysical Radiative Processes and Transport
courses.description: Astrophysical Radiative Processes and Transport. Radiative processes important in astrophysics and the methods to model the propagation of radiation. Synchrotron and bremsstrahlung emission. Compton scattering. Plasma effects. Basic atomic and molecular processes. Example astronomical applications.

courses.name: Planetary Astrophysics
courses.description: Planetary AstrophysicsMethods of exoplanet detection. The observed architecture of exoplanetary systems.  The formation and evolution of planetary systems.  Modeling exoplanet interiors and atmospheres.  Exoplanet habitability and the search for biosignatures.

courses.name: Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics. Dynamics of fluids as applied to astrophysical bodies.  Topics include hydrostatics, shocks, waves, instabilities, and magnetohydrodynamics.  Applications include atmospheres, stars, accretion disks, stellar winds, and galactic disks.

courses.name: Observational Astrophysics
courses.description: Geometric optics applied to design of optical and x-ray telescopes; diffraction and the Airy disk; radio and optical interferometry and aperture synthesis; adaptive optics; recent developments in detector technology; quantum and thermal noise in astronomy. Independent research projects using the CCD camera and 18-inch refractor in Dearborn Observatory. Offered alternate years.

courses.name: Stellar Astrophysics
courses.description: Physics of stellar interiors, stellar atmospheres, and star formation. Specific topics include simple stellar models, nuclear energy generation, overview of evolutionary phases, white dwarfs, neutron stars, interstellar gas and dust grains, gravitational collapse.

courses.name: Extragalactic Astrophysics and Cosmology
courses.description: Big bang cosmology, Friedman model, thermal history of the Universe, primordial nucleosynthesis, microwave background, dark matter, inflation, arge-scale structure, galaxy formation, spiral and elliptical galaxies, and groups and clusters of galaxies.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Astrophysics
courses.description: Specialized lectures on current research topics.

courses.name: Stellar Structure and Evolution
courses.description: Stellar interiors, structure, and atmospheres; thermonuclear reactions, stellar stability, and evolution of binaries. Special topics such as supernovae or brown dwarfs may be included.

courses.name: Interstellar Matter and Star Formation
courses.description: Overview of interstellar gas, absorption and emission lines, synchrotron radiation, excitation of atoms and molecules, shocks, supernova remnants, gravitational collapse, and protostars.

courses.name: Stellar Dynamics
courses.description: Gravitational potential theory, regular and chaotic orbits, galactic nuclei and supermassive black holes, galactic disk dynamics and spiral structure, evolution of galaxies and star clusters, and dark matter.

courses.name: High Energy Astrophysics
courses.description: High Energy Astrophysics  Detectors for high-energy photons and particles. Formation and evolution of compact objects in isolation and in binaries. Supernova types. Gamma-ray bursts. Cosmic rays and particle acceleration.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERSMay be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERSIndependent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Introduction to Biological Sciences at Northwestern
courses.description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. An overview of recent advances in biological research and leadership within the field of biology. Taken with CHEM 100-0.

courses.name: Diversity of Life
courses.description: Comparative survey of organisms, emphasizing adaptation and phylogenetic relationships. Particular emphasis on animals.

courses.name: Plant-People Interactions
courses.description: Biology and history of the interaction of humans and flowering plants.

courses.name: The Nature of Plants
courses.description: Plant adaptations for growth, survival, and reproduction. Plant defense against herbivory, pollination, and seed dispersal.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Biological Thought & Action; preparatory to BIOL_SCI 116-6.

courses.name: The Human Brain
courses.description: Overview of the development, structure and function of the human nervous system; terminology and principles of neuroanatomy, neurochemistry, physiology, and molecular biology. How the brain works and its role in human behavior and psychopathology. Issues raised by new medical technologies.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Science Research Preparation; follows BIOL_SCI 115-6.

courses.name: Human Genetics
courses.description: Basic principles of human inheritance and genetic variation.

courses.name: Human Reproduction
courses.description: Basic biology of reproduction; relation between hormones, emotions, intelligence, and behavior; related policy issues.

courses.name: Basic Genetics and Evolution
courses.description: Principles of inheritance as they apply to evolution. May not receive credit after taking BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0.

courses.name: Genetics and Evolution
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Concepts of Biology
courses.description: General biological sciences introduction. Topics include evolution, biomolecules, cell biology, genetics, population biology, and the relationship between structure and function in organisms. The course is geared toward students with an interest in the topic but without a background in biological sciences.

courses.name: Concepts of Biology
courses.description: General biological sciences introduction. Topics include evolution, biomolecules, cell biology, genetics, population biology, and the relationship between structure and function in organisms. The course is geared toward students with an interest in the topic but without a background in biological sciences.

courses.name: Molecular Biology
courses.description: This course focuses on how information is stored and propagated in DNA, and used and regulated to generate proteins at the proper time and location. It also applies this information to understanding fundamentals of biotechnology. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 201-0 and BIOL_SCI 215-0.

courses.name: Peer-Guided SG: Molecular Biology
courses.description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 201-0.

courses.name: Cell Biology
courses.description: This course covers how biomolecules function together to generate the complexity of cells, and how cells behave collectively to communicate with each other and to enact key decisions, such as proliferation and cell death.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed, with a C- or better, BIOL_SCI 201-0 or 215-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 232-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 219-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0

courses.name: Peer-Guided SG: Cell Biology
courses.description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 202-0.

courses.name: Genetics and Evolution
courses.description: This course provides an analytic framework for studying the flow of biological information across generations, and understanding how phenotypes reveal biological mechanisms. This framework is applied to development, cancer, the history of life, and mechanisms governing the evolution and distribution of organisms over time.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed, with a C- or better, BIOL_SCI 202-0 or 219-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 233-0

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Genetics and Evolution
courses.description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 203-0.

courses.name: Genetics and Molecular Biology
courses.description: Principles of inheritance; gene function; mechanisms by which DNA is replicated, transcribed into RNAs, and translated into proteins; basics of the process of natural selection.
courses.prereqs: one year of general chemistry with laboratory

courses.name: Physiology
courses.description: Organization and functioning of the major organ systems in mammals.

courses.name: Cell Biology
courses.description: Mechanisms that cells use to compartmentalize and transport proteins, to move, to regulate growth and death, and to communicate with their environments.

courses.name: Genetic and Molecular Processes Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of transmission genetics and molecular biology. Credit for this course is 0.34 units.

courses.name: Cellular Processes Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of cell biology. Credit for this course is 0.34 units.
courses.prereqs: grades of C- or higher in both BIOL_SCI 220-CN and CHEM 132-CN

courses.name: Investigative Lab
courses.description: A culminating life-science lab experience. Credit for this course is 0.34 units.

courses.name: Molecular and Cellular Processes Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of cell and molecular biology. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 202-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 221-0 and BIOL_SCI 232-0.

courses.name: Genetics and Molecular Processes Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of transmission genetics and molecular biology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 232-0. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 203-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 220-0 and BIOL_SCI 233-0

courses.name: Investigative Laboratory
courses.description: A culminating life-science laboratory experience.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 233-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 222-0 and BIOL_SCI 234-0

courses.name: Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology - 1 for ISP
courses.description: This course aims to provide a framework for understanding the chemistry, structure and function of life’s smallest functional units known as cells. Starting out with a basic description of inherent properties of biological macromolecules, the course deals with information storage, the flow of genetic information, cytoskeleton, cell organelles, and cell division.
courses.prereqs: Students must be enrolled in the Integrated Science Program to register for this course

courses.name: Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology - 2 for ISP
courses.description: The course takes an in depth look at how the chemical and physical properties of organic molecules drive all aspects of life. Focus on principles of chemical evolution/diversification, biological membranes, membrane transport processes, enzyme structure and function, molecular signaling and design principles of the metabolic engine that enables the breakdown and synthesis of biological macromolecules.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed CHEM 171-0, CHEM 172-0, CHEM 212-1, BIOL_SCI 240-0, and ISP standing

courses.name: Principles of Biochemistry
courses.description: Biochemical processes.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed, or be currently enrolled in, CHEM 210-1 or CHEM 212-1 or CHEM 215-1

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Principles of Biochemistry
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in BIOL_SCI 301-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Neurobiology
courses.description: Cellular and biochemical approaches to the nervous system, focusing on neuron structure and function.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 217-0 or BIOL_SCI 310-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course. May not receive credit for both BIOL_SCI 302-0 and NEUROSCI 202-0

courses.name: Fundamentals of Neurobiology
courses.description: Structure and function of the mammalian central nervous system from the molecular to behavioral level. Emphasis on foundational concepts in neurobiology, including neuronal and glial structure and function, neurophysiology of membrane, resting and action potential, synaptic physiology, an introduction to sensory perception, neuronal plasticity in learning and memory.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Neurobiology
courses.description: Structure and function of the mammalian central nervous system from the molecular to behavioral level. Emphasis on foundational concepts in neurobiology, including neuronal and glial structure and function, neurophysiology of membrane, resting and action potential, synaptic physiology, an introduction to sensory perception, neuronal plasticity in learning and memory.

courses.name: Molecular Neurobiology
courses.description: Exploration of the overlap between neurobiology and molecular biology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Neurobiology Laboratory
courses.description: Hands-on experience in the performance of experiments in cellular neurophysiology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Brain Structure, Function, and Evolution
courses.description: An overview of the evolution of the nervous system and cognition, from the origin of neurons to the structure and function of the human brain. No P/N.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0, BIOL_SCI 325-0 or BIOL_SCI 344-0 in order to register for this course

courses.name: Biochemistry
courses.description: Basic concepts in biochemistry, emphasizing the structure and function of biological macromolecules, fundamental cellular biochemical processes, and the chemical logic in metabolic transformations.

courses.name: Human Physiology
courses.description: An exploration of the functions of the human body at the tissue, organ and organ system level. Emphasis on homeostatic mechanisms and interdependence within organs and organ systems and the influence of modulatory systems. Topics will include, but are not limited to: nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and CHEM 132-0, CHEM 152-0, or CHEM 172-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 310-0 and BIOL_SCI 217-0

courses.name: The Evolutionary Biology of Human Anatomy, Health and Disease
courses.description: Key features of human anatomy, health and disease from an evolutionary perspective. Review of some  evolutionary processes, overview of human evolutionary history, consideration of the primary body systems and regions in the human organism. The historical context of selected human structures and their function/dysfunction across these systems.

courses.name: Human Anatomy
courses.description: An introduction to human anatomy. Topics include system approach to anatomical organization; sections of the body; musculoskeletal and nervous systems; embryology development. Lectures are supplemented by selected prosections of human cadavers and dry exercises using bones, models, and computer animations.

courses.name: Human Anatomy
courses.description: An introduction to human anatomy. Topics include system approach to anatomical organization; sections of the body; musculoskeletal and nervous systems; embryology development. Lectures are supplemented by selected prosections of human cadavers and dry exercises using bones, models, and computer animations.

courses.name: Advanced Cell Biology
courses.description: Relationship of shape, structural dynamics, and function with the cellular state and gene expression; cell-to-cell communication.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Advanced Cell Biology
courses.description: Relationship of shape, structural dynamics, and function with the cellular state and gene expression; cell-to-cell communication.

courses.name: Human Structure and Function
courses.description: The function of the musculoskeletal system in modern humans. A comparative perspective emphasizing the adaptive contexts of the evolutionary transformations leading to our modern anatomy. Structural, functional, and evolutionary anatomy of humans, with primary focus on the musculoskeletal system of the postcranium. General biomechanical principles of anatomical systems are covered through the regional anatomy of the muscles, bones and joints.  Lectures are supplemented by selected prosections of human cadavers, in-class lab sessions examining bones and models, and computer animations and exercises.
courses.prereqs: BIOL_SCI 313-CN, equivalent anatomy course, or permission of instructor

courses.name: Regional Human Anatomy Lab
courses.description: Lab course utilizing prosections and demonstrations of human cadavers. It is an advanced anatomy course examining the details of human body systems. Topics include: body wall and cavities, contents and features of the thorax and abdomen (cardiac, pulmonary, and gastrointestinal systems), pelvis (genito-urinary system), spinal cord and back, innervation and blood supply of the upper and lower limbs, cranial cavities and contents, cranial nerves and blood supply of the head and neck. Credit for this course is 0.34 units.

courses.name: Advanced Human Physiology
courses.description: Builds on concepts covered in BIOL_SCI 217-CN or an equivalent physiology course focusing on the body as an integrated set of systems. A global view of the body, its systems, and the many processes that keep the systems working. Integrated approach to studying all major organ systems including neural, autonomic/somatic motor, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive, and reproductive physiology. The clinical relevance of the organ system that will include abnormal function, disease states, and medications used to bring the system back to normal functioning.

courses.name: Advanced Human Physiology
courses.description: Builds on concepts covered in BIOL_SCI 217-CN or an equivalent physiology course focusing on the body as an integrated set of systems. A global view of the body, its systems, and the many processes that keep the systems working. Integrated approach to studying all major organ systems including neural, autonomic/somatic motor, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive, and reproductive physiology. The clinical relevance of the organ system that will include abnormal function, disease states, and medications used to bring the system back to normal functioning.

courses.name: Biology of Animal Viruses
courses.description: Virus structure, synthesis of viral nucleic acids and proteins, the interaction of the viral and cellular genomes.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Bioinformatics:  Sequence and Structure Analysis
courses.description: Use of informational and modeling techniques to explore evolutionary and other problems related to the genome.
courses.prereqs: Students must have taken BIOL_SCI 241-0 or BIOL_SCI 301-0 in order to register for this class

courses.name: Animal Physiology
courses.description: Physiological principles and mechanisms responsible for the ability of animals to regulate variables in the steady state.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 217-0 or BIOL_SCI 310-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Animal Physiology
courses.description: Physiological principles and mechanisms responsible for the ability of animals to regulate variables in the steady state.

courses.name: Biology of Aging
courses.description: Biological aspects of aging, from molecular to evolutionary.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Biology of Aging
courses.description: Biological aspects of aging, from molecular to evolutionary.

courses.name: Microbiology
courses.description: How microbes interact with their environments, including with humans. Lecture and Laboratory.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Microbiology Lab
courses.description: Laboratory section for BIOL_SCI 328-CN.

courses.name: Microbiology
courses.description: How microbes interact with their environments, including with humans.

courses.name: Conservation Genetics
courses.description: Critical issues in the management and understanding of endangered populations.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Plant-Animal Interactions
courses.description: Plant-animal interactions, and their consequences for individuals, populations, ecological communities, and ecosystems. Examination of how these interactions are responding to ongoing global factors such as anthropogenic habitat destruction and climate change.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 339-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0

courses.name: Soils and the Environment: The Earth's Critical Zone
courses.description: Soil development and morphology; physical, chemical, hydrologic, and biological properties of soils.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Spring Flora
courses.description: Life cycles, vegetative and reproductive structures, and adaptations for pollination and fruit and seed dispersal of the wildflowers, trees, and shrubs of oak woodland.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 240-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Biostatistics
courses.description: Approaches, methods, and techniques for analyzing datasets in ecology and conservation biology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Modeling Biological Dynamics
courses.description: Mathematical and computational techniques for analyzing and predicting biological dynamics. Techniques include statistical models, discrete- and continuous- time dynamical models, and stochastic models. Applications cover a range of scales, with an emphasis on common mathematical concepts and computational techniques, the interpretation of existing data, and making predictions for new experiments.
courses.prereqs: at least one of MATH 218-1, MATH 220-1, MATH 240-0, STAT 202-0, BIOL_SCI 337-0, OR equivalent

courses.name: Critical Topics in Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Seminar discussing historical and modern publications in the field.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Population Genetics
courses.description: Processes that affect allele frequency change and thus cause evolution.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and a course in statistics to register for this course

courses.name: Evolutionary Processes
courses.description: Evolutionary mechanisms (natural selection, genetic drift), evolutionary history (speciation, phylogenetics), and adaptations (sex, cooperation, aging, life history).
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and a course in statistics to register for this course

courses.name: Evolutionary Processes
courses.description: Evolutionary mechanisms (natural selection, genetic drift), evolutionary history (speciation, phylogenetics), and adaptations (sex, cooperation, aging, life history).

courses.name: Anatomy of Vertebrates
courses.description: Vertebrate phylogeny illustrated via comparative morphology; anatomical/ functional and ontogenetic considerations; dissections.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 103-0, BIOL_SCI 203-0, BIOL_SCI 341-0, or BIOL_SCI 342-0

courses.name: Topics in Biology
courses.description: Topics vary but always deal with an area of advanced study in the life sciences. With laboratory. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 234-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Field Ecology
courses.description: An intensive experience in field ecological research.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and a course in statistics to register for this course

courses.name: Conservation Biology
courses.description: Evolution, ecology, and conservation of patterns of biological diversity.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 and a course in statistics to register for this course

courses.name: Community Ecology
courses.description: Abundance, distribution, diversity, and scaling in plant communities in space-time.

courses.name: Plant Evolution and Diversity Lab
courses.description: Introduction to the diversity and evolutionary history of land plants.

courses.name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Project-based approach to learning lab skills in eukaryotic molecular biology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Quantitative Analysis of Biology
courses.description: Random genetic processes, gene expression, cell adaptation, cell cycle, developmental morphogens, phylgenomics.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Immunobiology
courses.description: Nature of host resistance; characteristics of antigens, antibodies; basis of immune response; hypersensitivity.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Immunobiology
courses.description: Nature of host resistance; characteristics of antigens, antibodies; basis of immune response; hypersensitivity.

courses.name: Immunobiology
courses.description: Nature of host resistance; characteristics of antigens, antibodies; basis of immune response; hypersensitivity.

courses.name: Endocrinology
courses.description: Physiology and biochemistry of hormones and glands of internal secretion in vertebrates; endocrine glands.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 325-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Advanced Physiology Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments in several physiological systems. Design, techniques, data analysis, and report writing emphasized.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 310-0 or BIOL_SCI 217-0, and BIOL_SCI 234-0 or BIOL_SCI 222-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Quantitative Experimentation in Biology
courses.description: Laboratory in experimental methods in quantitative biology. Random genetic processes, gene expression, cell cycle, developmental morphogens, genome sequencing.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, or BIOL_SCI 354-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Principles of Cell Signaling
courses.description: Emphasis on principles, components, and logic that are common to different cell signaling systems. Modern experimental strategies for studying cellular signaling as well as the implications of disrupting cell communication pathways in disease will be described.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

courses.name: Protein Structure and Function
courses.description: Structure and function of proteins; x-ray crystallography and NMR.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Biophysics
courses.description: Protein interaction with small molecules; protein tertiary structure determination.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: The Human Microbiome
courses.description: Course explores different communities of microorganisms in the human body – the gut, urogenital, oral, and skin microbiota, and how these communities contribute to or are altered in health and disease. Topics will include but are not limited to: the contribution of these communities to digestion and gut health, mood, obesity, the immune system, fertility and pregnancy, and neurological disorders.
courses.prereqs: BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0

courses.name: Functional Genomics
courses.description: Patterns of gene expression and their causes.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

courses.name: Biology of Cancer
courses.description: The disease of cancer: causation at the cell and molecular levels; treatment.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Stem Cells and Regeneration
courses.description: Developmental and molecular biology of tissue regeneration, with regard to regeneration from embryonic or adult stem cells. Discussion of conserved developmental pathways necessary for regeneration. Applications in regenerative medicine.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

courses.name: Advanced Molecular Biology
courses.description: Nucleic acid structure; DNA mutation, repair, recombination, replication, restriction, and modification; translation.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Advanced Molecular Biology
courses.description: Builds on topics introduced in introductory Molecular Biology. Topics discussed include techniques, transcriptional and translational regulation, epigenetics, replication, regulatory RNAs, DNA repair, and genetic engineering.

courses.name: Developmental Biology
courses.description: Molecular mechanisms underlying early embryonic development, including establishment of the body and organogenesis. Discussion of original literature.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Developmental Genetics Laboratory
courses.description: Development of independent projects alongside classic readings and experiments exploring key concepts in developmental biology.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Human Genomics
courses.description: This course will examine how the analysis of the human genome and its variation provides insight into diversity, human health and our evolutionary history.

courses.name: Molecular Genetics
courses.description: Exploration of recent advances that have revolutionized the fields of gene expression and cell regulation. Discussion of articles and primary research papers.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Evolution and Diversity: Mushroom Genetics and Genomics
courses.description: The occurrence of natural genetic variation is the raw material with which evolution has sculpted every species that has ever existed. In this laboratory-based course, students are immersed in the world of a widespread and biologically famous mushroom-forming fungus.
courses.prereqs: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

courses.name: Senior Thesis Colloquium
courses.description: Supervision while writing a Senior Thesis. Discussion of students' research. Instructor feedback on thesis drafts. Continued student research. Enrollment limited to Senior Biological Sciences majors hoping to graduate with Program Honors and/or to produce a Senior Thesis. Registration required for all Honors candidates.

courses.name: Tutorial in Biology
courses.description: Supervised reading and discussion or supervised laboratory work. P/N only.

courses.name: Independent Research
courses.description: Supervised independent research project.

courses.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Information to 1) help students determine if BME is the right major for them and 2) learn how to make the most of their undergraduate experience. The field of biomedical engineering, career and research opportunities, ethics.

courses.name: BME Lab: Experimental Design
courses.description: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports.

courses.name: Introduction to Biomedical Statistics
courses.description: Basic statistical concepts presented with emphasis on their relevance to biological and medical investigations.

courses.name: Thermodynamics
courses.description: Physical and chemical principles as applied to biological systems and medical devices. Topics include material balances, thermodynamics, solution chemistry, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, transport, and kinetics.

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics and their applications to biological systems.

courses.name: Introduction to Biomechanics
courses.description: Analysis of stresses and deformations in solids. Problems in biomechanics, with emphasis on assumptions appropriate to modeling biological materials including bone, skin, muscle, and cell membranes.

courses.name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
courses.description: Functional/structural aspects of mammalian nervous system. Neural biophysics. Laboratory exercises.

courses.name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
courses.description: Rigorous overview of cardiovascular and respiratory anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology. Case studies and a design team project.
courses.prereqs: Students must have taken MATH 228-1 or be a BME graduate student in order to register for this course; junior standing recommended

courses.name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
courses.description: Cellular mechanisms of and quantitative systems' approach to human renal, digestive, endocrine, and metabolic physiology.

courses.name: Biomedical Signals and Circuits
courses.description: Time and frequency domain analysis: convolution representation, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, frequency response, filtering, sampling.

courses.name: Biomedical Systems Analysis
courses.description: Introduction to linear systems analysis. Time and frequency domain techniques for analyzing linear systems, emphasizing their applications to biomedical systems. MATLAB-based problem sets and lab illustrate topics covered in class.
courses.prereqs: BMD_ENG 207-0 (can also be taken concurrently); BMD_ENG 308-0; BMD_ENG 220-0, IEMS 303-0, or MECH_ENG 359-0; GEN_ENG 205-4

courses.name: Computational Genomics
courses.description: The course introduces state-of-the-art genomic sequencing technologies and computational modeling of high-throughput sequencing datasets. Through the course, students will learn how to apply these experimental and computational genomics technologies to study gene expression regulation underlying various biological processes, such as oncogenesis. Students will also apply computational and statistical skills, using linux and R/Matlab/Python.

courses.name: Biochemical Sensors
courses.description: Theory, design, and applications of chemical sensors used in medical diagnosis and patient monitoring. Electrochemical and optical sensors.

courses.name: Visual Engineering Science
courses.description: Mammalian visual system. Physiological optics.  Visual image representation and interpretation. Visual adaptation. Motion. Color vision.

courses.name: Introduction to Medical Imaging
courses.description: Diagnostic X-rays; X-ray film and radiographic image; computed tomography; ultrasound.

courses.name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
courses.description: Nuclear magnetic resonance; two-dimensional Fourier transform, spinecho and gradientecho imaging; gradient and RF hardware.

courses.name: Modern Optical Microscopy & Imaging
courses.description: Rigorous introduction to principles, current trends, emerging technologies, and biomedical applications of modern optical microscopy.

courses.name: Biomaterials and Medical Devices
courses.description: Structure-property relationships for biomaterials. Metal, ceramic, and polymeric implant materials and their implant applications. Interactions of materials with the body. Taught with MAT_SCI 370-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
courses.prereqs: BIOL_SCI 215-0; BIOL_SCI 219-0; MAT_SCI 201-0 or MAT_SCI 301-0; senior standing

courses.name: Biological Performance of Materials
courses.description: Structure-property relationships of materials, physical chemistry of surfaces and interfaces, materials-tissue interactions, applications to the selection and design of materials for medical implants and devices.

courses.name: Tissue Engineering
courses.description: In vivo molecular, cellular, and organ engineering, with emphasis on the foundations, techniques, experiments, and clinical applications of tissue engineering.

courses.name: Foundations of Regenerative Engineering
courses.description: Embryonic development, stem cell engineering, somatic regeneration, genome and transcriptome modifications, cell and tissue-level regenerative engineering.

courses.name: Applications of Regenerative Engineering
courses.description: Mechanisms of human disease, development and application of molecular, cellular, and tissue-level regenerative engineering strategies to selected human disorders, including neurodegenerative disorders, stroke, cystic fibrosis, cirrhosis, diabetes, muscular degenerative disorders, and skin injury.

courses.name: Bioelectronics
courses.description: Development and design of sensors, stimulators, and their medical devices for biointegrated electronics. Materials design and fabrication of passive and active components for sensitive, multimodal, and robust wearable and implantable devices.

courses.name: Bioelectronics Lab
courses.description: Laboratories focused on the practical implementation, instrumentation, and fabrication of wearables and skinsensing. Applications range from vital sign monitoring to rehabilitation.

courses.name: Control of Human Limbs and Their  Artificial Replacements
courses.description: Human movement, biomechanics, skeletal and muscular anatomy, comparative anatomy, muscle physiology, and locomotion. Engineering design of artificial limbs.
courses.prereqs: senior standing with engineering or physical science background

courses.name: Biomechanics of Movement
courses.description: Engineering mechanics applied to analyze human movement, including models of muscle and tendon, kinematics of joints, and dynamics of multi-joint movement. Applications in sports, rehabilitation, and orthopedics.

courses.name: Mechanics of Biological Tissue
courses.description: Stress and strain for small and large deformations. Nonlinear elastic, viscoelastic, pseudo-elastic, and biphasic models.

courses.name: Intermediate Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics. Kinematics, mass and momentum balances, constitutive relations. Navier-Stokes equations and methods of solution. Sealing techniques.

courses.name: Transport Fundamentals
courses.description: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer.

courses.name: Medical Devices, Disease & Global Health
courses.description: Health systems and technologies to address health problems of the world's underserved populations, with special emphasis on developing countries.

courses.name: Health Systems Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to health systems in the context of disease burden with special emphasis in developing countries.  We examine healthcare systems, financing, data and analytics. The course focuses primarily on health-related issues confronting South Africa and the associated social and economic impact.

courses.name: Health Technology Management
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to formal concepts and methodologies used in support of health technology planning, assessment and adoption - and related decision making - as part of cost-effective healthcare delivery.  Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

courses.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
courses.description: Open-ended team-designed projects in the medical devices arena. Systems approach requiring design strategy and concepts, including reliability, safety, ethics, economic analysis, marketing, FDA regulations, and patents. Written and oral reports.
courses.prereqs: BMD_ENG 207-0, BMD_ENG 220-0, BMD_ENG 250-0, BMD_ENG 270-0, BMD_ENG 271-0, BMD_ENG 308-0, BMD_ENG 309-0 and MAT_SCI 201-0

courses.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
courses.description: Development of a design project initiated during the previous quarter.

courses.name: Biomedical Engineering Design
courses.description: Continuation of a design project; independent study. May not be repeated for credit.
courses.prereqs: BMD_ENG 390-1 or BMD_ENG 390-2; consent of instructor

courses.name: HealthCare Techology Innovation and Design
courses.description: Principles and practice of medical device design for the developing world.  Evaluation of user needs in the environment of under-resourced segments of South African health care system.  Validation and verification of engineering design solutions.  Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

courses.name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis

courses.name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis

courses.name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Advanced Systems Physiology
courses.description: Physiology of the central and peripheral nervous systems. Biophysics of the nerve cell from an engineering perspective. General overview and in-depth study of original work.

courses.name: Advanced Systems Physiology
courses.description: Physiology of the heart, circulatory system, lungs, and respiration from an engineering perspective. General overview and in-depth study of original work.

courses.name: Advanced Systems Physiology
courses.description: Physiology of the renal, digestive, and endocrine systems. Membrane transport, epithelia, and second messenger systems from an engineering perspective. General overview and in-depth study of original work.

courses.name: Special Topics in Systems Physiology
courses.description: Course will train biomedical engineering PhD students in critical analysis of scientific papers, specifically in systems physiology.  Instruction in the presentation of scientific data in a manner appropriate for delivery at professional scientific meetings.  BMD_ENG 404-1 will cover neural systems physiology, BMD_ENG 404-2 will cover cardiovascular and respiratory physiology, and BMD_ENG 404-3 will cover endocrine, gastrointestinal, hepatic and renal physiology.

courses.name: Special Topics in Systems Physiology
courses.description: Course will train biomedical engineering PhD students in critical analysis of scientific papers, specifically in systems physiology.  Instruction in the presentation of scientific data in a manner appropriate for delivery at professional scientific meetings.  BMD_ENG 404-1 will cover neural systems physiology, BMD_ENG 404-2 will cover cardiovascular and respiratory physiology, and BMD_ENG 404-3 will cover endocrine, gastrointestinal, hepatic and renal physiology.

courses.name: Special Topics in Systems Physiology
courses.description: Course will train biomedical engineering PhD students in critical analysis of scientific papers, specifically in systems physiology. Instruction in the presentation of scientific data in a manner appropriate for delivery at professional scientific meetings. BMD_ENG 404-1 will cover neural systems physiology, BMD_ENG 404-2 will cover cardiovascular and respiratory physiology, and BMD_ENG 404-3 will cover endocrine, gastrointestinal, hepatic and renal physiology.

courses.name: Experimental Design and Measurement
courses.description: Introductory quantitative skills required to conduct experimental research and analyze resulting data. Principles of measurement, modeling of experimental data, and statistical design of experiments.

courses.name: fMRI (Functional Imaging)
courses.description: Cutting-edge functional imaging techniques and their applications in research and clinical practice. MRI is the predominantly discussed modality,but also includes other modalities.

courses.name: MRI Modeling of Brain Physiology
courses.description: Modeling of brain activity, blood flow, and tissue properties using different MRI data, including fMRI, Arterial Spin Labeling, and Diffusion Weighted Imaging. Programming-based analysis assignments in real and simulated data. Critical analysis of the literature to develop new research questions in a clinical or neuroscience application of the student’s choice.  Students should have already completed an MRI course.

courses.name: Advanced MR Imaging
courses.description: The use and design of MR pulse sequences; emphasis on image contrast mechanisms and some of the more widely used MR acquisition strategies.

courses.name: Advanced Physical and Applied Optics
courses.description: Theory and applications of the state-of-the-art physical optics. Topics include wave optics, Gaussian optics, Fourier optics, light propagation in continuous and turbid media, light scattering, statistical optics, and fiber optics.

courses.name: Organic Nanomaterials
courses.description: The materials science and chemistry of soft nanomaterials for myriad applications including nanomedicine. Preparative and synthetic approaches to organized, assembled, discrete nanomaterials will be described. Course will include an in depth discussion of advanced characterization techniques and strategies for this class of material.

courses.name: Biomaterials in Synthetic Biol
courses.description: A course that focuses on the emerging principles in synthetic biology that have the capability to expand the functionality of biomaterials: what properties of biomaterials 'matter', emerging techniques to control the biological-material interface, and ways of inscribing the vital functions found in biological systems into synthetic materials.

courses.name: Biomaterials in Synthetic Biology
courses.description: A course that focuses on the emerging principles in synthetic biology that have the capability to expand the functionality of biomaterials: what properties of biomaterials 'matter', emerging techniques to control the biological-material interface, and ways of inscribing the vital functions found in biological systems into synthetic materials.

courses.name: Cardiovascular Biology and Engineering
courses.description: Molecular basis of cardiovascular development, performance, and pathogenesis; engineering analysis of cardiovascular functions; and fundamentals of cardiovascular engineering and regeneration.

courses.name: Transport Through Connective Tissue
courses.description: Use of porous media theory to examine principles governing fluid flow and mass transfer in extracellular matrices and the application of these principles to tissue engineering.

courses.name: Sensory Acquisition
courses.description: The class involves a neuroethological approach to the nervous system, comparing how information is encoded and processed across sensory modalities, and examining the relation between sensing and movement.

courses.name: Advanced Signal Processing Methods in Neuropathophysiology
courses.description: A quantitative approach to the study and treatment of neurological diseases, including stroke, SCI and visual deficits. Incorporates neuropathophysiology, computer modeling and systems analysis.

courses.name: Biomechanical Modeling & Simulation of Human Movement
courses.description: This course is designed to familiarize the student with the development and use of   biomechanical models to simulate motion.

courses.name: Biomedical Robotics
courses.description: A perspective on robotics technologies applied to, and inspired by, themes of biomedical research and practice.

courses.name: Computational Neuromechanics and Neuroethology
courses.description: Understanding the embodied nervous system through analysis of evolution, behavior, sensory ecology, and the computational principles / algorithms that the nervous system needs to solve for execution of natural behaviors.

courses.name: Neural Control and Mechanics of Movement
courses.description: Muscle mechanics and relevant spinal cord neurophysiology as the basis for understanding neural control of movement.

courses.name: Transport Fundamentals
courses.description: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer with problems appropriate for graduate students.

courses.name: Special Advanced Topics in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Current topics of interest for graduate students. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Permission of instructor and department required. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Graduate Research Seminar in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: A series of seminars covering current research interests in biomedical engineering. Attendance by first-year Biomedical Engineering graduate students required.

courses.name: Research
