courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Accounting
courses.description: Introduction to both financial and managerial accounting. Use of organizations' financial statements for making decisions.

courses.name: Marketing Management
courses.description: Basic principles and applications of marketing management. Marketing segmentation, target marketing, brand positioning, consumer behavior, channels strategy, pricing, advertising and promotion.

courses.name: Leadership in Organizations
courses.description: Social science tools for solving organizational problems and influencing individuals, groups, and organizations. Competitive decision making, reward system design, team building, strategic negotiation, political dynamics, corporate culture, and strategic organizational design.

courses.name: Corporate Finance
courses.description: Effects of time and uncertainty on valuation and decision making. Discounting techniques, stock and bond valuation, capital budgeting, firm valuation, capital asset pricing model, financial options. May not receive credit for both this course and ECON 360-1. Not for students who have previously taken KELLG_FE 310-0.
courses.prereqs: ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1; and BUS_INST 301-0

courses.name: Business and Economic Institutions in Historical Perspective
courses.description: Factors affecting economic growth and challenges to achieving economic success. Organization of firms and financial markets; corporate governance; innovation; financial crises; income inequality; race and gender.
courses.prereqs: ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; and MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1

courses.name: Professional Linkage Seminar
courses.description: Content varies. Possible topics include entrepreneurship, investment banking, business ethics, global marketing, sports marketing, and nonprofit management. Prerequisites vary.

courses.name: Introduction to Career Development
courses.description: Course preparing students for the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program, internships, and fulltime employment. It includes units on job-search skills, self-assessment, transition to the workplace, workplace-management issues, and transition back to school.

courses.name: Cooperative Engineering Education
courses.description: Sequence of courses covering the work terms of students in the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program.

courses.description: Sequence of courses covering the work terms of students in the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program. Offered in partnership with the Global McCormick initiative.

Students are required to work directly with an entrepreneurial advisor of their choice including: entrepreneurship faculty, senior business executives, and other seasoned entrepreneurs.

courses.name: Paradigms and Strategies of Leadership
courses.description: ULP students' introduction to six foundational leadership assets: asking powerful questions, navigating and leading amid change, inspiring others through narrative, mobilizing difference to maximize team performance, thriving in collaborative and hierarchical settings, and responding to setbacks and failure with resilience. Components include weekly lectures, guest speakers, and discussion groups.

courses.name: Leading From Design
courses.description: Through readings, small group discussion, one-on-one coaching, self-assessment and reflecting on leadership and other life experiences, this course builds on the themes, models and concepts introduced in LDRSHP 204-0 (Paradigms and Strategies of Leadership), to help students develop a deeper self-awareness that serves as the foundation for the construction of their own individual leadership model.

courses.name: Special Topics in Leadership
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

courses.name: Field Studies in Leadership
courses.description: Students have the opportunity to leave a positive "leadership footprint" by fostering the success of a group, organization, or community. Spending at least 160 hours outside the classroom, they undertake a leadership role, an internship or externship, or a community engagement experience, exploring leadership models and concepts through application. Consent of instructor required.

courses.name: Leadership Independent Study
courses.description: Independent study on a Leadership subject supervised by a faculty member and concluding with a final report or project.

courses.name: Leadership By Design
courses.description: Students improve overall leadership effectiveness by gaining insight into their unique leadership capabilities, and by developing their ability to identify and draw out the same from others. Students also learn how to equip others to solve problems, create opportunities and improve performance. Components include lecture and discussion.

courses.name: Leadership Coaching
courses.description: Students meet one-on-one with a trained coach who uses the practices and approaches of executive leadership coaching, such as Socratic questioning, guided behavioral experiments and researched assessments to help students understand their own authentic style of leadership, meet immediate challenges and prepare for leadership roles they will encounter after graduation. A successfully completed coaching engagement will consist of four to six one-hour sessions in one academic quarter.

courses.name: Engineering of Chemical and Biological Processes
courses.description: Survey of engineering principles as they are applied to processes involving chemical and biological transformations. Examples from the chemical, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, food processing, electronics, and other industries. Impact of economics, ethics, and other nontechnical constraints.

courses.name: Analysis of Chemical Process Systems
courses.description: Introduction to process systems. Material balances and stoichiometry. Analysis of process system flow sheets. Introduction to departmental computing facilities. Basic numerical analysis.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0, CHEM 152-0, or CHEM 172-0; GEN_ENG 205-3 (may be taken concurrently)

courses.name: Thermodynamics
courses.description: The first and second laws of thermodynamics. Entropy and equilibrium. Material and energy balances. Equations of state and properties of fluids. Solutions, phase equilibria, and chemical reactions.

courses.name: Phase Equilibrium and Staged Separations
courses.description: Thermodynamic models of mixtures and phase equilibrium. Analysis and design of staged separation processes such as distillation, absorption, stripping, and extraction.

courses.name: Molecular & Cell Biology for Engineers
courses.description: Introduction to cell and molecular biology concepts that provide the foundation for modern biotechnology and bioengineering.

courses.name: Kinetics and Reactor Engineering
courses.description: Chemical reaction kinetics with application to the design of chemical reactors.

courses.name: Probability and Statistics for Chemical Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to probability theory and statistical methods necessary for analyzing the behavior of processes and experiments. Statistical tests for detecting significant changes in process parameters.
courses.prereqs: MATH 220-1, MATH 220-2, MATH 228-1, & MATH 228-2 (formerly listed as MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, MATH 230-0, & MATH 234-0), or ES_APPM 252-1 & ES_APPM 252-2

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Derivation and applications of continuity and Navier-Stokes equations. Macroscopic mass, momentum, and energy balance. Dimensional analysis: friction factors in pipes and packed beds; drag coefficients.
courses.prereqs: completion of mathematics requirements with no grades of D; GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better)

courses.name: Heat Transfer
courses.description: The differential equations of energy transport. Solutions for various applications.
courses.prereqs: completion of mathematics requirements with no grades of D; GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better); CHEM_ENG 321-0 recommended

courses.name: Mass Transfer
courses.description: Diffusion and rate concepts; application to distillation, extraction, absorption, humidification, drying.

courses.name: Molecular Engineering and Statistical Mechanics
courses.description: Basic statistical mechanics. Applications to thermodynamics, kinetics, and transport of various engineering systems, including frontier areas of chemical and biological engineering. Not open to students who have taken CHEM_ENG 406-0, CHEM 342-3, or PHYSICS 332-0.
courses.prereqs: CHEM_ENG 211-0 or another thermodynamics course; courses in probability and statistics, heat transfer, or other transport recommended

courses.name: Dynamics and Control of Chemical and Biological Processes
courses.description: Dynamic behavior of chemical process components. Feedback control principles.

courses.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
courses.description: Operation and control of process equipment for the determination of operating data. Analysis and written presentation of results.

courses.name: Process Optimization for Energy and Sustainability
courses.description: Modern techniques and application to the design and operation of chemical process systems. Steady-state and dynamic methods. Experimental search for the optimum.

courses.name: Process Economics, Design, & Evaluation
courses.description: Preliminary design of industrial processes for the production of chemical and allied products by the application of the engineering sciences and economics.

courses.name: Chemical Engineering Design Projects
courses.description: Design of chemical and process plants applying the principles of unit operations, thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, and economics. Mechanical design and selection of chemical process equipment.

courses.name: Chemical Product Design
courses.description: Properties and selection of chemicals for products from single-molecule pharmaceuticals to devices to manufactured products such as food and consumer goods.

courses.name: Introduction to Polymers
courses.description: Polymerization mechanisms and their relation to molecular structure, polymerization processes, and the mechanical properties of polymers, especially flow behavior.
courses.prereqs: CHEM_ENG 211-0 or other thermodynamics course; CHEM 210-1

courses.name: Chemical Processing and the Environment
courses.description: Application of chemical engineering fundamentals to environmental problems. Chemistry and mechanisms, chemical reaction and rate, and transport emphasized. Risk assessment and analysis revealed through case studies.

courses.name: Sustainability, Technology, and Society
courses.description: Technical discussion of selected topics related to sustainability, sustainable development, global climate changes, natural and renewal resources and utilization, industrial ecology, eco-efficiency, technology related to sustainability such as biofuel, electrification of transportation, and water purification, and role of policy and business risk assessment.
courses.prereqs: junior standing in science or engineering; familiarity with process system analysis, energy and material balances (such as found in CHEM_ENG 210-0 or CIV_ENV 260-0)

courses.name: Quantitative Methods in Life Cycle Analysis
courses.description: Lifecycle analysis (LCA) framework for environmental assessment of technology systems, focusing on modeling methods for systems mass and energy flows, process and input-output-based systems inventories, environmental impact analysis, and methods for robust engineering decisions. MECH_ENG 367-0 is taught with CHEM_ENG 367-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Bionanotechnology
courses.description: Physical biology of the cell and its implications for nanotechnology, with a focus on the quantitative description of sizes, shapes, times, and energies at the nanoscale.

courses.name: Biotechnology and Global Health
courses.description: Recent advances in synthetic biology and genetic, metabolic, and tissue engineering. Design, development, and commercialization of healthcare technologies for countries in the developing world and the challenges of deploying preventative, diagnostic, and therapeutic products in these settings.

courses.name: Biochemical Engineering
courses.description: Modern biochemical engineering. Life sciences: microbiology, biochemistry, and molecular genetics. Metabolic stoichiometry, energetics, growth kinetics, transport phenomena in bioreactors, and product recovery.
courses.prereqs: CHEM_ENG 307-0, CHEM_ENG 323-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Principles of Synthetic Biology
courses.description: Overview of synthetic biology's foundations in the natural sciences and engineering and its applications in medicine, biotechnology, and green chemistry. How engineering driven approaches may be used to accelerate design-build-test loops required for reprogramming existing biological systems and constructing new ones.
courses.prereqs: CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0)

courses.name: Bioseparations
courses.description: Downstream process in biotechnology. Separation and lysis of cells. Recovery of organelles and proteins. Protein separation and purification.
courses.prereqs: CHEM_ENG 323-0 (may be taken concurrently); CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0)

courses.name: Computational Biology: Analysis and Design of Living Systems
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental principles and methods for computational and mathematical analysis of natural and engineered biological systems. Emphasis is placed upon understanding and designing biological systems based upon conceptual framings including multi-scale networks, dynamic control, genetic circuits, and biological programs.

courses.name: Practical Biological Imaging
courses.description: Theory and practice of biological microscopy in a lab setting; image acquisition, analysis, and the ethics of image manipulation.

courses.name: Regulatory Sciences in Biotechnology
courses.description: Course on topics at the intersection of science, engineering, and biotech regulatory compliance. Federal regulations for drug product development; regulatory compliance processes and organizational structure; interface between biotechnology processes and regulatory sciences; global harmonization of regulations; regulatory documentation.

courses.name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Supervised investigation of a chemical engineering problem with submission of a final report.

courses.name: Advanced Thermodynamics
courses.description: Quantitative study of the fundamental principles of thermodynamics. Application of the laws of thermodynamics, concepts of equilibrium, equations of state, and properties of solutions to problems of engineering significance, including phase and chemical reaction equilibria.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Thermodynamics
courses.description: Selected topics from recent literature in thermodynamics.

courses.name: Chemical Engineering Kinetics and Reactor Design
courses.description: Interpretation of chemical rate selectivity data in homogeneous and heterogeneous reaction systems. Development and application of the theory of chemical kinetics, including collision, transition state, and surface reactivity approaches. Theory and analysis of reaction in heterogeneous phases. Reactor design with applications to and extension of ideal and nonideal reactor models: gas-solid, gas-liquid, and three-phase reactor design.

courses.name: Advanced Reactor Design
courses.description: Advanced engineering aspects of reactor design. Analysis of coupled transport processes and chemical reaction in application to realistic design and scale-up of various types of chemical reactors. Optimization problems in reactor design and operation.

courses.name: Principles of Heterogeneous Catalysis
courses.description: Recent publications in heterogeneous catalysis are reviewed along with formal lectures on fundamentals. Topics include kinetics and mechanisms of surface reactions, catalyst characterization, structure of solids, surface reactivity trends, active site concepts, importance of mass transfer, and examples of catalysis by metals, oxides, sulfides and zeolites.

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Derivation of Navier-Stokes equations and their application for solution of fluid mechanics problems in the inviscid fluid, creeping flow and boundary layer approximations.

courses.name: Heat and Mass Transfer
courses.description: Heat and Mass transfer by heat conduction, diffusion, and convection.  (Linear phenomena only; heat transfer by radiation, natural convection, and mass transfer in concentrated solutions are not discussed.)  Steady-state and transient processes.  General formulation, approximations, and model building.  Emphasis on developing physical insight.

courses.name: Applied Molecular Modeling
courses.description: Introduction to modern computational methods for calculating properties of reaction systems, as well as thermodynamics, transport, and structural properties of materials.

courses.name: Viscoelasticity & Flow in Polymer Systems
courses.description: Fundamental aspects of polymer rheology, including the theory of linear viscoelasticity, measurement of fundamental flow properties, constitutive equations, the kinetic- molecular theories of viscoelasticity, and polymer processing behavior.

courses.name: Polymerization Reaction Engineering
courses.description: Polymerization reactions and resulting molecular weight distributions; modeling of polymerization kinetics; batch, continuous stirred tank and tubular flow reactor design for optimal polymerizations; emulsion and catalyzed polymerizations; photoresist technology.

courses.name: Bioseparations
courses.description: Downstream processing in biotechnology. Separation and lysis of cells. Recovery of organelles and proteins. Protein separation and purification.

courses.name: Advances in Biotechnology
courses.description: The emergence of new tools and ideas in biotechnology continues to accelerate, and this course is an introduction to a range of topics at the forefront of this field. The objective of this class is to expose students to the multidisciplinary research, and provide technical and intellectual skills from fields such as biochemical engineering, biochemistry, bioengineering, biomaterials, metabolic engineering, molecular biology, nanobiotechnology, pharmacology, and tissue engineering.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Chemical Engineering
courses.description: Selected topics from recent literature.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Thorough study and submission of a report on a chemical engineering problem. Permission of instructor and department required. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.description: Department seminar

courses.name: Professional Development in Research in Chemical and Biological Engineering
courses.description: A required class for all PhD students in Chemical and Biological Engineering.  This class will cover necessary skills and best practices for research, including expectation and intensity, developing and maintaining a network, running an effective meeting, effective correspondence, interfacing with collaborators, effective oral and written scientific communication, data management, and digging into the research literature.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Introduction to Calculus and Chemistry
courses.description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. Introduction to calculus and general chemistry. Taken with BIOL_SCI 100-0.

courses.name: Introduction to Problem Solving in Chemistry
courses.description: For participants in Bridge I summer program. Developing facility with quantitative tools to solve problems in chemistry.

courses.name: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry
courses.description: Solution strategies for traditional word problems and their application to basic chemistry quantitative problems: dimensional analysis, chemical equations, stoichiometry, limiting reagents.

courses.name: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry
courses.description: Solution strategies for traditional word problems and their application to basic chemistry quantitative problems: dimensional analysis, chemical equations, stoichiometry, limiting reagents.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 110-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: General Chemistry 1
courses.description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, special topics in modern chemistry.

courses.name: General Chemistry 1
courses.description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of the elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, special topics in modern chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 141-CN.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 110-CN

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry 1
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 131-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Solutions and colligative properties, chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry, special topics in modern chemistry.

courses.name: General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Solutions and colligative properties, chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry, special topics in modern chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 142-CN.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 131-CN and CHEM 141-CN

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 132-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: General Chemistry Laboratory 1
courses.description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 131-0.

courses.name: General Chemistry 1 Lab
courses.description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Credit for this course is 0.34 units. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 131-CN.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 110-CN

courses.name: General Chemistry Laboratory 2
courses.description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 132-0.

courses.name: General Chemistry Lab 2
courses.description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. The course must be taken concurrently with CHEM 132-CN. Credit for this course is 0.34 units.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 131-CN

courses.name: Accelerated General Chemistry 1
courses.description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, gas laws, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, special topics in modern chemistry.
courses.prereqs: permission of department by placement exam

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Accelerated General Chemistry 1
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 151-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Accelerated General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Solutions and colligative properties, chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry, special topics in modern chemistry.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Accelerated General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 152-0.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory 1
courses.description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 151-0.

courses.name: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory 2
courses.description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 152-0.

courses.name: Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Review of mole problems and stoichiometry; descriptive chemistry, elements, compounds, and inorganic reactions; gas laws; phase equilibria and colligative properties; chemical equilibrium; aqueous equilibria; topics in chemical bonding and molecular structure. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 181-0.
courses.prereqs: department placement exam or appropriate AP credit

courses.name: Advanced General Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Thermodynamics and equilibrium; chemical kinetics and mechanism; electrochemistry; electronic structure of the atom and quantum theory; advanced topics in chemical bonding; coordination compounds; solid-state chemistry; nuclear chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 182-0.

courses.name: Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory techniques for studying chemical analysis and chemical reactions relevant to environmental or materials research. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 171-0.

courses.name: Advanced General Physical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Study of the physical chemistry (acid base chemistry, kinetics, etc.) behind the operating principles of biosensors. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on these experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 172-0.

courses.name: Foundations of Organic Chemistry
courses.description: For participants in Bridge II summer program.  Exploring foundations and problem-solving skills in organic chemistry.

courses.name: Chemistry of Nature and Culture
courses.description: Chemistry for the nonscientist. Chemicals commonly encountered in everyday life. With laboratory.

courses.name: Chemistry of Nature and Culture
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Basic concepts of structure, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds. The chemistry of hydrocarbons and alcohols.
courses.prereqs: completion of General Chemistry Sequence  with grade of C- or better, or equivalent transfer credit with qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam

courses.name: Organic Chemistry
courses.description: The chemistry of aromatic, carbonyl, and nitrogen compounds; characterization of organic substances by chemical and spectral methods; reaction mechanisms. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 230-B.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 210-A

courses.name: Organic Chemistry III
courses.description: The chemistry of poly-functional compounds of biological and medicinal interest. Modern organic syn-thesis, bioorganic chemistry, and recent developments in organic chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 230-C.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 210-B

courses.name: Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. Basic concepts of structure, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds. The chemistry of hydrocarbons and alcohols. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 232-1. No P/N registration.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), and consent of department, enrollment in ISP, or department placement

courses.name: Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of aromatic, carbonyl, and nitrogen compounds; characterization of organic substances by chemical and spectral methods; reaction mechanisms. No P/N registration. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 232-2.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of poly-functional compounds of biological and medicinal interest. Modern organic syn-thesis, bioorganic chemistry, and recent developments in organic chemistry. No P/N registration. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry I
courses.description: Foundational concepts in organic chemistry will be introduced. Topics include structure and properties of common functional groups, acidity/basicity, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-1

courses.name: Organic Chemistry II
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in organic chemistry will be covered.  The topics will include important functional groups and will include:  nomenclature, structure, properties, and multistep synthesis. Reaction mechanisms for organic transformations will be presented, and synthesis strategies will be covered.
courses.prereqs: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-2

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Advanced concepts in modern organic chemistry will be introduced. The material will focus on recent developments in synthetic organic chemistry, including: concerted/pericyclic reactions, catalysis, green/environmental chemistry, automated synthesis, and combinatorial/screening methods.
courses.prereqs: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry I
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-1. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry II
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-2. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry III
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-3. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Introductory Instrumental  Analysis
courses.description: Introduction to basic laboratory techniques in analytical chemistry and spectroscopy. Topics include infrared and UV-visible spectroscopy, gas and liquid chromatography, elemental and thermal analysis, simple x-ray diffraction, error analysis, and literature searching techniques.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

courses.name: Organic Chemistry II Laboratory
courses.description: Instruction in experimental techniques of modern organic chemistry emphasizing chemical separations, spectroscopic characterization, and reactions of alkanes, alkenes, alkyl halides, alcohols, carbonyls, esters, and aromatic compounds. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 210-B.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 210-A

courses.name: Organic Chemistry III Laboratory
courses.description: Experimental techniques of modern organic chemistry emphasizing chemical separations, spectroscopic characterization, and reactions such as amide synthesis, Grignard reaction, aldol condensation, Robinson annulation, and DielsAlder reaction. Must be taken concurrently CHEM 210-C.
courses.prereqs: grade of C- or higher in CHEM 210-B

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
courses.description: For ISP students and chemistry majors. Molecular modeling, unknown identification by spectroscopic methods, and experimental techniques of modern chemistry emphasizing reactions of alkanes, alkenes, alkyl halides, alcohols, and carbonyls. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 212-1.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
courses.description: For ISP students and chemistry majors. Techniques of modern organic chemistry including NMR spectroscopy and reactions such as electrophilic aromatic substitution, esterification, Grignard reaction, aldol condensation, Robinson annulation, and DielsAlder reaction. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 212-2 (C- or better).

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Lab I
courses.description: Standard laboratory techniques in organic chemistry will be covered. Techniques will focus on the isolation and purification of organic compounds as well as the use of spectroscopic methods to determine identity and purity.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-1

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Lab II
courses.description: Complete laboratory experiments focusing on standard synthetic organic chemistry will be conducted each week. Students will complete a prelab worksheet including stoichiometric calculations, prediction of reaction outcome, and identification of safety protocols.
courses.prereqs: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-2

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry Lab
courses.description: Current laboratory practices for organic synthesis will be introduced. Reactions will include mechanistically complex multi-step process for the preparation of compounds related to topical themes from academic research and industrial chemistry. Synthetic targets will include complex small molecules, polymers, and molecules of biological relevance.
courses.prereqs: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3

courses.name: Thermodynamics
courses.description: NPEP course

courses.name: Principles of Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to the field of physical organic chemistry. Topics include bonding and structure, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, acids and bases, reactivity, and reaction mechanisms. CHEM 301-0 and CHEM 401-0 are taught together.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 212-3 or CHEM 210-3 and CHEM 230-3 (C- or better) and 1 quarter of physical chemistry; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Principles of Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Topics in advanced inorganic chemistry. CHEM 302-0 and CHEM 402-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Principles of Physical Chemistry
courses.description: An overview of advanced topics in physical chemistry. CHEM 303-0 and CHEM 403-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Chemistry of Life Processes
courses.description: Topics in the chemistry and biochemistry of life processes. Taught with CHEM 405-0.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and 1 biochemistry course; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Environmental Chemistry
courses.description: Topics in the physical chemistry of the environment. Taught with CHEM 406-0.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); MATH 230-2, MATH 250-0; PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 135-2; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Materials and Nanochemistry
courses.description: Introduction to frontier research at the interface of chemistry and materials science. CHEM 307-0 and CHEM 407-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Design, Synthesis, and Applications of Nanomaterials
courses.description: Fabrication, chemical synthesis, assembly, and characterization of controlled-dimensionality materials, including metals, semiconductors, oxides, polymers, and mesoporous scaffolds. Interfacial phenomena and particle stability, nano forms of carbon, and material design. Taught with CHEM 408-0.
courses.prereqs: 1 quarter of physical chemistry or consent of instructor

courses.name: Polymer Chemistry
courses.description: This course will cover the design and synthesis of polymers, including reaction mechanisms, characterization, and structure-property relationships. CHEM 309-0 is taught with CHEM 409-0. Prerequisites (for undergraduates only): CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and one of the following courses: CHEM 307-0, CHEM 313-0, CHEM 319-0, CHEM 412-0, or CHEM 415-0.

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry 1. Advanced concepts of organic reactivity and selectivity in synthesis.
courses.description: Strategies and tactics involved in complex target synthesis. Modern reaction classes as applied to chemical synthesis, coupled to in-depth discussion of the underlying key principles of synthesis design and execution, are covered in the class. Students will gain experience in problem solving, creative thinking, structural analysis and presentation skills.

courses.name: Bioorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to using chemical principles in biology and medicine. Experimental techniques and experiments in chemical biology. Suitable for students in chemistry, engineering, and biology. Taught with CHEM 415-0.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and 1 quarter of biology; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Medicinal Chemistry: the Organic Chemistry of Drug Design and Action
courses.description: Introduction to principles of drug design and mechanisms of drug action from a chemical viewpoint. Historical introduction, drug design and development, receptors, enzymes and enzyme inhibitors, DNA, drug metabolism, and prodrugs.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); or consent of instructor

courses.name: Advanced Organic Synthesis - Concepts and Applications
courses.description: Synthesis of natural products and other medicinally relevant organic compounds. Retrosynthetic analysis, substructure keying, and pattern recognition. Classic and modern organic reactions. Terpenes, alkaloids, polyketides, steroids, proteins, and pharmaceuticals.

courses.name: Analytical Chemistry
courses.description: Principles and applications of analytical methods, with emphasis on advanced separation science, dynamic electrochemistry, and advanced mass spectrometry. No P/N registration.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Descriptive chemistry of some important elements. Current concepts and models of chemical bonding.

courses.name: Thermodynamics
courses.description: Laws of applications of thermodynamics. Thermochemistry, chemical potentials, solution thermodynamics, nonideal gases.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); MATH 230-1; PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 136-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2 (PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2 may be taken concurrently)

courses.name: Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
courses.description: Quantum mechanics with emphasis on atomic and molecular electronic structure. Electronic, vibrational, rotational, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy.
courses.prereqs: MATH 230-1 (MATH 230-2 recommended also); PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 136-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2

courses.name: Kinetics and Statistical Thermodynamics
courses.description: Chemical kinetics, including experimental techniques and theories of rate processes. Statistical mechanics, including Boltzmann distribution, partition functions, and applications to thermodynamics.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry for ISP
courses.description: Gas laws and properties; kinetic theory; first, second, and third laws; phase equilibria; mixtures, phase diagrams, statistical thermodynamics, kinetics.
courses.prereqs: ISP enrollment; CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); MATH 281-1, MATH 281-2, MATH 281-3; or consent of department

courses.name: Advanced Laboratory 1
courses.description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: mass spectrometry, chromatography, NMR spectroscopy, and organic synthesis techniques.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 220-0; and CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3, and CHEM 235-3 (C- or better); or equivalent

courses.name: Advanced Laboratory 2
courses.description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy, polymer characterization methods, electrochemistry, x-ray crystallography, atomic spectroscopy, and inorganic synthesis techniques.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 333-0 and CHEM 350-1 (C- or better) or equivalent

courses.name: Advanced Laboratory 3
courses.description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: infrared and Raman spectroscopy, electronic spectroscopy, fast kinetics, organic and inorganic synthesis techniques in a self-guided project.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 342-2 or equivalent and CHEM 350-2 (C- or better)

courses.name: Nanopatterning: Top-down meets Bottom-up
courses.description: Introduction to current problems in nanoscale science and technology; hands-on experience with nanoscale characterization tools and benchtop nanoscale experiments. With laboratory.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

courses.name: Green Chemistry
courses.description: Practices of environmentally benign chemistry as applied to the chemical industry. Introduction to the concept and discipline of green chemistry; growth and expansion of the discipline in historical context from its origins in the early 1990s to the present.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work for superior students through supervised reading, research, and discussion.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Faculty-directed research. Must be taken P/N for first 2 quarters.

courses.name: Principles of Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to the field of physical organic chemistry. Topics include bonding and structure, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, acids and bases, reactivity, and reaction mechanisms. CHEM 301-0 and CHEM 401-0 are taught together.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 212-3 or CHEM 210-3 and CHEM 230-3 (C- or better) and 1 quarter of physical chemistry; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Principles of Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Topics in advanced inorganic chemistry. CHEM 302-0 and CHEM 402-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Principles of Physical Chemistry
courses.description: An overview of advanced topics in physical chemistry. CHEM 303-0 and CHEM 403-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Chemistry of Life Processes
courses.description: Topics in the chemistry and biochemistry of life processes. Taught with CHEM 305-0.
courses.prereqs: full year of organic chemistry and 1 biochemistry course; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Environmental Chemistry
courses.description: Topics in the physical chemistry of the environment. Taught with CHEM 306-0.
courses.prereqs: full year of organic chemistry; background in multivariable integral calculus and differential equations; at least two quarters of general physics; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Materials and Nanochemistry
courses.description: Introduction to frontier research at the interface of chemistry and materials science. CHEM 307-0 and CHEM 407-0 are taught together.

courses.name: Design, Synthesis, and Applications of Nanomaterials
courses.description: Approaches to the fabrication, chemical synthesis, assembly and characterization of controlled dimensionality materials including metals, semiconductors, oxides, polymers, and mesoporous scaffolds. Topics include interfacial phenomena and particle stability, nano-forms of carbon, and applications-driven material design. Taught with CHEM 308-0.

courses.name: Polymer Chemistry
courses.description: This course will cover the design and synthesis of polymers, including reaction mechanisms, characterization, and structure-property relationships. CHEM 309-0 is taught with CHEM 409-0. Prerequisites (for undergraduates only): full year of organic chemistry; and one of the following courses: CHEM 307-0/CHEM 407-0, CHEM 313-0/CHEM 413-0, CHEM 319-0/CHEM 419-0, CHEM 412-0, or CHEM 415-0.

courses.name: Physical Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Methods in the investigation of reaction mechanisms. Stereochemistry, conformational analysis, thermochemistry, kinetics, isotope effects, solvent effects, quantitative structure-reactivity relationships, pericyclic reactions, and photochemistry.

courses.name: Organic Spectroscopy
courses.description: Applications of contemporary spectroscopic methods to organic structural and dynamic problems.

courses.name: Organometallic Reaction Mechanisms
courses.description: Organic reaction mechanisms, including carbocations, carbanions, carbenes, nitrenes, radicals, rearrangement reactions and photochemistry.

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry 1. Advanced concepts of organic reactivity and selectivity in synthesis.
courses.description: Advanced topics in organic chemistry: bonding, reaction intermediates, functional group transformations, reaction methodology; approaches to natural product synthesis.

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry II
courses.description: Advanced topics in organic chemistry continued: organometallic reaction methodology, catalysis, and their application to total synthesis.

courses.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Topics vary. Recent topics include carbanions, catalysis of organic reactions, enzyme mechanisms, natural products, nucleotide chemistry, and photochemistry.

courses.name: Practical Training in Chemical Biology Methods and Experimental Design
courses.description: Experimental design, data analysis,  mass spectrometry; proteomics, in vivo and molecular imaging, small molecule synthesis and purification; high-throughput screening, x-ray crystallography, analysis of bioelements.

courses.name: Photochemistry
courses.description: The physical and chemical behavior of electronically excited molecules. Methods for the investigation of excited state phenomena and major classes of photochemical reactions.

courses.name: Organometallic Chemistry and Homogeneous Catalysis
courses.description: The basic reactions of organometallic chemistry and their applications in homogeneous catalysis.

courses.name: Advanced Organic Synthesis - Concepts and Applications
courses.description: Synthesis of natural products and other medicinally relevant organic compounds. Retrosynthetic analysis, substructure keying, and pattern recognition. Classic and modern organic reactions. Terpenes, alkaloids, polyketides, steroids, proteins, and pharmaceuticals.

courses.name: X-Ray Crystallography
courses.description: This class focuses on structure determination by X-Ray Crystallography. The course includes lectures on crystallographic theory and practice as well as hands-on experience with instrumentation and structure determination software.

courses.name: Structural Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Chemical applications of group theory and the determination of molecular structure by modern physical techniques.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Inorganic and solid-state chemistry of main group elements, particularly those in Group III, second and third transition elements, lanthanides, and actinides.

courses.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Topics vary. Recent topics include organometallic chemistry, coordination chemistry, hydride chemistry, ligand field theory, solid-state chemistry, and photoelectron spectroscopy of inorganic compounds.

courses.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Topics vary. Recent topics include organometallic chemistry, coordination chemistry, hydride chemistry, ligand field theory, solid-state chemistry, and photoelectron spectroscopy of inorganic compounds.

courses.name: Quantum Chemistry
courses.description: First Quarter: Principles of basic quantum mechanics, approximation methods, applications to molecules, and introductory group theory. Second Quarter: Molecular orbital theory, applications of group theory, and quantum mechanics as applied to spectroscopy.

courses.name: Quantum Chemistry
courses.description: First Quarter: Principles of basic quantum mechanics, approximation methods, applications to molecules, and introductory group theory. Second Quarter: Molecular orbital theory, applications of group theory, and quantum mechanics as applied to spectroscopy.

courses.name: Kinetics and Spectroscopy
courses.description: The first part of the course focuses on a practical approach to chemical kinetics and dynamics (basic rate laws, rate laws for complex reactions, temperature dependence of reaction rates and their chemical applications). The second part focuses on spectroscopic methods in solving chemical kinetics and dynamics problems, with fundamental concepts on the interaction of light and matter, the core process in various spectroscopic methods.

courses.name: Elementary Statistical Mechanics
courses.description: Statistical mechanics in chemical systems. Partition functions, thermodynamic correspondence, absolute rate theory, equilibrium, vibration behavior of solids, and adsorption theory.

courses.name: Advanced Physical & Analytical Chemistry
courses.description: Topics vary. Recent topics include electrochemistry, molecular beam kinetics, electron spectroscopy, molecular reaction dynamics, laser spectroscopy, separations, and resonance spectroscopy.

courses.name: Computational Chemistry
courses.description: The theory and application of molecular electronic structure methods, techniques for determining vibrational eigenfunctions and scattering properties, and molecular mechanics, molecular mechanics and Monte Carlo calculations. Included are extensive applications to chemical problems using Unix workstations.

courses.name: Seminar in Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Current research topics presented by visiting and Northwestern University speakers.

courses.name: Seminar in Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Current research topics presented by visiting and Northwestern University speakers.

courses.name: Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Current research topics presented by visiting and Northwestern University speakers.

courses.name: Organic Chemistry Independent Study
courses.description: Advanced work for students through supervised reading, research, and discussion.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: May be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Chemistry Colloquium
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Biological Chemistry
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Chemical Physics & Theoretical Chemistry
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Organometallic & Coordination Chemistry
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Physical Organic Chm
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Solid State Chem
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research Seminar in Synthetic Organic
courses.description: N/A

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit

courses.name: Analysis of Field Experience
courses.description: Online course for students who intern 10 to 40 hours a week in firms and organizations throughout the world. Requires students to read, reflect upon and discuss the structure and purpose of organizations as well as workplace inclusion, teamwork, productivity, and leadership styles. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying.

courses.name: Field Studies in Environment, Science, and Sustainability
courses.description: Explores theoretical, geographic, and historical stakes of environmental thought and practice with emphasis on Chicago-based environmental work. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Field Studies in Business Culture
courses.description: Online course for students who intern 10 to 40 hours a week in firms and organizations throughout the world.  Course focus on critical issues shaping business culture, especially pertaining to interns and internships. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying.

courses.name: Field Studies in Social Justice
courses.description: Approaches to social change with focus on particular justice issues and current events. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in advocacy, policy, and social justice organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Field Studies in Public Health
courses.description: Explores foundational concepts and current issues in global and local Public Health, with emphasis on promoting health equity. Students earn 10 to 40 hours a week in health- and medicine-related organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Field Studies in the Modern Workplace
courses.description: Workplace culture and political theory of labor. Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in a variety of professional fields. 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Legal Field Studies
courses.description: Contemporary issues and workplace culture in the legal field.  Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in legal organizations. 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Business Field Studies
courses.description: Contemporary issues and workplace culture in business. Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in business organizations (primarily finance, consulting, and marketing). 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Field Studies in Civic Engagement
courses.description: Forms of civic engagement with emphasis on local issues and approaches. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in civic, educational, legal, governmental, nonprofit, or community-based organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Field Studies in Humanities
courses.description: Labor issues through arts and cultural history, with emphasis on humanities, arts, and media in the public sphere. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in fields including but not limited to arts and cultural organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

courses.name: Civic Engagement and Graduate Education
courses.description: This seminar examines topics including theories of citizenship, the scope of civic action and public work, the nature of public scholarship, and the role of public intellectuals in civic life. Students will undertake an internship or field study in a community organization, educational setting, or non-profit.

courses.name: Chinese I
courses.description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

courses.name: Chinese I
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese I
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-2 or equivalent

courses.description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

courses.name: Chinese I
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

courses.description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese I - Accelerated
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: First-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: First-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.

courses.name: Chinese II
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.

courses.name: Chinese II - Accelerated
courses.description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II - Accelerated
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese II - Accelerated
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III
courses.description: First-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese in Business Practice 1
courses.description: Basic business Chinese focused on professional settings. For students interested in using business-related texts to learn Chinese or aspiring to China-focused careers.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-2, CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III - Accelerated
courses.description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III - Accelerated
courses.description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese III - Accelerated
courses.description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-2 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese IV: Formal Speaking
courses.description: Development of skills in speaking formal Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese IV: Formal Writing
courses.description: Development of skills in writing formal Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese IV: Formal Reading
courses.description: Development of skills in reading different types of authentic Chinese works.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese in Business Practice 2
courses.description: Training for professional tasks using Chinese. Especially for students who completed CHINESE 212-0 or aspire to China-focused careers or to becoming multi-proficient business professionals.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3, CHINESE 211-3, CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent

courses.name: Multinational Corporations in China
courses.description: Training in business reading skills, with a focus on case studies, and speaking/writing skills for discussing business topics professionally. Designed for students interested in China's economic development and using Chinese in their careers.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3, CHINESE 211-3, CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent

courses.name: Chinese IV - Accelerated: Formal Writing and Public Speaking
courses.description: Development of academic writing and speaking in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

courses.name: Chinese IV - Accelerated: Advanced Reading and Writing
courses.description: Development of academic reading and writing in Chinese.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

courses.name: Chinese IV  - Accelerated: Media & Society
courses.description: Development of skills in reading primary sociocultural sources.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

courses.name: Chinese V: Special Topics in Advanced Chinese
courses.description: Standalone topics course using films, audiovisual materials, and texts in primary sources to develop ability to analyze diverse textual logic, language patterns, and cultural features. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in three of CHINESE 315-1, CHINESE 315-2, CHINESE 315-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Chinese.

courses.name: Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.description: In this seminar course we discuss the grand challenges facing society in the coming decades, and how Civil and Environmental Engineers are meeting these challenges.  Seminars will focus on key CE and EE topics, the CE & EE curricula at NU, and the career paths of recent CE & EE graduates.

courses.name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Seminar
courses.description: Introductory-level special topic seminar intended for first and second-year students.

courses.name: Introductory Course in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.description: Introductory-level special topics courses in civil and environmental engineering. 195 is similar to CIV_ENV 395-0 but intended for first and second-year students.

courses.name: Engineering Possibilities: Decision Science in the Age of Smart Technologies
courses.description: Define challenges facing cities, and learn how to critically evaluate different solutions, ranging from traditional to innovative. Fostercritical thinking about problem definitions along with the definition of metrics that represent desirable (and undesirable) outcomes in urban systems.

courses.name: Biological and Ecological Principles
courses.description: Fundamentals of biology - including cell biology, genetics, and biochemistry - and ecology - including biological interactions, microbial ecology - and biogeochemical cycling as they apply to natural and engineered systems. Bioinformatics tools necessary for analyzing biological and ecological data.

courses.name: Earth in the Anthropocene
courses.description: Fundamentals of Earth system science and their connections to the need for humansto develop food, water, energy and infrastructure systems that has led to transformation of the Earth's surface and of its atmosphere.
courses.prereqs: MATH 220-2;  CHEM 131-0, CHEM 151-0, or CHEM 171-0 is highly recommended

courses.name: Economics and Finance for Engineers
courses.description: Principles of corporate finance; financial decisions of firms; value; risk and return; investment and capital budgeting decisions under certainty and uncertainty; performance evaluation. May not be taken for credit with or after KELLG_FE 310-0.
courses.prereqs: MATH 220-1; basic understanding of probability and economics recommended

courses.name: Mechanics of Materials I
courses.description: Analytical and experimental study of stresses and deformations and their application to the design of machine and structural elements subjected to static, dynamic, and repeated loads.

courses.name: Structural Art
courses.description: Learn how to interpret and understand the built environment through an examination of the history of structural engineering as a creative art, with particular emphasis on technical, visual, and social analysis and critique of bridges, buildings, and designers.

courses.name: Theory of Structures I
courses.description: Deflections of structures, energy concepts, idealization of structures, truss analysis, column stability, and influence lines. Introduction to indeterminate truss and frame analyses, slope-deflection analysis, and moment distribution. Portal method.

courses.name: Earth Surface Engineering
courses.description: Fundamental properties and behavior of soils as engineering materials. Origin of soils through the properties of soil components to the strength, permeability, and deformation of soil masses.

courses.name: Environmental Systems and Processes
courses.description: Basic engineering principles required for the design, operation, analysis, and modeling of both natural and engineered systems and their application to major issues facing human and environmental health of ecosystems. Corequisite: MATH 220-2; CHEM 131-0, CHEM 151-0, or CHEM 171-0 highly recommended.

courses.name: Introductory topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.description: Intermediate-level study of topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

courses.name: Professional Development Seminar I
courses.description: Case study in engineering ethics, with discussion of topics in professional development and lifelong learning.

courses.name: Professional Development Seminar II
courses.description: Preparation for the Fundamentals of Engineering (FE) exam.

courses.name: Engineering Law
courses.description: The American legal system from an engineer's perspective. Socratic-method analysis of statutory and case law. Contract, patent, corporation, antitrust, property, and environmental law. Torts, product liability, and arbitration.

courses.name: Environmental Law and Policy
courses.description: An introduction to important aspects of environmental law and policy. Covers a wide range of environmental topics, with a focus on major federal environmental statutes.

courses.name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Systems Analysis
courses.description: Quantitative techniques to develop descriptive and prescriptive models that support efficient planning and management of civil and environmental engineering systems.

courses.name: Uncertainty Analysis
courses.description: Probability, statistics, and decision theory. Discrete and continuous random variables, marginal and conditional distributions, moments, statistical model selection and significance tests, hypothesis testing, and elementary Bayesian decision theory. Application to problems in soil mechanics, water resources, transportation, and structures.

courses.name: Organic Geochemistry
courses.description: The sources and fates of organic matter in the natural environment; global cycling of organic carbon; applications to the study of modern and ancient environments. Taught with EARTH 314-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
courses.prereqs: 1 course in earth and planetary sciences or environmental sciences; 1 course in chemistry

courses.name: Biogeochemistry
courses.description: Cycling of biogenic elements (C, N, S, Fe, Mn) in surficial environments. Emphasis on microbial processes and isotopic signatures.
courses.prereqs: 1 quarter of chemistry; 1 quarter of geoscience, environmental sciences, or biological sciences

courses.name: Mechanics of Fracture
courses.description: Stress concentration, analysis of the stress field near a crack tip, fracture modes, brittle and ductile fracture, fracture toughness, fracture criteria, fracture mechanics design, fatigue, and dynamic effects.

courses.name: Theory of Structures 2
courses.description: Shear center, non-prismatic members, nonlinear materials, influence lines, Mueller-Breslau principle, approximate methods of analysis, energy methods, stiffness matrix, and computer methods of analysis.

courses.name: Structural Analysis--Dynamics
courses.description: Single and multiple degree-of-freedom systems subjected to periodic, seismic, and general loadings. Time-history analysis of linear and nonlinear systems. Design methods for earthquakes.

courses.name: Concrete Properties
courses.description: Concrete as a composite material; relationship between constitutive laws and microstructure; failure theories; fracture; fatigue; strain rate effects; destructive and nondestructive testing; creep and shrinkage; chemistry of cement hydration; admixtures; aggregates; proportioning; new materials.

courses.name: Structural Design
courses.description: Design criteria; planning and design aspects of structural systems for gravity and lateral loads. A total design project involving the analysis and design of a structure.

courses.name: Structural Steel Design
courses.description: Rational basis of structural design. Design approach for structural-steel components of a building system.

courses.name: Reinforced Concrete
courses.description: Fundamentals of reinforced concrete theory and design. Analysis and design of beams, slabs, and columns. Concurrent familiarization with current building codes, specifications, and practices.

courses.name: Engineering Forensics
courses.description: Introduction to failure analysis and forensic engineering to describe how these investigative procedures contribute to regulations, engineering design, safety principles, and the economic aspects of structure engineering.

courses.name: Finite Element Methods in Mechanics
courses.description: Development of finite elements from variational principles and application to static stress analysis. Introduction to techniques for transient and generalized field problems. Computer implementation of finite element techniques. Taught with MECH_ENG 327-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Computational Forensics and Failure Analysis
courses.description: The course will cover the use of the scientific method for accident investigation, hypothesis development, and the use of the finite element method to analyze the root cause of a failure. Practical application problems for both civil and mechanical structures will be analyzed using commercial finite element codes (Abaqus, Hypermesh, LS-Dyna)Prerequiste: CIV_ENV 327-0 or MECH_ENG 327-0

courses.name: Engineering Project Management
courses.description: Techniques for coordinating decisions and actions of various parties in the design and construction of civil and environmental engineering projects. Delivery systems; preconstruction services; project planning; cost control and value engineering; bidding.

courses.name: Building Construction Estimating
courses.description: Estimation of cost at different stages of design; conceptual estimating and quantity takeoff of various elements, such as materials, labor, and equipment.

courses.name: Project Scheduling
courses.description: Project planning, scheduling, and control using CPM arrow and precedence networks; resource allocation and resource leveling; earned value analysis; linear scheduling; PERT, CPM in dispute resolution and litigation, computer scheduling.

courses.name: Hydraulics and Hydrology
courses.description: Civil and environmental engineering applications of fluid mechanics. Turbulent flow in pipes and rivers, pipe and river networks, and open channels.

courses.name: Ecohydrology
courses.description: Interactions between water and ecosystems in freshwater, terrestrial, and urban environments. Feedbacks between ecological and hydrological processes. Engineering of ecosystems such as constructed wetlands, green roofs, and other green infrastructure for resilient and sustainable water management.

courses.name: Environmental Management
courses.description: The roles and responsibilities of project managers who deal with environmental issues. How managers deal with previously created environmental problems, respond to current requirements, and anticipate future needs.
courses.prereqs: a technical background and senior standing

courses.name: Foundation Engineering
courses.description: Application of soil mechanics to analysis and design of foundations and embankments. Settlement of structures, bearing capacities of shallow and deep foundations, earth pressures on retaining structures, and slope stability.

courses.name: Energy Geostructures & Geosystems
courses.description: This course focuses on energy geostructures and geosystems: novel earth-contact technologies that provide renewable energy supply and structural support to any built environment. The course comprises theoretical and practical sessions. The theoretical sessions expand on the analysis and design of such technologies from energy, geotechnical and structural perspectives. The practical sessions simulate an actual design project of energy geostructures.

courses.name: Hydrogeology and Subsurface Contamination
courses.description: The integration of principles of geology, physics, chemistry, and mathematics required for understanding groundwater flow and how to perform aquifer tests, the fate and remediation of contaminants in the subsurface, and to develop numerical models for simulating these processes.

courses.name: Transport Processes in Porous Media
courses.description: Transport processes in porous media including unsaturated flow, flow in deformable porous media, convective transport of solutes with hydrodynamic dispersion effects, and coupled flow phenomena with particular emphasis on electrokinetics.

courses.name: Airphoto Interpretation
