courses.name: Electrons, Photons, and Bits:  Adventures in Electrical and Computer Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to contemporary topics in electrical engineering (5 weeks) and computer engineering (5 weeks) via lectures, demonstrations, and lab tours. No exams, but two in-depth term papers are required: the first on an electrical engineering topic reviewed during the first half of the course, and the second on a computer engineering topic reviewed during the second half of the course.

courses.name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts and applications of electrical engineering. Topics include: circuit analysis from dc resistive networks to networks of impedances operating in the sinusoidal steady-state; circuit simplification and the Thevenin equivalent circuit; complex numbers and phasors; series and parallel inductor-capacitor resonance; simple analog filters; power transfer and impedance matching; op amps realizing active filters; signal spectra and the Fourier transform; signal sampling and aliasing; bandwidth and channel capacity; simple feedback and control systems; semiconductor electronics and devices including diodes, transistors, light-emitting diodes, and lasers.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Circuits
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in electrical circuits; circuit analysis and network theorems; linearity and superposition; series/parallel combinations of R, L, and C circuits; sinusoidal forcing; complex frequency and Bode plots; mutual inductance and transformers; two port networks.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Signals & Systems
courses.description: Comprehensive introduction to analysis of continuous and discrete-time signals and systems. Linear time-invariant systems, convolution. Fourier series representations of periodic signals. Continuous and discrete-time Fourier transforms. Laplace transform; z-transform.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Solid State Engineering
courses.description: Crystalline state of matter; quantum phenomena and quantum mechanics; electrons in atoms, atoms in crystals, electrons in crystals; semiconductors; thermal properties of crystals, electrical properties of crystals and semiconductors; pn junction.

courses.name: Fund of Electromagnetics & Photonics
courses.description: Introduction to electromagnetic waves in electrical engineering. Topics include: analysis of transmission lines in the time domain and the sinusoidal steady-state; fundamentals of electrostatics and magnetostatics; Maxwell's equations for time-varying electromagnetic fields; plane electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection, and transmission at material interfaces; Poynting's theorem; introduction to fiber optics and photonics.
courses.prereqs: (ELEC_ENG 202-0 and ELEC_ENG 221-0 and PHYSICS 135-2 and MATH 228-2) or consent of instructor

courses.name: Fundamentals of Electronics
courses.description: Diode, BJT, and FET circuits; design using ideal operational amplifiers; feedback; frequency response; biasing; current sources and mirrors; small-signal analysis; design of operational amplifiers.

courses.name: Physical Electronics and Devices
courses.description: The physical basis of electronic and optoelectronic devices and their application in analog and digital systems. Diodes, transistors, LEDs, photodetectors, and lasers are described, and their properties explored.

courses.name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Probabilistic Systems
courses.description: Introduction to probability theory and its applications. Axioms of probability, distributions, discrete and continuous random variables, conditional and joint distributions, correlation, limit laws, connection to statistics, and applications in engineering systems. May not receive credit for both ELEC_ENG 302-0 and any of the following: IEMS 202-0; MATH 310-1; STAT 320-1; ELEC_ENG 383-0, ELEC_ENG 385-0. Corequisite: MATH 228-2 or equivalent.

courses.name: Communications Systems
courses.description: Analysis of analog and digital communications systems, including modulation, transmission, and demodulation of AM, FM, and TV systems. Design issues, channel distortion and loss, bandwidth limitations, additive noise.

courses.name: Applied Electromagnetics and Photonics
courses.description: Electromagnetic wave behavior and design of metallic, dielectric, and optical waveguides and antennas and antenna arrays.  Electromagnetic wave fundamentals of wireless communications systems and radar techniques.

courses.name: Electronic System Design I
courses.description: This fast-paced course teaches students how to go from a project idea to a fully functional prototype implementation. This involves a printed circuit board design using PCB CAD software, surface mount soldering, MCU programming, CAD design for 3D printing, and web design.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 221-0 and ELEC_ENG 225-0 and COMP_SCI 211-0, or graduate standing, or instructor consent

courses.name: Electronic System Design II: Project
courses.description: This course puts to practice the knowledge gained in Electronic System Design I, and have students create a fully functional prototype implementation. This involves the same principles as in Electronic System Design I, but more independently, and with some design optimization.  The course will also focus on team management and presentation skills, culminating in a project fair to the public.  For a student with senior standing, this course can count towards the Design Degree Requirement in EE.

courses.name: Information Theory & Learning
courses.description: This course gives students analytical tools to quantify information, perform inference, and study the relationship of information and learning. The course covers information measures, the source and the channel coding theorems, statistical inference, and learning with neural networks. In particular, the course explores a common set of models and tools used by both machine learning and state-of-the-art data compression and error-control codes. This course is aimed at undergraduate students in engineering, science, mathematics, and computing. It expects familiarity with undergraduate-level calculus, probability theory, and linear algebra.

courses.name: Introduction to Computational Photography
courses.description: Fundamentals of digital imaging and modern camera architectures. Hands-on experience acquiring, characterizing, and manipulating data captured using a modern camera platform.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer Vision
courses.description: Computer and biological vision systems, image formation, edge detection, image segmentation, texture, representation and analysis of two-dimensional geometric structures and of three-dimensional structures.
courses.prereqs: COMP_SCI 212-0 or ELEC_ENG 302-0 or equivalent or graduate standing

courses.name: Introduction to Communication Networks
courses.description: Data communication basics. Telephone, cellular, cable, and computer networks. Layered network architectures, models, and protocols. Switching, routing, flow control, and congestion control. Medium access control, ARQ, and local area networks. Queuing models and network performance analysis.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Blockchains and Decentralization
courses.description: This course is partly an introduction to the fundamentals of blockchains and decentralized applications and partly a springboard toward deeper understanding and further exploration. The course explains how blockchains work; teaches the underlying fundamentals of distributed consensus; provides hands-on experience through computer assignments; and also touches upon economic and policy issues.
courses.prereqs: COMP_SCI 212-0 or ELEC_ENG 302-0 or equivalent or graduate standing and basic programming skills

courses.name: Deep Learning Foundations from Scratch
courses.description: The course covers the fundamentals of deep learning and numerical optimization, with many application examples.

courses.name: Digital Microelectronics
courses.description: Logic families, comparators, A/D and D/A converters, combinational systems, sequential systems, solid-state memory, largescale integrated circuits, and design of electronic systems.

courses.name: Digital Signal Processing
courses.description: Discrete-time signals and systems. Discrete-time Fourier transform, z-transform, discrete Fourier transform, digital filters.

courses.name: Introduction to Feedback Systems
courses.description: Linear feedback control systems, their physical behavior, dynamical analysis, and stability. Laplace transform, frequency spectrum, and root locus methods. System design and compensation using PID and lead-lag controllers. Digital implementations of analog controllers.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 222-0 or MECH_ENG 390-0 or BMD_ENG 309-0 or equivalent

courses.name: Digital Filtering
courses.description: Recursive and nonrecursive digital filters, decimation and interpolation, A/D and D/A conversion as digital filtering problems. Implementation of nonrecursive filters via FFT, quantization problems (e.g., companding and limit cycles).

courses.name: Robot Design Studio
courses.description: In this course, teams of students will design and build robots. For instance, teams may build robots inspired by the Summer Olympics: a robot that can perform on the uneven bars, that can skate a half-pipe, or or that can do flips on a BMX bike. The ultimate goal is to build a robust, elegant machine capable of performing exciting dynamic feats. Along the way, students will refine skills in mechatronics, electromechanical design, real-time programming, sensor selection and integration, motor/transmission design, and feedback control.

courses.name: Robot Design Studio
courses.description: In this course, teams of students will design and build robots.  For instance, teams may build robots inspired by the Summer Olympics:  a robot that can perform on the uneven bars, that can skate a half-pipe, or that can do flips on a BMX bike.  The ultimate goal is to build a robust, elegant machine capable of performing exciting dynamic feats.  Along the way, students will refine skills in mechatronics, electromechanical design, real-time programming, sensor selection and integration, motor/transmission design, and feedback control.

courses.name: Deep Reinforcement Learning
courses.description: Fundamentals of Deep Reinforcement Learning starting from its roots in dynamic programming and optimal control, and ending with some of the most popular applications in practice today; basic Q-Learning algorithm and its extensions; deep Q-Learning. Through exercises and a final course project students will gain significant hands-on experience coding up and testing reinforcement systems on a variety of interesting problems.

courses.name: Introduction to Digital Control
courses.description: Discrete dynamics systems; discrete models of continuous systems feedback and digital controllers; analog-digital conversion; digital control design including PID, lead/lag, deadbeat, and mode-lmatching controllers.

courses.name: Machine Learning: Foundations, Applications, and Algorithms
courses.description: The course covers the fundamentals of machine learning and numerical optimization, with many application examples.

courses.name: Digital Communications
courses.description: Sampling and time-division multiplexing, baseband digital signals and systems. Coded pulse modulation, error control coding, digital modulation systems, information measure and source encoding, and introduction to spread spectrum communications.

courses.name: Lasers and Coherent Optics
courses.description: Optical resonators; fundamental operation of lasers; mode-locking and Q-switching; optical propagation and diffraction; Gaussian beams; thin-lens imaging; optical signal processing.

courses.name: Wireless Communications
courses.description: Overview of existing and emerging wireless communications systems; interference, blocking, and spectral efficiency; radio propagation and fading models; performance of digital modulation in the presence of fading; diversity techniques; code-division multiple access.

courses.name: Electronic Properties of Materials
courses.description: Fundamental properties of electrons in materials. Classical and quantum mechanical descriptions of free and bound electrons. Optical, electrical, thermal, and magnetic properties of materials. Microelectronic, optoelectronic, magnetic recording, superconductivity.

courses.name: Photonic Information Processing
courses.description: Introduction to photonic information processing; coherent and incoherent light; electro-optic and acousto-optic modulation; optical signal processing; holography; optical storage.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 222-0 and ELEC_ENG 224-0 or consent of instructor

courses.name: Fiber-Optic Communications
courses.description: Semiconductor diode lasers, internal modulation, electro-optic modulation, coherent and incoherent detection, optical fibers and their properties, optical amplifiers, communication systems, optical networks.

courses.name: Solid State Electronic Devices
courses.description: Energy-band model for semiconductors; carrier statistics and transport; diodes, bipolar and field-effect transistors; integrated circuits, optoelectronic and heterojunction devices.

courses.name: Optoelectronics
courses.description: Introduction to solid-state optoelectronic devices; display devices, laser diodes, photodetectors, and light modulators; optical waveguides and fibers; system application of optoelectronic devices.

courses.name: Nanotechnology
courses.description: Physics and fabrication of photonic and electronic devices. Physics of semiconductors: crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, elements of quantum mechanics, heterojunctions, quantum wells, and super-lattices. Bulk crystal, thin-film, and epitaxial growth technologies. Device processing technologies: diffusion oxidation, ion implantation, annealing, etching, and photolithography.

courses.name: Superconductivity and Its Applications
courses.description: Properties of materials in the superconducting state; charge flow dynamics of type II superconductors; highTc superconductors; applications for computers and high-frequency devices.

courses.name: Introduction to Robotics
courses.description: Homogeneous vectors and planes; homogeneous transformation, position and orientation transformations, kinematics and inverse kinematic solutions of robot manipulators; Jacobian and inverse Jacobian relation; robot trajectory and task planning; dynamic formulation and computation of robot manipulators; robot programming and control systems.

courses.name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Electrical Engineering Design
courses.description: Design of electrical and electronic devices, circuits, and systems by the application of the engineering sciences, economics, and Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers or other national standards.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Seminar and projects for advanced undergraduates on subjects of current interest in electrical and computer engineering.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Electronic Devices
courses.description: Transport phenomena in semiconductors, theory of the p-n junction, biopolar and unipolar devices, general analysis of the metal-semiconductor and MIS structures, CCD, and MOSFET and biopolar transistors.

courses.name: Advanced Electronic Devices
courses.description: Semiconductor optics, heterojunctions, quantum wells, superlattices, and resonant funneling. Field-effect and potential-effect devices. Hot-electron devices. Microwave devices.

courses.name: Quantum Semiconductors
courses.description: Elements of wave mechanics necessary to explain band theory. Fermi-Dirac statistics, introduction to the theory of electrical conductivity in semiconductors, optical and thermal properties, diffusion of electrons, and holes in solids.

courses.name: Quantum Electronics
courses.description: Review of quantum mechanics. Harmonic oscillator. Perturbation theory. Phonons and photons. Interaction of radiation and atomic systems. Einstein coefficients. Laser oscillation. Laser photon statistics.

courses.name: Advanced Photonics
courses.description: Physical description of compound semiconductors; optical properties of heterostructures, quantum wells, superlattices, quantum wires and quantum dots; physics and technology of optoelectronic devices; light emitting diodes (LEDs) and lasers.

courses.name: Nonlinear Optics
courses.description: Nonlinear optical susceptibilities; wave propagation and coupling in nonlinear media; harmonic, sum, and difference frequency generation; parametric amplification and oscillation; phase-conjugation via four-wave mixing; self-phase modulation and solitons.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 382-0 and ELEC_ENG 404-0 or permission of instructor

courses.name: Quantum Optics
courses.description: Review of quantum fields; quantization of the electromagnetic field; photodetection theory; direct, homodyne, and heterodyne detection; squeezed and photon-number state generation; application to optical communication and interferometers.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 404-0 and ELEC_ENG 406-0 or permission of instructor

courses.name: Classical Electodynamics
courses.description: Introduction to classical analytical techniques for static and dynamic electromagnetic fields. Static electric field and scalar potential; multipole expansions of the scalar potential; magnetostatics and the vector potential; time-varying fields; Maxwell's equations; Coulomb and Lorentz gauge; Green's functions for the wave equation; use of the causal Green's function for electromagnetic radiation; multipole expansions of the radiating field; application to simple antennas.

courses.name: Computational Electrodynamics
courses.description: Advanced topics in the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method for numerical modeling of electromagnetic wave interactions with engineering structures. Reduced-numerical-dispersion algorithms employing fourth-order spatial differencing; uniaxial perfectly matched layer absorbing boundary conditions; generalized grids; incorporation of lumped-circuit elements.

courses.name: Semiconductor Lasers
courses.description: Basic concepts of lasers; laser applications; gas and liquid lasers; solid-state lasers; semiconductor lasers; materials and devices; rate equations; laser gain and saturation; modulation and light pulse generation; advanced technology for semiconductor laser fabrication and integration; industrial and medical applications of laser diodes.

courses.name: System Theory
courses.description: Unified treatment of continuous and discrete time systems from a state-variable viewpoint; emphasis on linear systems. Concept of state, writing and solving state equations, controllability and observability, transform techniques (Fourier, Laplace, Z), stability, and Lyapunov's method.

courses.name: Fundamentals and Applications of Special Relativity
courses.description: This course will introduce students to Special Relativity (SR), illustrate the relation between SR and Maxwell's Equations, and explain the origin of magnetic fields and forces.  In addition, it will describe quantitatively the role of SR in modern optical devices and systems such as Sagnac interferometers, gyroscopes, free electron lasers, clocks and the global positioning system.  The origin of electron spin and the Pauli exclusion principle based on SR will also be discussed.

courses.name: Managing People and Workforce Diversity in Energy & Sustainability
courses.description: This course is built off of a highly successful Kellogg course: Leading & Managing Diverse Organizations. The aim is to develop the cross‐cultural competence you need to lead effectively in the modern collaboration‐powered global marketplace - one that is more diverse than ever before on multiple dimensions. This course is designed to provide i) evidence‐based insights on how to lead ii) individual, interpersonal, enterprise‐level strategies to successfully optimize the value of diversity and inclusion in teams and organizations iii) industry specific perspectives for teams in energy & sustainability and guidelines on how to navigate challenges and opportunities specific to these markets.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Quantum Electronics
courses.description: Study of advanced topics of current interest in the field of quantum electronics, with an emphasis on atom-laser interaction.  Selected topics from the following areas will be covered, with an emphasis on practical applications:  Review of Atomic Transitions, Semi-Classical Atom-Laser Interaction, Quantized Radiation Field, Cavity Quantum Electrodynamics, Fundamental Formalisms in Quantum Noise, Quantum Theory of Spontaneous Emission, and Quantum Theory of Laser.

courses.name: Advanced Digital Signal Processing
courses.description: Selected topics in digital signal processing such as digital speech processing, multidimensional digital signal processing, spectrum estimation, and error analysis.

courses.name: Digital Image Processing
courses.description: Fundamentals of image processing. Image compression, enhancement, and restoration. Image reconstruction from projections and partial information.

courses.name: Multimedia Signal Processing
courses.description: Fundamentals of applying digital signal processing to speech signals. Topics include models of speech production and hearing and analysis/synthesis methods and applications.

courses.name: Random Processes in Communications and Control 1
courses.description: Fundamentals of random variables; mean-squared estimation; limit theorems and convergence; definition of random processes; autocorrelation and stationarity; Gaussian and Poisson processes; Markov chains.

courses.name: Random Processes in Communications and Control 2
courses.description: Advanced topics in random processes: point processes, Wiener processes; Markov processes, spectral representation, series expansion of random processes, linear filtering, Wiener and Kalman filters, optimum receivers, and matched filters.

courses.name: Distributed Optimization
courses.description: This course studies various models and algorithms in the distributed and parallel settings. Topics include graph theory, algorithms for solving linear equations, iterative methods for convex problems, synchronous and asynchronous setups, consensus algorithms and rate analysis.

courses.name: Introduction to Nanoscale Lasers, Quantum Noise, Photons, and Measurement
courses.description: Introduction to semiclassical theory of lasers leading to coherent, noise, and modulation properties of lasers, with emphasis on semiconductor lasers. Includes topics on noise in optical amplifiers and effects of optical feedback on lasers. Quantum theory of lasers is introduced, leading to topics on quantum states of laser light.

courses.name: Signal Detection and Estimation
courses.description: Simple-hypothesis detection problems, detection of signals with unknown parameters, Bays' maximum likelihood estimation, estimation of signal parameters, detection of stochastic signals, nonparametric detection and estimation.

courses.name: Optical Communications
courses.description: Optical communication systems, optical wave propagation, photodetection statistics, heterodyne receiver, and noise sources. Evaluation of communication performance for the free-space channel. Introduction to fiber optic communication and fiber optic networks.

courses.name: Information Theory and Learning
courses.description: This course gives students analytical tools to quantify information, perform inference, and study the relationship of information and learning. The course covers information measures, the source and the channel coding theorems, statistical inference, and learning with neural networks. In particular, the course explores a common set of models and tools used by both machine learning and state-of-the-art data compression and error-control codes. This course is aimed at students in engineering, science, mathematics, and computing. It expects familiarity with undergraduate-level calculus, probability theory, and linear algebra.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Quantum Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Basic general principles of quantum mechanics for applications to quantum information science andtechnology. The fundamentals will be covered, together with topics of current interest among the areas of quantum teleportation, quantum computation,and quantum cryptography.
courses.prereqs: Knowledge of quantum mechanics and permission of instructor

courses.name: Human Perception and Electronic Media
courses.description: Fundamentals of visual, acoustic, and tactile perception; display devices; perceptual models for image, video, acoustic, and tactile signal analysis, compression, quality evaluation, and understanding; multimodal signal processing and perception; content-based retrieval; sense substitution.

courses.name: Statistical Pattern Recognition
courses.description: Fundamental and advanced topics in statistical pattern recognition including Bayesian decision theory, Maximum-likelihood and Bayesian estimation, Nonparametric density estimation, Component Analysis and Discriminants, Kernel machines, Feature selection, dimension reduction and embedding, Boosting, Minimum description length, Mixture models and clustering, Spectral clustering, Bayesian network and Hidden Markov models, with the applications to image and video pattern recognition.

courses.name: Deep Learning: Foundations, Applications, and Algorithms
courses.description: The course covers the fundamentals of deep learning and numerical optimization, with many application examples.

courses.name: Advanced Communication Networks
courses.description: Basic techniques for modeling and analyzing data communication networks. Protocol specification and correctness, queuing models, loss networks, multi-class queues and scheduling, graph-based and flow-based routing, congestion control and pricing.
courses.prereqs: ELEC_ENG 302-0; ELEC_ENG 333-0 helpful but not required

courses.name: Adaptive Filters
courses.description: Applications of adaptive filtering, autoregressive and moving average processes, linear prediction, Wiener filter, Least Mean Square (LMS) algorithm,  lattice filter, least squares filtering, Kalman filter, convergence analysis.

courses.name: Deep Reinforcement Learning
courses.description: Fundamentals of Deep Reinforcement Learning starting from its roots in dynamic programming and optimal control, and ending with some of the most popular applications in practice today; basic Q-Learning algorithm and its extensions; deep Q-Learning. Through exercises and a final course project students will gain significant hands-on experience coding up and testing reinforcement systems on a variety of interesting problems.

courses.name: Machine Learning: Foundations, Applications, and Algorithms
courses.description: The course covers the fundamentals of machine learning and numerical optimization, with many application examples.

courses.name: Advanced Digital Communications
courses.description: Digital modulation, complex base band signaling, sequence estimation, the Viterbi algorithm, probability of error analysis, equalization, and code-division multiple access.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Special projects carried out under faculty direction. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.description: Seminar on topics of current interest.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Honors Calculus for Engineers
courses.description: Alternative to standard calculus sequence. Covers more material at a deeper level with more applications. Satisfies same requirements as MATH 228-1 and MATH 228-2.

courses.name: Honors Calculus for Engineers
courses.description: Alternative to standard calculus sequence. Covers more material at a deeper level with more applications. Satisfies same requirements as MATH 228-1 and MATH 228-2.

courses.name: Methods of Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Ordinary differential equations: Sturm-Liouville theory, properties of special functions, solution methods including Laplace transforms, Fourier series, eigenvalue problems and expansions in orthogonal functions. Partial differential equations: classification, separation of variables, solution by series and transform methods.

courses.name: Methods of Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Ordinary differential equations; Sturm-Liouville theory, properties of special functions, solution methods including Laplace transforms. Fourier series: eigenvalue problems and expansions in orthogonal functions. Partial differential equations: classification, separation of variables, solution by series and transform methods.

courses.name: Complex Variables
courses.description: Imaginary numbers and complex variables, analytic functions, calculus of complex functions, contour integration with application to transform inversion, conformal mapping.

courses.name: Applied Dynamical Systems
courses.description: Example-oriented survey of nonlinear dynamical systems, including chaos. Combines numerical exploration of differential equations describing physical problems with analytic methods and geometric concepts. Applications to mechanical, fluid dynamical, electrical, chemical, and biological systems.
courses.prereqs: GEN_ENG 205-4, GEN_ENG 206-4, or MATH 250-0. ES_APPM 311-1 is recommended

courses.name: High Performance Scientific Computing
courses.description: Solving partial differential equations using high performance computing platforms. Basic C programming. Distributed computing using MPI. GPU programming using CUDA. Adaptation of algorithms for solving PDE's to different architectures.

courses.name: Applied Linear Algebra
courses.description: Understanding and implentation of algorithms to calculate matrix decompositions such as eigenvalue/vector, LU, QR, and SVD decompositions. Applications include data-fitting, image analysis, and ranking algorithms.

courses.name: Modeling and Computation in Science & Engineering
courses.description: Advanced techniques for initial value problems, differential algebraic systems, bifurcations, chaos, and partial differential equations. Applications drawn from different physical areas.
courses.prereqs: MATH 228-2, MATH 240-0, and MATH 250-0; or GEN_ENG 205-4 and PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2; or equivalent; familiarity with a programming language; or consent of instructor

courses.name: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience
courses.description: From neurons to networks. Ion channels, Hodgkin-Huxley framework, simplified models, cable equation, synapses, spike triggered average, and optimal stimulus. Feedforward and recurrent firing rate networks. Statistical approach, Bayesian modeling. Brief introduction to numerical methods.

courses.name: Quantitative Biology I: Experiments, Data, Models, and Analysis
courses.description: High-resolution, high-throughput, and dynamic imaging and sequencing data is the substrate of modern biology. The course consists of case-studies where we learn how to computational work with, analyze, and make sense of experimental dataset using fundamental principles of mathematics, statistics, and physics. No formal course prerequisites. Programming in python.

courses.name: Quantitative Biology II: Experiments, Data, Models, and Analysis
courses.description: High-resolution, high-throughput, and dynamic imaging and sequencing data is the substrate of modern biology. In this course we learn how to perform experiments, and computational work with, analyze, and make sense of experimental dataset using fundamental principles of mathematics, statistics, and physics. No formal course prerequisites. Programming in python.

courses.name: Introduction to Applied Math Research
courses.description: This is a seminar course where ESAM faculty present their current and planned research topics in applied mathematics.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Special studies to be carried out under faculty direction. Credit to be arranged.

courses.name: Options Pricing: Theory and Applications
courses.description: Consideration of ordinary and elementary partial differential equations models of problems in science and engineering, arising in various areas of application.

courses.name: Differential Equations of Mathematical Physics
courses.description: Methods for solving linear, ordinary, and partial differential equations of mathematical physics. Green's functions, distribution theory,integral equations, transforms, potential theory, diffusion equation, wave equation, maximum principles, and variational methods.

courses.name: Differential Equations of Mathematical Physics
courses.description: Methods for solving linear, ordinary, and partial differential equations of mathematical physics. Green's functions, distribution theory,integral equations, transforms, potential theory, diffusion equation, wave equation, maximum principles, and variational methods.

courses.name: Differential Equations of Mathematical Physics
courses.description: Methods for solving linear, ordinary, and partial differential equations of mathematical physics. Green's functions, distribution theory,integral equations, transforms, potential theory, diffusion equation, wave equation, maximum principles, and variational methods.

courses.name: Methods of Nonlinear Analysis
courses.description: Methods for analyzing nonlinear problems in science and engineering. Constructive approach to bifurcation theory and stability theory, dynamical response of nonlinear systems, nonlinear oscillations and phase plane analysis, nonlinear wave propagation, and perturbation methods. Applications.

courses.name: Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Asymptotic expansions of integrals. Regular and singular perturbation methods for ordinary and partial differential equations. Boundary layer theory. Matched asymptotic expansions. Homogenization. Two-time and uniform expansions. Wave propagation and WKBJ method. Turning point theory. Nonlinear oscillations. Bifurcation and stability theory.

courses.name: Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Asymptotic expansions of integrals. Regular and singular perturbation methods for ordinary and partial differential equations. Boundary layer theory. Matched asymptotic expansions. Homogenization. Two-time and uniform expansions. Wave propagation and WKBJ method. Turning point theory. Nonlinear oscillations. Bifurcation and stability theory.

courses.name: Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Asymptotic expansions of integrals. Regular and singular perturbation methods for ordinary and partial differential equations. Boundary layer theory. Matched asymptotic expansions. Homogenization. Two-time and uniform expansions. Wave propagation and WKBJ method. Turning point theory. Nonlinear oscillations. Bifurcation and stability theory.

courses.name: Models in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Applications to illustrate typical problems and methods of applied mathematics. Mathematical formulation of models for phenomena in science and engineering, problem solution, and interpretation of results. Examples from solid and fluid mechanics, combustion, diffusion phenomena, chemical and nuclear reactors, and biological processes.

courses.name: Theory of Flows With Small Inertia
courses.description: Asymptotic methods for flows with small inertia: flows past bodies and matching procedures. Slowly varying flows: lubrication theory and Hele-Shaw flow; swimming of microorganisms and suspension of particles.

courses.name: Hydrodynamic Stability Theory
courses.description: Mathematical theory of hydrodynamic states; energy methods, linear theories, and nonlinear bifurcation theories. Convective, centrifugal, and shear flow instabilities. Instability of unsteady flows and systems having interfaces. Physical mechanisms and results of experiments.

courses.name: Wave Propagation
courses.description: Problems of linear wave propagation; applications to acoustics, optics, electromagnetics, elasticity, and fluids. Radiation, transmission, scattering, diffraction, dispersion, layered media, wave-guides, coupled fluid solid waves, and inverse problems. Development and application of perturbation, asymptotic, numerical, and integral transform methods.

courses.name: Integral Equations & Applications
courses.description: Integral equations in various scientific theories and their relation to differential equations. Methods of solving linear problems with Hilbert-Schmidt, Cauchy, and Wiener-Hopf type kernels; applications. Nonlinear problems in bifurcation phenomena.

courses.name: Stochastic Differential Equations
courses.description: Brownian motion and Langevin's equation. Ito and Stratonovich stochastic integrals. Stochastic calculus and Ito's formula. SDEs and PDEs of Kolmogorov, Fokker-Planck, and Dynkin. Boundary conditions, exit times, exit distributions, stability. Asymptotic analysis of SDE, the Smoluchowski-Kramers approximation, and diffusion approximation to Markov chains. Applications.

courses.name: High Performance Scientific Computing
courses.description: Solving partial differential equations using high performance computing platforms. Basic C programming. Distributed computing using MPI. GPU programming using CUDA. Adaptation of algorithms for solving PDE's to different architectures.

courses.name: Iterative Methods for Elliptic Equations
courses.description: Analysis and application of numerical methods for solving elliptic equations. Stationary iterative, multigrid, conjugate gradient, GMRES methods and preconditioners.

courses.name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Numerical solution of partial differential equations by finite difference methods and spectral methods. Construction of algorithms, consistency, convergence, and stability of numerical methods. Matrix iterative analysis.

courses.name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Numerical solution of partial differential equations by finite difference methods and spectral methods. Construction of algorithms, consistency, convergence, and stability of numerical methods. Matrix iterative analysis.

courses.name: Boundary Integral Method
courses.description: Numerical solution of Fredholm and Volterra integral equations and of integro-differential equations. Convergence and stability of algorithms.

courses.name: Numerical Methods for Random Processes
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for random processes: random number generators, Monte Carlo methods, Markov chains, stochastic differential equations, and applications.

courses.name: Numerical Methods for Moving Interfaces
courses.description: methods for simulating sharp interfaces. Marker particle, level set, fast marching, volume of fluid, and phase fields methods.

courses.name: Mathematical Models in Biology
courses.description: This half-credit course discusses classical mathematical models of biological systems, with emphasis on the modeling process. Modeling tools used include ordinary and partial differential equations as well as agent-based frameworks. Topics may include chemotaxis, cellular aggregation, morphogenesis, and other classical systems that lend themselves to mathematical modeling. No biological background is required.

courses.name: Introduction to the Analysis of RNA Sequencing Data
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing high-throughput RNA sequencing data.  This includes working with data up to and including a differential expression analysis, and troubleshooting issues.  The course will also cover some of the theory, i.e., we will discuss the mathematical and statistical assumptions made in order to perform the various steps described above.

courses.name: What Do Your Data Say? A course to help you better understand your data.
courses.description: Modern data streams, whether from biomedical research labs, environmental research teams, or social-media survey projects, are increasingly quantitative and noisy.  In this class, we will teach you to think quantitatively and statistically about your data, so that you can confidently answer the question "What do my data (actually) say?"

courses.name: Data Driven Methods for Dynamical Systems
courses.description: The course will survey methods for characterizing time-series data by reading and discussing primary literature and implementing and testing methods. Students will simulate time-series from deterministic, chaotic,  and stochastic systems and apply a range of data-driven methods. The goal is to understand the suitability of different methods for characterizing dynamical systems with noise, nonlinearities, and other characteristics.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics
courses.description: Topics selected from research of current interest in applied mathematics.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Special projects to be carried out under faculty direction. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Summer Academic Workshop in Writing
courses.description: An introduction to college writing. Students learn how to use a process of planning, drafting, revising, and editing to write papers that are clear, concise, interesting, and persuasive.

courses.name: Expository Writing
courses.description: Emphasizes all phases of the composition process, research methods, and critical thinking. Careful review of student papers and reports. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Expository Writing
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Writing in Special Contexts
courses.description: Introduction to expository writing similar to ENGLISH 105-0 but paired with a course in another discipline.

courses.name: Writing in Special Contexts
courses.description: Introduction to expository writing similar to ENGLISH 105-0 but paired with a course in another discipline.

courses.name: Writing Seminar I:
courses.description: Topics vary. TBD.

courses.name: Writing Seminar II
courses.description: Topics vary. TBD.

courses.name: Writing Seminar II
courses.description: Topics vary. TBD.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature
courses.description: Introduction to the vocabulary, techniques, and pleasures of literature through close study and discussion of poems, plays, short stories, and novels. Short critical papers develop ability to analyze and interpret literature.

courses.name: Professional Communication
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Writing for Professionals
courses.description: Introduction to writing effective business documents, ranging from letters, memos, and email messages to reports, proposals, and press releases. ENGLISH 111-CN, ENGLISH 205-CN, or equivalent writing experience recommended.

courses.name: Introduction to Creative Writing
courses.description: Forms and techniques of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction.

courses.name: Intermediate Composition
courses.description: Expository writing at an intermediate level. Emphasis on techniques for writing clearly, precisely, and persuasively. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Intermediate Composition
courses.description: Expository writing at an intermediate level. Emphasis on techniques for writing clearly, precisely, and persuasively. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Intermediate Composition
courses.description: Expository writing at an intermediate level. Emphasis on techniques for writing clearly, precisely, and persuasively. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Reading & Writing Poetry
courses.description: Forms and techniques of verse. May not be taken earlier than winter quarter of the first year. Seniors may enroll only with department consent.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Poetry
courses.description: Forms and techniques of verse. May not be audited or taken P/N. Advanced composition course or equivalent writing experience strongly recommended.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Fiction
courses.description: Forms and techniques of fiction.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Fiction
courses.description: Forms and techniques of fiction. May not be audited or taken P/N. Advanced composition course or equivalent writing experience strongly recommended.

courses.name: Reading & Writing Creative Non-Fiction
courses.description: Forms and techniques of creative nonfiction.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Creative Nonfiction
courses.description: Forms and techniques of creative nonfiction. May not be audited or taken P/N. Advanced composition class and strong basic writing skills highly recommended.

courses.name: Topics in Genre Writing
courses.description: Forms and techniques of genre writing (e.g., screenwriting, young adult fiction, adaptation, memoir). May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: British Literary Traditions
courses.description: Chronological survey of British literature in its cultural contexts from Beowulf to the 18th century. Beowulf to the late 18th century.

courses.name: British Literary Traditions
courses.description: Chronological survey of British literature in its cultural contexts from Beowulf to the 20th century. Late 18th century to the 20th century.

courses.name: British Literary Traditions II
courses.description: Chronological survey of British literature in its cultural contexts from the late 18th century to the 20th century.

courses.name: Introduction to Poetry
courses.description: Elements of lyric and narrative poetry, with emphasis on the ways these can create meaning and elicit response.

courses.name: Introduction to Drama
courses.description: Fundamental elements of drama as perceived in performance. How a play communicates from text to stage to audience.

courses.name: Introduction to Fiction
courses.description: How prose fiction, as practiced by various British and American authors from the 18th century to today, creates and communicates meaning.

courses.name: Introduction to Fiction
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Introduction to Film and Its Literatures
courses.description: Skills of formal film analysis. Critical overview of multiple forms of film related writing, including historical scholarship, film theory, popular reviews, legal documents, manifestos, and movie-inspired fiction.

courses.name: The Bible as Literature
courses.description: Selected books of the Hebrew bible and New Testament studied from a literary perspective; issues of plot, character, genre, narrative strategy, and theories of interpretation. Students may not receive credit if they took the same class as the former COMP_LIT 210-0.

courses.name: Introduction to Shakespeare
courses.description: Representative Shakespearean plays.

courses.name: American Literary Traditions
courses.description: Representative writers and works of American literature in cultural context. Puritans to Moby-Dick.

courses.name: American Literary Traditions
courses.description: Representative writers and works of American literature in cultural context. Mid-19th century to World War I.

courses.description: Chronological survey of American literature from the Puritan era to the Civil War. Previous literature course strongly recommended. Students should have fulfilled the SPS writing requirement or completed equivalent writing courses prior to enrolling.

courses.name: American Literary Traditions II
courses.description: Chronological survey of American literature from the aftermath of the Civil War to World War I. Previous literature course strongly recommended. Students should have fulfilled the SPS writing requirement or completed equivalent writing courses prior to enrolling.

courses.name: Introduction to 20th-Century American Literature
courses.description: Principal writers and works since World War I.

courses.name: Introduction to Native American and Indigenous Literatures
courses.description: Key texts and themes from pre-contact periods to the present.

courses.name: Introduction to Asian American Literature
courses.description: From the early 20th century to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. Taught with ASIAN_AM 275-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Literature
courses.description: Survey of major writers and movements from the Spanish colonial era to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. Taught with LATINO 277-0 and SPANISH 277-0; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

courses.name: Writing and Speaking in Business
courses.description: Emphasizes writing and speaking to inform and persuade audiences in business contexts to achieve business goals. Attention to clear, compelling, and well-organized written and oral communication.

courses.name: Seminar in Reading and Interpretation
courses.description: Close reading of literary works in the light of various perspectives in literary study.

courses.name: Seminar in Reading and Interpretation
courses.description: Close reading of literary works in the light of various perspectives in literary study.

courses.name: History of the English Language
courses.description: The English language from the earliest times to today.

courses.name: Practical Rhetoric
courses.description: The theory of writing and skills that underlie good writing; primarily for teachers in secondary schools and universities.

courses.name: Advanced Composition
courses.description: This course is for undergraduate students in their second year or above who want to develop their abilities to write in different styles and for different audiences.

courses.description: For students who have taken courses in poetry writing or who have been writing poetry on their own, further practice and study in the development of poems. May not be audited or taken P/N.
courses.prereqs: ENGLISH 206-CN or permission of instructor. Students should have previous poetry writing experience in an academic setting. Instructor's consent and confirmation of the prerequisite course or appropriate writing experience is required for enrollment in this course

courses.description: For students who have taken courses in fiction writing or who have been writing fiction on their own, further practice and study in the development of short stories. May not be audited or taken P/N.
courses.prereqs: ENGLISH 207-CN or permission of instructor. Students should have previous creative writing experience in an academic setting. Instructor's consent and confirmation of the prerequisite course or appropriate writing experience is required for enrollment in this course

courses.name: Advanced Creative Writing: Fiction II
courses.description: For students who have completed at least one course in fiction writing,  further study of matters of technique and structure, with  an emphasis on the exploration of character and discovery of plot through the  process of revising. Short stories by contemporary authors will be read as models. The course builds on the premises, assignments, and goals of ENGLISH 307-A, but students may enroll without having completed that course. May not be audited or taken P/N.
courses.prereqs: ENGLISH 207-CN or ENGLISH 307-A or comparable courses in creative writing with permission of instructor. Instructor's consent and confirmation of the prerequisite course or appropriate writing experience is required for enrollment in this course

courses.name: Advanced Reading and Writing Creative Nonfiction I
courses.description: For students who have taken courses in creative nonfiction or who have been writing creative nonfiction on their own, further study in developing command of creative writing techniques and forms to frequent short writing exercises and essays. Class discussion of published essays and excerpts from longer works and student drafts may address such topics as voice, style, structure, the uses of research, and truth. May not be audited or taken P/N.
courses.prereqs: ENGLISH 208-CN or permission of instructor. Students should have previous creative writing experience in an academic setting. Instructor's consent and confirmation of the prerequisite course or appropriate writing experience is required for enrollment in this course

courses.name: Advanced Reading and Writing Creative Nonfiction II
courses.description: For students who have completed at least one course in fiction writing,  further study of the analysis and writing of creative nonfiction, emphasizing close reading of assigned selections and careful writing and revision of student work. The course builds on the premises, assignments, and goals of ENGLISH 308-A, with focus on the writing of a longer work; students may enroll without having completed that course. May not be audited or taken P/N.
courses.prereqs: ENGLISH 208-CN or ENGLISH 308-A, or comparable courses in creative writing with permission of instructor.  Instructor's consent and confirmation of the prerequisite course or appropriate writing experience is required for enrollment in this course

courses.name: Writers' Studies in Literature
courses.description: Writers' Studies in Literature. Students will learn about literature from a writers' perspective through close reading, as well as contextualization through generic, and thematic and formal lineage. Students will begin to see literature as a "body of enacted criticism" in a way that is essential to the program's interdisciplinary foundation and to their own development as writers. These courses will be taught by either creative writing faculty or literature faculty, with at least one major assignment in each course relying on research and critical writing.

courses.name: Introduction to Graduate Study
courses.description: Principles, techniques, and consequences of representative modes of literary inquiry exemplified in works of contemporary scholarship and criticism. Required of Ph.D. students.

courses.name: Studies in Poetry
courses.description: Content varies. Topics may include prosody or other formal aspects of poetry; comparative study of poems from different historical periods; consideration of poetics and the relationship of poetry to other cultural activities.

courses.name: Editorial Practicum
courses.description: Summer work as an editorial assistant for TriQuarterly Online. Open to students in the Litowitz Creative Writing Graduate Program, MFA+MA.

courses.name: Elements of Craft
courses.description: A cross-genre seminar-based workshop for first-year MFA+MA students. This course will prepare students for the dual-degree program and teach them the "language of workshop" while developing their critical and creative writing skills.

courses.name: Mapping the MFA Thesis
courses.description: The Long Form-MFA cross-genre workshop dedicated to organizing the MFA thesis.

courses.name: Cross-Genre Creative Writing Workshop
courses.description: Students will practice creative writing across genres and will examine the ways that genres overlap, influence and inform one another.

courses.name: MFA Poetry Workshop
courses.description: A graduate level poetry workshop for MFA+MA students. Open to other university graduate students by application.

courses.name: MFA Fiction Workshop
courses.description: A graduate level fiction workshop for MFA+MA students. Open to other university graduate students by application.

courses.name: MFA Creative Nonfiction Workshop
courses.description: A graduate level creative nonfiction workshop for MFA+MA students. Open to other university graduate students by application.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Permission of instructor and department required. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Research Development Seminar
courses.description: Third year doctoral students in the English department will be required to take this class in which they will draft a doctoral prospectus and an application for a research grant.

courses.name: Writing for Publication
courses.description: English department students in candidacy will develop professional skills related to writing for publication, whether for an academic or a broader public audience.

courses.name: Seminar in Teaching Composition
courses.description: An introduction to theories, practices and controversies in the teaching of writing in colleges and universities, within the context of various definitions of literacy in American culture.

courses.name: Teaching Creative Writing
courses.description: All MFA+MA students will take this specially designed pedagogy course during their first year. Students will study the history and models of teaching for Creative Writing programs. Students will design creative writing courses, set clear, achievable learning objectives, draft syllabi, generate exercises, and select reading material for introductory courses in poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS- Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: MFA Thesis Tutorial
courses.description: Registration for MFA+MA students writing an MFA Thesis project.

courses.name: Principles of Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This survey-style class is designed for students with limited or no prior exposure to entrepreneurship. The class serves as the foundational course for the undergraduate minor in entrepreneurship, but is also a good choice for students who simply wish to familiarize themselves with the world of entrepreneurship. Students will be introduced to the requisite skill sets for advanced entrepreneurship coursework. They will also learn how to understand and analyze a broad range of entrepreneurial activity, and will have the opportunity to locate their own goals and values within the field of entrepreneurship.  Taught with IEMS 225-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Personal Branding
courses.description: Growing and Monetizing your Fanbase is designed to expose artists to entrepreneurial thinking in building their careers. Are you a singer, actor, musician, comedian, writer, graphic artist, fashionista, or dancer that wants to promote your career? Students will be exposed to highly relevant methodologies that startup entrepreneurs use to create and grow their companies, but in this case, the corporation being grown and promoted is their talent and fans, via their own personal brand.

courses.name: Storytelling for Business
courses.description: Humans have been communicating through stories for 20,000 years. They have the power to persuade, engage, and inspire action. But too often, in business, we don't think about harnessing the power of stories. Storytelling for Business will teach students how to use narrative techniques and structures to create compelling stories to help them nail an interview, motivate a team, secure funding, build a brand, and inspire customers.

courses.name: Engineering Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Overview of the entrepreneurial process from an engineering perspective. Idea generation, planning, financing, marketing, protecting, staffing, leading, growing, and harvesting. Business models for startups. Lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Taught with IEMS 325-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Startup Accounting and Finance
courses.description: This class teaches students how to manage the finances of small and early-stage businesses using accounting software. Students also learn foundational accounting principles, and will work in teams on projects driven by case studies.

courses.name: Entrepreneurial Sales and Marketing
courses.description: Principles and practices for scaling entrepreneurial ventures. Application of coherent methodology to a student-run venture. Self-organizing teams develop a customer/client focus, provide for continuous improvement in successive iterations, and operate with transparency.

courses.name: Financing Entrepreneurial Ventures
courses.description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Innovate for Impact
courses.description: This is an experiential, team-based course in which students create social-impact focused entrepreneurial ventures using both lean startup methodology and human-centered design.

courses.name: Leadership, Ethics, and You
courses.description: This class is designed for students who want to explore how ethics and integrity are tied to leadership, and how developing leadership skills can contribute to students’ future successes in both entrepreneurial endeavors and more traditional careers.

courses.name: Entrepreneurship Demystified
courses.description: This is a discussion and project-based course in which students explore topics in ethics and leadership with the context of working for a startup or building one's own company.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Independent Study with Farley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
courses.description: Special projects under faculty direction. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Consulting for Wearable Technology
courses.description: In Consulting for Wearable Technology, students form small consulting teams around technologies being developed in the Querrey Simpson Institute for Bioelectronics, and work with real client companies in the biosensor space. Students learn to manage high technical and market risks, deal with complex intellectual property, and navigate the culturally diverse worlds of science and business. Application required. Open to graduate students and advanced undergrads.

courses.name: NUvention: Medical Innovation
courses.description: NUvention: Medical Innovation is an interdisciplinary experiential learning program designed to expose students to the entire innovation and entrepreneurial life cycle of new medical technologies. Medical innovations evolve from basic clinical needs, and NUvention is designed to simulate how they become businesses in the real world.

courses.name: NUvention: Medical Innovation
courses.description: NUvention: Medical Innovation is an interdisciplinary experiential learning program designed to expose students to the entire innovation and entrepreneurial life cycle of new medical technologies. Medical innovations evolve from basic clinical needs, and NUvention is designed to simulate how they become businesses in the real world.

courses.name: NUvention Transportation
courses.description: NUvention: Transportation is an interdisciplinary, experiential course created in collaboration with the Transportation Center, designed to teach students about creating businesses in the transportation space. NUvention: Transportation will look at the evolutionary and revolutionary changes that are recreating the face of transportation, and will provide opportunities for student teams to build business models in this field under the guidance of industry veterans. This class is designed to expose students to all aspects of the business development process from the idea to the creation, financing and running of a start-up business. Finally, this is a project-based class in which students will receive mentorship and expert advice from Advisory Board members in order to ensure a proper product-market alignment.

courses.name: NUvention Therapeutics
courses.description: Students learn how to commercialize research and start a company in the therapeutics/pharmaceutical space.

courses.name: NUvention: Web and Media
courses.description: NUvention:Web is an interdisciplinary experiential learning program designed to expose students to the entire product and  business development life cycle for a software company. Students work in teams on project ideas from their peers. An advisory board of alums coach students through the development and launch of their business.

courses.name: NUvention: Web and Media
courses.description: NUvention:Web is an interdisciplinary experiential learning program designed to expose students to the entire product and  business development life cycle for a software company. Students work in teams on project ideas from their peers. An advisory board of alums coach students through the development and launch of their business.

courses.name: NUvention: Energy
courses.description: NUvention: Energy is  a capstone course in the graduate-level course cluster offered through ISEN. Over an intense quarter, undergraduates and graduate students from schools across campus come together in interdisciplinary teams to develop a product or service and a business in the burgeoning sustainable energy and technology industry. By simulating the product/service and business development process, NUvention Energy helps students develop creative, interpersonal, business, and technical skills.

courses.name: NUvention: Analytics
courses.description: Modeled similarly after other NUvention courses, in this course interdisciplinary students teams will be created and assigned to an NU faculty member to work on commercializing a technology the faculty member believes has potential. A focus of course is to determine a viable business model to commercialize faculty research. Student teams are not engaged in technology innovation, but their efforts may inform technology evolution. Admittance to course by application only

courses.name: NUvention: Arts
courses.description: NUvention: Arts targets students from across Northwestern with a passion for the arts. This course facilitates the creation, innovation, and organization of new ideas and companies in the field of the creative arts, and works to help students understand that success in the arts is a function of passion, work ethic, talent, and entrepreneurial drive.

courses.name: NUvention Wearable Technology and Body-Interfaced Electronics
courses.description: This course will teach students how to commercialize technology and start companies in the biotech space.

courses.name: Product Management
courses.description: Product Management is a project-based course that focused on action learning and a build-your-own-case approach to teach foundational product management skills. The class goals are simple: 1) Learn how to launch a product. 2) Learn how to obtain a top-notch product management job in tech. This section is for undergraduate and non-McCormick MS registrants. Cross-listed with MEM 490 and IMC 490.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Projects (Research)
courses.description: Special projects under faculty direction. Permission of instructor and department required. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Decision Making for Climate Change: Policy Responses and Options
courses.description: Decision Making for Climate Change: Policy Responses and Options

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College.  Does not satisfy major/minor requirements in EPC.

courses.name: Organizational Strategies for Sustainability: Sustainability Leadership
courses.description: Organizational Strategies for Sustainability: Sustainability Leadership

courses.name: Food and Society: An Introduction
courses.description: Overview of past and present food systems from a sociological perspective, examining the roles of culture, government policy, and social movements in shaping such systems and future alternatives. ENVR_POL 211-0 and SOCIOL 211-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Environment and Society
courses.description: Key environmental problems, such as climate change and oil spills; how they are shaped by the market, government regulations, and social movements; possible solutions. SOCIOL 212-0 and ENVR_POL 212-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Religion, Ecology and Culture
courses.description: The historical rise of environmentalism in American culture and its impact on religious thought and practice. ENVR_POL 261-0 and RELIGION 261-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Environmental History
courses.description: American history from precontact to the present, focusing on the role of the natural world in human history and the role of human thought and action in natural history. ENVR_POL 309-0 and HISTORY 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Food, Politics and Society
courses.description: Social groups, institutions, and policies shaping food production, distribution, and consumption around the world; their social and environmental consequences. Alternatives to existing food systems. SOCIOL 311-0 and ENVR_POL 311-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Social Change and the Environment
courses.description: The ways social patterns of production and consumption affect the natural environment, such as climate and biodiversity. Roles of social actors and structures in shaping environmental problems and policies. SOCIOL 312-0 and ENVR_POL 312-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The Climate Crisis, Policies, and Society
courses.description: Examination of main impacts of climate change and of different perspectives toward mitigation and adaptation: market-based, institutionalist, bio-environmentalist, social movement, and climate justice. SOCIOL 336-0 and ENVR_POL 336-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global Environments and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the recent histories of environmental issues around the world, including urbanization, industrialization, population growth, commodification, empire building, intercontinental welfare, energy extraction, and new technologies. ENVR_POL 340-0 and HISTORY 376-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Native Americans and Environmental Decision Making
courses.description: Focus on Native Americans, culture and cultural processes, and environmental decision making. Emphasis on contemporary Native American cultures and relevant research. ENVR_POL 356-0 and PSYCH 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Policy and Culture
courses.description: Lecture course on environmental issues of current interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics Seminar
courses.description: Seminar on current environmental issues and problems. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent project in student's area of interest. Readings and conferences. Comprehensive term paper required.

courses.name: Earth: A Habitable Planet
courses.description: Overview of the physical processes governing environmental systems, from lithosphere to hydrosphere to atmosphere. Physical science perspectives on current debates, such as those over water resources, energy, and climate change.

courses.name: The Health of the Biosphere
courses.description: Dimensions of the ecological niche; growth and regulation of populations; interactions among populations; community structure and diversity; conservation.

courses.name: Humans and the Environment
courses.description: Introduction to human interactions with the environment. Topics may include but are not limited to energy, sustainability, pollution, and climate change.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Sciences
courses.description: Lecture course on environmental science topics of interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent research on special problems under direct supervision of a faculty adviser. Comprehensive report required.

courses.name: Principles of Finance
courses.description: Foundation course for the certificate. Basic principles of finance, focusing on the effects of time and uncertainty on value. First half emphasizes valuation, including discounted cash flows, equity and debt valuation, the term structure of interest rates, portfolio theory, asset pricing, and efficient market theory. Second half examines firms' financing decisions, including capital budgeting, capital structure, and payout policy.

courses.name: Investments
courses.description: Active portfolio strategies in bonds and stocks, optimal portfolio selection from the perspective of individual and institutional investors, and the role of style and performance benchmarks in portfolio management. Performance evaluation, trading costs, and other special topics.

courses.name: Derivatives
courses.description: Use and pricing of forwards and futures, swaps, and options. Strategies for speculation and risk management, no-arbitrage pricing for forward contracts, binomial and Black-Scholes option pricing models, applications of pricing models in other contexts.

courses.name: Topics in Financial Economics
courses.description: In-depth examination of selected issues in finance.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. For students with less than two years of high school French or with no previous study of French.

courses.name: Elementary French II
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners.

courses.name: Elementary French III

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.

courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 111-1 or Department placement

courses.name: Elementary French

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. For students with less than two years of high school French or with no previous study of French.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 111-A or FRENCH 101-A, FRENCH 111-B or FRENCH 101-B or equivalent

courses.name: Intensive Elementary French
courses.description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Elementary French
courses.description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 115-1 or Department placement

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 121-1 or Department placement

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.
