courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 111-C or FRENCH 101-C or equivalent, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 121-A or FRENCH 102-A or equivalent, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 121-B or FRENCH 102-B or equivalent, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 115-2 or Department placement

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 125-1 or Department placement

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 125-2 or Department placement

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Credit for 1 quarter only.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: Grammar, conversation, reading, writing, and culture study. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

courses.name: Culture and Society
courses.description: Development of fluency, accuracy, and creativity in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing French; introduction to social, cultural, and literary topics.
courses.prereqs: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 121-3 or Department placement

courses.name: Writing Workshop: Cultural Encounters in Contemporary France
courses.description: Practical study of French grammar and structure; students develop and improve writing skills through practice in preparing short compositions.

courses.name: Oral Workshop: Individual and Society in France Today
courses.description: Practical course to increase listening comprehension, build vocabulary and idiom use, and enhance communication skills.

courses.name: Acting French
courses.description: Use of dramatic scenes, dialogues, songs and performance to help students improve their language skills and develop their interpretive, interpersonal and intercultural competence at the Intermediate Mid/High level.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 121-3 or FRENCH 125-3 or FRENCH 201-0 or consent of instructor

courses.name: Reading Literatures in French
courses.description: Introduction to texts in various genres such as essay, poetry, drama, novel, and autobiography, from at least two periods from the Middle Ages to the present.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 202-0, AP score of 5, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Reading Cultures in French
courses.description: Introduction to French and/or francophone cultures through texts and media from at least two periods; major themes, issues, and debates.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 202-0, AP score of 5, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Introducing the Novel
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of short French novels from different periods, with special attention to formal issues.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Introducing Theatre
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French plays from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Principles of tragedy and comedy; contemporary developments.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor. Credit not allowed for both FRENCH 272-0 and FRENCH 279-0

courses.name: Introducing Poetry
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French poetry from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Overview of major poetic movements.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor

courses.name: French Existentialism
courses.description: Existentialism in its literary, philosophical, and cultural manifestations.

courses.name: Theater in Translation
courses.description: Representative French plays from the 17th through 20th centuries; basic concepts of genre; social and historical context. Credit not allowed for both FRENCH 279-0 and FRENCH 272-0.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: Study of French language and culture in Paris. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

courses.name: French Phonetics
courses.description: Development of near-native spoken French through practice in correct pronunciation. Phonetic system of contemporary French; introduction to basic issues of theoretical phonetics.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 202-0, FRENCH 203-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Advanced Language in Context: Society and Popular Culture
courses.description: Practical study of structure, syntax, and usage of French through contemporary media, cinema, theater, and popular culture.

courses.name: Advanced Writing: Finding Your Voice in French
courses.description: Development of written expression for different communicative needs and functions based on the study of French writing styles and techniques.

courses.name: Advanced Conversation: Debating Contemporary France
courses.description: Development of advanced proficiency and confidence in spoken French through practice of speech and discussion of issues in current French media and culture. Emphasis on culturally appropriate usage.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 202-0, FRENCH 203-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: French For Professions
courses.description: French language as used in professional contexts. May include study of a specific field and differences from its American counterpart. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: The Middle Ages & Renaissance
courses.description: Study of literary texts of the French Middle Ages and Renaissance with emphasis on their historical and literary-historical contexts.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Medieval French Narratives
courses.description: Major narrative works of the French Middle Ages in historical context. Content varies; may include epics such as the Song of Roland, romances such as Chrétien de Troyes's Perceval, and narratives of childhood. Texts read in modern French versions.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Topics in Renaissance Literature
courses.description: Study of literary and other texts of the French Renaissance with emphasis on their literary, historical, and political contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Montaigne and Modernity
courses.description: In-depth study of the work of Michel de Montaigne and his models within the context of Renaissance history, politics and philosophy. All readings and discussion in French.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: 17th Century Literature
courses.description: Topics and issues related to the literature and culture of 17th century France. Content varies; topics covered previously include theater and its social and political contexts, the rise of rational thought, and the development of fiction and poetry. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Sexual Politics and the Ancien Regime
courses.description: Literary, intellectual, and political role of women in view of the debates generated by the issues of women's power in the public sphere before the French Revolution.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Rousseau and the French Revolution
courses.description: Analysis of Rousseau's political thought and major literary works and their impact on Revolutionary ideology and culture.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Studies in the Enlightenment
courses.description: Authors such as Rousseau, Diderot, Montesquieu, Voltaire, and Graffigny in relation to Enlightenment debates about science, religion, political authority, human nature, colonialism, gender, and slavery.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: The Novel in French
courses.description: Content varies; may include the novel of the ancien régime, the psychological novel, and the Bildungsroman in France.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: The Invention of Modernity
courses.description: Study of the origins of modernity in the 19th century, addressing such issues as the rise of mass culture, urbanization, and the beginnings of consumer society.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: From Modernism to Postmodernism
courses.description: Crises and reinventions of French prose from the modernist moment of the early 20th century to the ambiguities of "engaged" literature of the 1930s to postmodernism.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: African Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Major issues, trends, and authors from francophone Africa. Content varies; may include Shahrazade, narratives of gender relations, law and literature, violence, and writing.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Caribbean Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Major issues, trends, and authors from the francophone Caribbean and its diasporas. Content varies; may include Caribbean women writers; slavery, history, and memory; Caribbean identities.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: The Maghreb and the Middle East
courses.description: Major issues in the literatures and cultures of North Africa and the Middle East. Content varies. May include exile in writing; politics of language and translation.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: France and East Asia
courses.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the history of French-East Asian relations, including French representations of East Asia. May include translation, japonisme, cinema, literary and philosophical avant-gardes, and culture and globalization.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Transnational Francophone Studies
courses.description: Exploration of cultural production in various genres from the French-speaking world, with an emphasis on themes, ideas, and/or forms that traverse national and/or cultural boundaries.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit when content changes

courses.name: Giants, Cannibals, and Critique
courses.description: Analysis of works of Rabelais and Montaigne and their techniques of satire and social critique. Readings include related selections from Erasmus, More, La Boétie, and others.

courses.name: Proust
courses.description: Introduces the works of Marcel Proust, a central figure of European literature and thought.

courses.name: French Film
courses.description: Topics in French cinema: for example, French classical cinema, the New Wave, postcolonial French film, the cinema of Marguerite Duras.

courses.name: Gender & Sexuality
courses.description: Major trends and perspectives in gender and sexuality studies such as first and second wave feminisms, lesbian writers, AIDS literature, queer theory, gender and orientalism, cross-cultural feminism.

courses.name: Contemporary Theory
courses.description: Introduction to some major trends in contemporary French theory and the way they have influenced literary studies in the United States.

courses.name: Topics in French Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced exploration of special topics in French studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Political & Social Thought in France
courses.description: Major political and social trends in France from the ancien régime to the 20th century. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Women Writing in French
courses.description: Analysis of texts by women authors with regard to their respective social, cultural, political, and historical contexts.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Gender & Writing
courses.description: Issues of gender and sexuality in the production of literary and other creative texts in various historical periods. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Translation
courses.description: Intercultural communication through analysis of translation theories and translated works; translation exercises. Content varies; genres may include prose, poetry, graphic novels, and theater.
courses.prereqs: FRENCH 301-0, FRENCH 302-0, study abroad, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Foreign Language Teaching: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Theoretical foundation and practical applications of second-language acquisition and applied linguistics. Analysis and design of pedagogical materials. Self-reflection and analysis of teaching style and teaching philosophy.
courses.prereqs: senior status or consent of instructor

courses.name: Advanced Studies in Culture and Thought
courses.description: Theoretical perspectives and paradigms for understanding culture through in-depth study of a historical, cultural, or theoretical issue or of a literary or artistic work. Independent term paper.
courses.prereqs: senior status or consent of undergraduate advisor

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent reading and research. Topics arranged through consultation with an instructor and approval of the department.

courses.name: Print Culture: Authors
courses.description: Content varies. Studies of one or several major literary or cultural figures of French and Francophone studies. Emphasizes their status within literary history or the cultural context of their work.

courses.name: Foreign Language Teaching: Theory and Practice
courses.description: French and Italian Language Teaching: Theory and Practice Theoretical foundation in and practical applications of Second Language Acquisition and Applied Linguistics to the teaching of French and Italian. Analysis and design of pedagogical materials. Self-reflection and analysis of teaching style and teaching philosophy.

courses.name: Studies in Medieval Literature
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: Romances by Chretien de Troyes, Christine de Pizan, and Marie de France.

courses.name: Studies in the 16Th Century
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: Renaissance poetry; Rabelais; Montaigne.

courses.name: Visual Culture:Cinema, Performance Studies & Multimedia
courses.description: Content varies. Contemporary French cinema and film history, television and multimedia cultures, courses on film directors.

courses.name: Visual Culture: Art History & Literature
courses.description: Content varies: painting and literature, the circulation of works of art, the history of the relationship between literature and the visual arts.

courses.name: Studies in the 17Th Century
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: the moralists; power and knowledge in classical theatre; the critique of rationality.

courses.name: French, Francophone & Transnational Studies
courses.description: Studies of migration and diasporic discourses from missionary discourses and pre-modern travelers to contemporary globalized movements.

courses.name: Studies in the 18th Century
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: The rise of the public sphere; Diderot's aesthetics; Rousseau and the French Revolution; the global eighteenth century.

courses.name: Studies in the 19Th Century
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: Literature and/of the city; literature and revolution.

courses.name: Studies in 20Th Century Literature
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: Literature and cultural authority in 20th century France; l'aimance, l'amour, le corps de l'écriture.

courses.name: Topics in Francophone Colonial and Postcolonial Studies
courses.description: Content varies. Literature and culture of one or several geopolitical areas such as the Caribbean, the Maghreb, Sub-Saharan Africa or Vietnam.

courses.name: Topics in Literary Studies
courses.description: Content varies. Studies of a motif, theme, genre or theoretical issue across languages.

courses.name: Special Topics in Literature
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: literature of the African diaspora; women's autobiography.

courses.name: Topics in Culture and Society
courses.description: Content varies. Samples: culture and politics of the 1920s and 1930s; early modern print culture; the Situationist International.

courses.name: Topics in Literary Theory
courses.description: Topics in Literary Theory. Content varies (e.g., Post-structuralist Theory, Feminist Theory, Post-colonial Theory, Materialist/Marxist Theory, Media Theory).

courses.name: Interdisciplinary, Theoretical, and Critical Approaches
courses.description: Content varies. An examination of theoretical discourses from disciplines other than literature (linguistics, philosophy, psychoanalysis, historiography) and their relationship to the French and Francophone world; history of ideas.

courses.name: Practicum in Scholarly Writing, Publication, & Research
courses.description: Required of all second year students. Under faculty supervision, students revise and expand a paper written in the first or second year of course work for submission for the second year review.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: May be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor and department required. Please contact department for permission number.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit. Please see department for permission number.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Sexual Subjects: Introduction to Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Survey of sexuality studies across a range of disciplines. Introduction to major theoretical and methodological approaches. Epistemology, morphology, history, subjectivity/identity, race formation, gender, social organization, and regulation.

courses.name: Traditions in Feminist Thought
courses.description: Introduction to milestone texts in the development of 200 years of British, European, and American feminist thought, with particular attention to emerging arguments and strategies around issues of gender and sexuality.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Representation
courses.description: Representations in art and literature within their historical, social, and political contexts. Theories of spectatorship, resistance, and revision.

courses.name: Sexuality & Society
courses.description: Examination of the role of sexuality in the cultural, economic, political, and social organization of the United States. Sex work, sex tourism, sexual migration, LGBT social movements, and moral panics. SOCIOL 232-0 and GNDR_ST 232-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Gender, Politics, and Philosophy
courses.description: Role of gender difference in the main political-philosophical traditions: social contract, liberalism, republicanism, socialism-Marxism, critical theory. Classics of feminist and political thought (Wollstonecraft, Mill, Taylor, Engels) and contemporary debates. PHIL 221-0 and GNDR_ST 233-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Language & Gender
courses.description: Exploration of socially significant differences in the language used by/about/to men and women, focusing on the role of language in constructing gender as part of local communities of practice. LING 223-0 and GNDR_ST 234-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Beyond the Binary: Transgender and Race
courses.description: Exploration of transgender history, identity, and expression, with a focus on the intersection of gender and race.

courses.name: Gender Issues in Science and Health
courses.description: Aspects of gender in the cultures of science and medicine.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and History
courses.description: Historical considerations of gender and/or sexuality. Topics may cover different historical time periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: US Gay and Lesbian History
courses.description: Gender, sexuality, and the rise of modern lesbian and gay identities. Lecture and discussion. HISTORY 324-0 and GNDR_ST 324-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Language & Sexuality
courses.description: The use of language to construct sexual identity, focusing on the language of and about gay men and lesbians. Topics include heteronormativity, identity labels and categories, gender versus sexuality, and cross-cultural sexual diversity. Taught with GNDR_ST 327-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics or consent of instructor

courses.name: Sociology of Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Gender and issues of social reproduction and social change, with an emphasis on sexuality and reproduction.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Health
courses.description: Health-related topics concerning gender and/or sexuality. Topics include reproductive health, sexual health, HIV/AIDS, women's health movements, trans* health and activism and disability studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and the Law
courses.description: Examination of the changing role of law in governing gender and sexual relations in America. Legal definitions of gender and sexuality in the household, the marketplace, and the state. GNDR_ST 340-0 and LEGAL_ST 340-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Transnational Perspectives on Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Studies of gender and sexuality in relation to globalization or non-US/non-Western cultures. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Public Policy
courses.description: Studies of legal systems and public policy. Specific topics may include domestic violence and abortion legislation. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Political Theory
courses.description: Studies in political theory relating to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender and Citizenship
courses.description: Examinations of conventional conceptions of political participation and counter-public spheres informed by feminist activism and feminist and gender theory.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Literature
courses.description: Studies of literary texts in the context of gender theory, feminism, or sexuality studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Drama
courses.description: Studies in gender and/or sexuality in the context of theater and drama in or across historical periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Postcolonial Studies and Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Postcolonial approaches to literature and theory. Topics include orientalism and diaspora theory as they relate to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
courses.description: Cultural studies perspective on selected topics in popular culture as they relate to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Performance
courses.description: Selected topics concerning theories of performance in relation to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Film
courses.description: Primary emphasis on representations of gender and sexuality in film and film theory. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Digital Technologies
courses.description: Theories concerning gender and sexuality in digital representations, particularly Internet related. Content varies by quarter.

courses.name: Internship in Gender and Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Field research and practical work experience in activist organizations; biweekly meeting with the instructor and other interns for discussion of internship experiences and common readings.

courses.name: Black Feminist Theory
courses.description: Survey of black feminist theories. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement

courses.name: Queer Theory
courses.description: Survey of queer theories and methodologies. Fulfills the major's theory requirement. Content varies by quarter.

courses.name: Race, Gender, and Sexuality
courses.description: Literature and/or theory concerned primarily with the intersections of race and/or ethnicity and gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Topics vary. For example: masculinity; gender, race, and reproduction; gender, law, and public policy; Asian American women's history; women artists and their publics. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Topics in Gender Studies:
courses.description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Senior Capstone Seminar
courses.description: Introduction to research methods in the interdisciplinary study of gender and sexuality.

courses.name: Feminist Theory
courses.description: Survey of gender and feminist theory. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement.

courses.name: Senior Research Seminar
courses.description: Students work with an adviser and begin research on a senior thesis project, meeting on a reduced schedule over two quarters.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual tutorials or research projects.

courses.name: Graduate Colloquium
courses.description: Graduate colloquium dedicated to the discussion of recent published work in gender and sexuality studies and of graduate student work in progress. This two-course colloquium will meet five times per quarter, for two quarters. Students will receive credit at the end of the school year.

courses.name: Advanced Feminist Theory
courses.description: Survey of foundational feminist texts, and an exploration of the relationship between feminist theory and feminist practice, both within the academy and in the realm of politics.

courses.name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual tutorials or research projects.

courses.name: Engineering Freshman Seminar
courses.description: Broad engineering or interdisciplinary subjects of current interest.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog I
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog II
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog III
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog IV
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse I
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-1.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse II
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-2.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse III
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-3.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse IV
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-4.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to linear algebra from computational, mathematical, and applications viewpoints. Computational methods using a higher-level software package such as MATLAB.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis  II
courses.description: Linear algebra and introduction to vector methods in engineering analysis. Statics and dynamics of rigid bodies and matrix analysis of trusses and networks. Engineering design problems.
courses.prereqs: C- or better in GEN_ENG 205-1; MATH 220-1

courses.name: Engineering Analysis III
courses.description: Dynamic behavior of the elements. Modeling of mechanical (both translational and rotational), electrical, thermal, hydraulic, and chemical systems composed of those elements.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Solution methods for ordinary differential equations, including exact, numerical, and qualitative methods. Applications and modeling principles; solution techniques.
courses.prereqs: C- or better in GEN_ENG 205-2; MATH 220-2

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis I
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-1.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis II
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-2.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis III
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-3.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-4.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Honor Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-1 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-2 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-3 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-4 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Analy/Comp Graph
courses.description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

courses.name: Analy/Comp Graph II
courses.description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

courses.name: Special Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Intermediate-level topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Domestic Study Affiliated
courses.description: Fulltime registration in an academic program in the continental United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, registration is replaced with credits transferred from the affiliated institution.

courses.name: Special Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Topics of limited scope as suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent study on an engineering subject supervised by a faculty member and concluding with a final report.

courses.name: Responsible Conduct for Research Training
courses.description: The primary focus of this course will be on education in the responsible conduct of research (RCR), especially as it pertains to the engineering disciplines. Ethical and moral reasoning will be developed through analysis of case studies on the topics of conflict of interest, mentoring and lab management, collaborative research, data ownership and management, peer review, authorship, misconduct and the processes for handling misconduct.

courses.name: Teaching Experience
courses.description: Participation in the teaching service of the department, commonly as a Teaching Assistant.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Language Study I
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level.  Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Language Study II
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Language Study III
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Internship
courses.description: Restricted to Weinberg College students who need documentation of an internship on their transcripts. Requires approval of the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs. Contact college advisers for more information.

courses.name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study I
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study II
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study III
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance. Does not automatically satisfy the Weinberg College foreign language proficiency requirement.

courses.name: Arch Scholar Mentoring Program
courses.description: A weekly 1-hour workshop for first-year students in the Arch Scholar programs. Workshops will focus on academic skills, professional development, and college success strategies. Only two excused absences are allowed. Instructor permission to register is required.

courses.name: UPAL: Strategies for Advancing Learning
courses.description: Peer-mentored weekly small-group meetings about enhanced learning strategies. Time management, study strategies, interacting with faculty, and other topics.

courses.name: Science Research Workshops
courses.description: Learn about entering research with the help of a peer group leader and writing a research proposal for summer funding. Instructor permission or prior attendance at a Finding a Lab Workshop run by the Office of Undergraduate Research required. Grade of satisfactory given to students who attend and participate in at least 7 of the weekly workshops.

courses.name: Residence-Linked Seminar - I (Natural Sciences)
courses.description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

courses.description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Required registration for students receiving summer research grants from Weinberg College or the Undergraduate Research Grants Committee. Grade of satisfactory will be entered after final report is submitted.

courses.name: Student Organized Seminar
courses.description: Student-initiated seminar, supervised by a sponsoring faculty member. See Weinberg College Policies section of the Undergraduate Catalog for more information. P/N grading only.

courses.name: Study Abroad Affiliated
courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Study Abroad Summer PT
courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Study at NU-Qatar, Doha Campus
courses.description: For Evanston-based Northwestern students studying in Qatar (NU-Q) for a term. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Domestic Study - Affiliated
courses.description: Registration in an academic program in the United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Introduction to Music
courses.description: Key concepts and contexts for becoming an informed listener and critical thinker with respect to a broad range of musical styles and genres and for acquiring the skills and vocabulary to discuss and write about music effectively. Individual sections may vary from quarter to quarter; see specific section descriptions for more information. No previous musical training or ability to read music notation is required. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Selected Topics in Applied Music for Non-Majors
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.name: History of the Symphony
courses.description: Study of music for the symphony orchestra from the 17th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: History of Opera
courses.description: History of opera from its origins in Italy at the end of the 16th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: History of Rock
courses.description: The basic elements of rock from its roots in pop, country and western, and rhythm and blues to the present. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Harmony
courses.description: A basic course in music theory fundamentals, including harmonic materials and tonal structures. Analysis of harmonic structures; harmonization of melodies. (II. Formal studies)

courses.name: Form and Analysis
courses.description: Nature of musical forms found in musical literature from renaissance to the present; analysis of musical examples.
courses.prereqs: GEN_MUS 252-0, or music-reading skills and some understanding of harmony

courses.name: Non-Major Private Voice-Intermediate
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Western Musical Tradition
courses.description: Major genres and composers from 1600 to 1825. Primary emphasis on the generations of Bach and Handel, Haydn and Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.
courses.prereqs: GEN_MUS 170-0 or equivalent. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Western Musical Tradition
courses.description: Major genres and composers from 1825 to the present.
courses.prereqs: GEN_MUS 170-0 or equivalent. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Non-Major Piano - Graduate

courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: Baroque Music Ensemble
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: World Biogeography
courses.description: Geography of the world's major ecosystems based on the global climate model. Physical processes of soil formation and vegetation development in various ecosystems. Human impacts on natural systems resulting from past and present land-use practices.

courses.name: Biogeography
courses.description: Geography of the world's major ecosystems based on the global climate model. Physical processes of soil formation and vegetation development in various ecosystems. Human impacts on natural systems resulting from past and present land-use practices.

courses.name: Atmosphere and Climate
courses.description: Nature and composition of the atmosphere, principles of atmospheric motion, global circulation model, cyclonic storms; climates and climatic change.

courses.name: Atmosphere and Climate
courses.description: Nature and composition of the atmosphere, principles of atmospheric motion, global circulation model, cyclonic storms; climates and climatic change.

courses.name: Economic Geography
courses.description: Population, natural resources, land use, commodity production, and trade, with an emphasis on the world scale. Industrial location theory and global economic structures.

courses.name: Geography of Chicago & Its Region
courses.description: Chicago as an example and model of city form. Physical environments of the Chicago region and their influence on settlement. Evolution of the geography of Chicago and its suburbs from the 19th century to the present, with an emphasis on recent trends.

courses.name: North America
courses.description: Detailed study of the regional geography of the United States and Canada. The regional distribution of landform types. Patterns of culture, history, and economic development that underlie the distribution of distinctive lifeways in the two countries.

courses.name: The Human Use of the Earth
courses.description: Geography of the earth's natural environments as modified by human agency. Natural versus anthropogenic environmental change. Processes of habitat alteration in hunter-gatherer societies. Impacts of modern agriculture and forestry.

courses.name: The Human Use of the Earth
courses.description: Geography of the earth's natural environments as modified by human agency. Natural versus anthropogenic environmental change. Processes of habitat alteration in hunter-gatherer societies. Impacts of modern agriculture and forestry.

courses.name: Principles of Cartography
courses.description: Design, construction, and use of thematic maps for effective presentation of spatial data. Typography and symbolization. Coordinate systems and map projections.

courses.name: Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: Methods and techniques of digital cartography; encoding and analysis of spatial information; applications to archaeology, environmental sciences, and business geographics.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent research projects. Open to qualified advanced students with consent of department.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Research
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.
courses.prereqs: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.
courses.prereqs: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: German for Research
courses.description: Introduction to the translation of scholarly and scientific German texts. No prerequisites in the language.

courses.name: Intensive Beginning German through Musical Journeys in Vienna
courses.description: Interdisciplinary course offering musically interested students the opportunity to acquire German language skills through an immersion in the musical and cultural history of Vienna.
courses.prereqs: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

courses.name: Focus Reading
courses.description: Course for students who would like to explore German texts in more depth. Examines contemporary German culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Does not count for the language requirement. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

courses.name: Focus Speaking
courses.description: Practical training in listening comprehension and speaking. Examines contemporary German culture. Does not count for the language requirement. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

courses.name: Focus Writing
courses.description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

courses.name: Focus Writing
courses.description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

courses.name: Current Events in German Media
courses.description: Exploration of current events in a variety of German media (newspapers, TV, Internet, etc.). Topics include politics, music, film, sports, and literature.

courses.name: German in the Business World
courses.description: German language study oriented toward business-related communication situations, such as social interactions with customers, business travel, basic business letters.

courses.name: German Culture through Film
courses.description: Introduction to 20th century German cinema. Discussion of German identity, culture, history, and politics. Course emphasizes cultural knowledge and German language skills.

courses.name: History, Politics, and Culture in 21st Century German
courses.description: In-depth cultural and linguistic exploration of history, politics, and current issues (e.g., integration of foreigners, multicultural life) in Germany.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature: 1800-1900
courses.description: Introduction to representative texts and writers of 19th century German literature and familiarizes them with literary analysis and genres.

courses.name: Introduction to German Literature: 1900-1945
courses.description: Introduction to representative German texts and writers of the first half of the 20th century, when the First World War, the Weimar Republic, and the Third Reich marked the demise of the German Empire.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature: 1945-today
courses.description: Introduction to representative short stories by major German-speaking authors since 1945. The stories represent a dynamic period in German literature and highlight important social, political, and intellectual issues.

courses.name: German History from 1789-1989
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

courses.name: German History from 1789-1989
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

courses.name: Austrian Literature
courses.description: Overview and introduction to contemporary Austria-the land, its people, and cultural institutions-through newer writers such as Hackl, Handke, Haslinger, Helfer, Jelinek, Nöstlinger, Reichart, Schlag, and Turrini.

courses.name: Contemporary Germany
courses.description: The German political, social, and cultural scene after 1945.
courses.prereqs: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

courses.name: New Voices in German Literature
courses.description: Introduction to contemporary German literature in English translation. Topics vary and may include the contemporary historical novel, short story, novel, or memoir.

courses.name: German Film
courses.description: In-depth study of German films and cultural background. Topics may vary-for example, the pioneer film or "new" German cinema.
courses.prereqs: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

courses.name: Berlin and the Culture of Democracy
courses.description: History and culture of the city from 1900 to the present, including the Weimar period, Nazi regime, the divisions of the Cold War, and the newly unified capital.

courses.name: The Theme of Faust Through the Ages
courses.description: Faust theme in literature and music through shifting intellectual and social climates from the 16th century to the present.

courses.name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History I
courses.description: Exploration of Jewish encounters with German culture. German Jewry from the 18th century to the end of the 19th century, when Jews were granted legal standing as German citizens.

courses.name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History II
courses.description: Jewish culture-German culture exploration. German-speaking Jewry from the late 19th century to 1933.

courses.name: Kafka and Nietzsche
courses.description: Exploration of two key figures in German modernity. Analysis of the relation between philosophy and literature; inquiry into the idea of the "ascetic ideal."

courses.name: Turn-of-the-Century Vienna
courses.description: Literature and thought of fin de siècle Vienna and their impact on modern consciousness. Fiction, poetry, essays, and plays by Freud, Schnitzler, Wittgenstein, Hofmannsthal, Musil, Karl Kraus, and Schoenberg.

courses.name: Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish and German
courses.description: History and character of Yiddish and the development of modern German culture and German-Jewish culture. Appreciation of the variety of "Judaisms" imagined and reimagined during modern European history.
courses.prereqs: None. GERMAN 242-0 and JWSH_ST 242-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses

courses.name: Analyzing Freud
courses.description: Freud's work from a comparative and interdisciplinary perspective. Fundamental texts by Freud in dialogue with related materials that situate him in historical, cultural, and intellectual context.

courses.name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: Studies of a major author, a prominent theme in German literature or culture, a movement, or a genre. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics vary-for example, the fairy tale, Germanic mythology.

courses.name: Learning Diversity: Germany and Global Migration
courses.description: Explores how migration from and to Germany has impacted and shaped the country's political, social, and cultural development as an increasingly diverse country.

courses.name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
courses.description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

courses.name: Luther and the West
courses.description: Examination of Luther's work in the context of his life and times. Introduces basic dimensions of Western thought, showing how theology relates to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues. GERMAN 272-0 and RELIGION 272-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Speaking as Discovery
courses.description: A course to improve German listening and speaking skills to the advanced level. Uses current cultural texts, films, and television broadcasts.

courses.name: Writing as Discovery
courses.description: Practice of advanced and sophisticated structures of written German through a series of linguistic exercises, including a biographical piece of writing.

courses.name: German Media
courses.description: Current political and cultural events in Germany and Europe. Topics from German language media, including newspapers, magazines, Internet sources, and news broadcasts. Discussion of journalistic differences.

courses.name: Advanced Business German: the German Economy
courses.description: Germany's economy, its current problems, business practices, and differences from the United States.

courses.name: Advanced Business German: Marketing and Management
courses.description: Students gain skills to function in a multitude of German business contexts, such as management and marketing. They also increase their cross-cultural knowledge and intercultural competency.

courses.name: Reason, Revolution, and Despair: 1800-1900
courses.description: Discussion of key texts in German intellectual history from the Enlightenment to the prerevolutionary period in the 1830s.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Myth and Modernity: 1900-1945
courses.description: Literature and thought, events, and ideologies that shaped German cultural, political, and social life from 1900 to 1945, during the Weimar Republic and the Nazi state.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Recoveries and Transitions: 1945-Present
courses.description: Examination of the relationship of literature and film to the sociopolitical sphere since 1945.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: German Contributions to World Literature
courses.description: Topics vary-for example, Rilke's poetry; Nietzsche's influence on literature; Thomas Mann; Hesse, the German novel, and the mystic tradition; German intellectual history.
courses.prereqs: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

courses.name: Rhyme and Reason in German Poetry
courses.description: Introduction to German poetry from the early 18th century to the present. Concentrates on the main formal categories of poetry as well as the main topics and themes of German poetry.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Modern German Drama
courses.description: Plays by authors ranging from Heinrich von Kleist to Peter Weiss, from the perspective of the stage as a "moral institution."

courses.name: German Cultural Studies
courses.description: Exploration of key concepts, major figures, and cultural and literary themes in German studies and interdisciplinary fields such as music, art, political science, media studies, and popular culture.

courses.name: German Expressionism
courses.description: German Expressionism in its most extreme literary and artistic reactions to the impact of modernity, war, and revolution and on the individual and collective experience in Berlin from 1910 to 1920.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Brecht: Theater, Film, and Media
courses.description: Introduction to Bertolt Brecht's theater in the 1920s and early 1930s during the Weimar Republic. Historical critical review of the still-evolving media of film and radio.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Shattered Worlds: Representation after the Shoa
courses.description: Examination of the role of German literature and art in the creation of historical consciousness in the postwar period.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Literature of a Divided Nation
courses.description: Study of the literature and culture of the German Democratic Republic within social, political, and historical contexts.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Writers and their Critics
courses.description: Study of the texts of leading writers in German through a discussion of the criticism these texts have evoked. Emphasis on 20th and 21st century criticism.

courses.name: Minority Voices in Germany
courses.description: Study of minority literatures in Germany (including Turkish, Italian, Afro German, and Jewish) within social, political, and historical contexts.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Science and Culture in Germany
courses.description: Exploration of key texts popularizing major scientific innovations in Germany. The focus is on tracing the scientific, political, philosophical, aesthetic history of German as a "green nation" from the 18th century until today.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: German History: Weimar and Nazi Germany
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Weimar and Nazi Germany. GERMAN 344-1 and HISTORY 344-1 are taught together: may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: German History: Germany Since 1945
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Germany beginning in 1945 to reunification at the end of the Cold War. GERMAN 344-2 and HISTORY 344-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature). May be repeated for credit with different topic

courses.name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.
courses.prereqs: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

courses.name: History of the Holocaust
courses.description: Origins and development of the massacre of European Jewry during World War II. GERMAN 349-0 and HISTORY 349-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
courses.description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War.
courses.prereqs: None. GERMAN 366-0, JWSH_ST 366-0 and YIDDISH 366-0 taught together; may receive credit for only one course.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Open to outstanding German majors with senior standing.
courses.prereqs: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

courses.name: German Literature and Critical Thought 1750-1832
courses.description: This course begins with the formative aesthetic discussions undertaken by Lessing and Mendelssohn, turns to Kant¿s program for critical self-reflection, and considers a wide range of responses, including those of Schiller, the early romantics, Kleist, Hölderlin, and Goethe.

courses.name: History of Literature and Critical Thought 1832-1900
courses.description: Thematic approach to key texts of 19th century German literature between Goethe and Gottfried Keller, tragedy and the Bildungsroman. Literary and philosophical texts are read side by side in order to interrogate traditional concepts of realism, mimesis, and interpretation.

courses.name: German Literature, Critical Thought and New Media 1900-1945
courses.description: Built around selected key texts on the aesthetic theories of modernism (e.g., by Nietzsche, Adorno, Bürger, and Kittler), this course explores the relationship of literature and the visual arts and scrutinizes the status of literature within aesthetic production in modernity. Particular attention to works by Rilke, Kafka, Brecht, Lasker-Schüler, Benn, Musil, and Mann.

courses.name: German Literature, Critical Thought, and New Media since 1945
courses.description: Overview of the most influential texts that reflect the mounting concern with media in German literary and critical theory since the Second World War. Emphasis on the effects of the rise of media studies and theory on the understanding and interpretation of literature.

courses.name: Basic Issues in Foreign Language Teaching
courses.description: This course focuses on basic principles of second language acquisition and language teaching methodology. It introduces students to the major trends and theories in language teaching. The critical reflection of pedagogical practices is emphasized.

courses.name: Critical Theory and Religion
courses.description: This course explores the central place the concept of “religion” has occupied in the development of critical theory and, in turn, the role critical theory has played in reframing “religion” in modernity and in the contemporary geopolitical moment. We take up the question, “Is critique secular,” as we consider the contributions, potential and actual, of “religion” to social transformation.

courses.name: Contemporary German Literature
courses.description: Readings from authors representative of literature in the former East and West Germany's. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Studies in Communication and Culture
courses.description: Content varies. Samples; feminist literature, media studies, the history of literary journals, and other specific topics representative of current research interests. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Independent Reading
courses.description: May be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor and department required.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: May be repeated for credit. SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to dissertation. May be repeated for credit.SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Introduction to International Public Health
courses.description: Introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide. The course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices, and forms of knowledge production characteristic of what we call "global health" today, and explores the factors that shape patterns and experiences of illness and healthcare across societies.

courses.name: Introduction to International Public Health
courses.description: Introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide. The course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices, and forms of knowledge production characteristic of what we call "global health" today, and explores the factors that shape patterns and experiences of illness and healthcare across societies.

courses.name: Global Bioethics
courses.description: Global health is a popular field of work and study for Americans, but though entered with the best of intentions, the work is beset with ethical questions, concerns, and dilemmas. In this course, students will assess emblematic ethical challenges in global health and consider approaches to addressing them.

courses.name: Global Health & Indigenous Medicine
courses.description: Exploration of a variety of healing systems, their relationship to global health, and the factors underlying why people choose one over another.

courses.name: Biomedicine and Culture
courses.description: Comparative exploration of biomedical cultures in different contexts, both in the U.S. and other countries. This course covers how biomedicine intersects with technology, consumerism, politics, economics, culture, power, and place. It further investigates the possibilities and limitations of biomedicine across the globe, particularly regarding how biomedical cultures affect and are affected by patients and health care workers.

courses.name: International Perspectives on Mental Health
courses.description: Cross-cultural and international perspectives on mental health issues and examination of the impact of psychological illness on the global burden of disease.

courses.name: Global Health in Human History
courses.description: Exploration of paleopathology, including records of pre- and proto-historic adaptations to human disease, health, and medicine. The biocultural perspective on patterns of disease links past perspectives and current realities.

courses.name: Biomedicine and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the social, political, scientific, and economic forces allowing biomedical systems to become synonymous with global health governance. GBL_HLTH 309-0 and HISTORY 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Supervised Global Health Research
courses.description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

courses.name: Supervised Global Health Research
courses.description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

courses.name: Health Care Systems in Europe and the United States
courses.description: Provides students with an understanding of the various ways in which health care systems are organized in European countries, the problems they face, and the reforms implemented or proposed at the national and EU levels. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Public Health in Europe: Issues and Policies
courses.description: Examines issues and debates on health policy in France and the EU, including primary health issues, health insurance, health inequalities, HIV/AIDS, SARS, elderly care, and genetically modified organisms. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: International Organizations and Health: A Research Seminar
courses.description: Students design team research projects, learn about research methodology, discuss their research progress, and present findings. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Health and Community Development in South Africa
courses.description: Health-related issues confronting South Africa, their social and economic impact, efforts to address them. Apartheid and post-transition policies. Demographics, prevention, and treatment of both infectious and chronic non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Public Health in South Africa
courses.description: Context of and responses to public health issues in South Africa, including HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, malnutrition and poverty, psychosocial rehabilitation, and environmental and occupational health. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Development Perspectives on Health in South Africa Through Community Engagement
courses.description: Reflection on service-learning experiences at community organizations in relation to theories of international development and global health. Focus on how health-related issues, including HIV/ AIDS, malnutrition, poverty, the environment, occupational health, and gender, impact development. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Global Health
courses.description: This course emphasizes research skills acquisition in a practical manner. Topics include how to design, conduct, analyze and write up qualitative ethnographic research. The course covers research methodologies, ethics and Institutional Review Boards, and ethnographic field methods such as participant observation, qualitative interviewing, life histories, focus groups, data coding and analysis. Students acquire research skills while receiving significant feedback throughout.

courses.name: War and Public Health
courses.description: Comparative overview of the impact of armed conflict on public health and healthcare delivery worldwide. Historical and contemporary case studies. Specific health needs of refugees and vulnerable populations.

courses.name: The Social Determinants of Health
courses.description: Advanced introduction to socioeconomic, political, and cultural determinants of health disparities between social groups and categories. Case studies from the United States, South Africa, and Brazil.

courses.name: Global Health from Policy to Practice
courses.description: Examines global health and development policy, from the politics of policy-making to the impacts of policy on global health practice and local realities. This course highlights the histories and material, political, and social realities of policy and its application. The course draws on case studies of policy makers, economists, public officials, health care workers, and aid recipients.

courses.name: Volunteerism and the Ethics of Help
courses.description: Explores the ethics of altruism through the discourses and practices that make up volunteering, from the perspectives of volunteers, hosts, and a range of others both promoting and critiquing volunteerism. What motivates people to volunteer among strangers or in unfamiliar contexts? What are the implications for volunteers, and communities and institutions where foreign volunteering takes place?

courses.name: History of Reproductive Health
courses.description: This course concerns the history of human reproduction from multiple vantage points. Since reproduction is often about power, the course is framed around the distribution of power in matters of reproduction; as such we will pay particular attention during this class to struggles over matters of reproduction as we explore historical changes and continuities in reproduction globally since 1900.

courses.name: Public Health in China
courses.description: Examination of China's public health system. Focus on role of government, emerging environmental problems, food safety, and prevalent communicable and non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

courses.name: Traditional Chinese Medicine
courses.description: Introduces traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) principles and methods as they relate to Chinese culture and philosophy, including TCM diagnostics and therapies. Compares and discusses integration of TCM and Western medicine. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

courses.name: Special Topics in Global Health
courses.description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad. Recent courses include Ecology of Infant Feeding, Native American Health, and Public Health and Mental Health in Serbia.

courses.name: Special Topics in Global Health
courses.description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics in Global Health
courses.description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad.
