courses.name: Korean IV: Readings in Korean Literature
courses.description: Reading literature in Korean to further develop literacy skills and understanding of Korean culture and society.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Korean IV: Korean through Movies
courses.description: Through Korean films and documentaries, improving oral and writing proficiency, and gaining the knowledge of Korean history, culture, and society.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Korean IV: Topics in the News
courses.description: Through current news, improving oral and writing profiency and better understanding Korean culture and society.
courses.prereqs: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Korean.

courses.name: Elementary Latin
courses.description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course one of three.

courses.name: Elementary Latin
courses.description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course two of three.

courses.name: Elementary Latin
courses.description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course three of three.

courses.name: Introduction to Latin Literature
courses.description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

courses.name: Introduction to Latin Literature
courses.description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

courses.name: Introduction to Latin Literature
courses.description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

courses.name: Readings in Latin Literature
courses.description: Selected topics and authors including Virgil, Horace, Ovid, Cicero, Tacitus, and Seneca.
courses.prereqs: LATIN 201-3 or consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit with different topics

courses.name: Latin Prose Composition: Advanced Syntax & Composition
courses.description: Rapid review of Latin morphology and basic grammar, followed by careful study of the syntax of Latin prose and by practice in prose composition.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual program of study under the direction of a faculty member. For advanced students only. Permission of department required.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Topics in Latin American and Caribbean Studies
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to significant topics in Latin American and Caribbean studies. Content varies from year to year; may be repeated for credit with a different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics in Latin American and Caribbean Studies
First-Year Seminar
courses.description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College.

courses.name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Studies
courses.description: Introduction to major themes and debates shaping US Latina/o communities, such as history of colonization, diverse ethnicities, debates on immigration, racialization, assimilation, and cultural resistance

courses.name: Introduction to Latina & Latino Cultural Studies
courses.description: Introduction to representations of identity and difference through literary theories and cultural studies. Draws on diverse cultural texts such as literature, popular music, folklore, journalism, media, visual culture, and performance arts.

courses.name: Latina & Latino History
courses.description: History of Latinas/os in the United States and in the context of US-Latin American relations from the 18th century to the present. HISTORY 218-0 and LATINO 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Latina & Latino Youth in U.S. Cities
courses.description: Cultural, social, and political contexts that shape the lives of Latina/o youth in US cities, as well as Latina/o youths' ideas of self-identity and civic engagement.

courses.name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Literature
courses.description: Survey of major writers and movements from Spanish colonial era to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. Taught with ENGLISH 277-0 and SPANISH 277-0; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

courses.name: Latinx Chicago
courses.description: The Chicagoland area has long been a home for Latina/o/x communities. These communities, spanning and spilling beyond city limits, have profoundly shaped life in the Windy City. Drawing on the ever-growing interdisciplinary scholarship on Latinx Chicago, students will explore the local formation of Latinx identities, politics, and cultural production.

courses.name: Latina and Latino Social Movements
courses.description: Histories and ideologies of various US Latina/o social movements. Draws upon historical, ethnographic, autobiographical, and documentary accounts.

courses.name: Topics in Latina and Latino History
courses.description: Historical approach to US Latina/o lives and communities, such as history of Latina/o Chicago, labor history, and immigration. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Topics in Latina and Latino Social and Political Issues
courses.description: Social and political issues affecting US Latina/o communities. May include quantitative or qualitative methods, or both. Topics may include electoral politics, immigration, and race and demography. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation
courses.description: The politics of representation in mainstream and Latina/o media, literature, visual culture, popular music, and performance arts. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Capstone Seminar in Latina & Latino Studies
courses.description: Advanced course synthesizing the state of current research. Questions the boundaries of Latina/o studies. Contextualizes research and topics in relation to other ethnic studies, gender/queer studies, and diaspora studies. Primarily for majors and graduate students.

courses.name: Independent Study in Latina and Latino Studies
courses.description: Reading, research, and/or tutorials for students pursuing projects outside the context of regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Graduate Readings in Latino Studies
courses.description: This readings course in Latino Studies is meant for Ph.D. students across the Weinberg College of Arts and Sciences, and perhaps other schools, within research and teaching interests in the interdisciplinary field of Latino Studies.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Research, reading, and/or writing with faculty member. Permission of faculty member required. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Intro to Organization Theory & Practice
courses.description: Examines major organizational behavior theories and practices through organizational analysis.

courses.name: Culture and Cognition
courses.description: Research and theory on the interrelatedness of culture and thought. Combined with LRN_SCI 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Culture and Cognition: SESP Leadership Institute
courses.description: Research and theory on the interrelatedness of culture and thought. Combined with LRN_SCI 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Introduction to Organizational Learning
courses.description: Looks at perspectives on learning across levels from individuals to groups to organizations.  The goal of the course is to set the foundation for comparing and contrasting different views of learning and making assessments of how each permit us to understand individual and collective processes and outcomes. The course emphasizes explanation, design, and critique through a combination of case analyses, primary empirical research, and project-based learning.

courses.name: Studies in Organizational Change
courses.description: Examines theories and methods of organizational change through analysis of organizational adaptations; applies theories from learning sciences and organizational behavior.

courses.name: Redesigning Everyday Organizations
courses.description: Concepts and methods for understanding and studying cognition and learning and putting these concepts and methods to use in a design/change project. Taught with LRN_SCI 308-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Team Dynamics
courses.description: In this course, we will explore team dynamics, those forces that influence a team's behavior and performance, and what can enhance or hinder potential for impact. We will analyze the contributors to team functioning and their interrelationships at multiple levels: intrapersonal, interpersonal, group and organizational. Key topics include team development, team make-up and roles, leadership and followership, decision-making, navigating conflict, collaboration and competition, effective communication, content vs. process, diversity and in-group/out-group tensions. Throughout the class, students will be analyzing and applying concepts through case studies and simulations. Assignments to demonstrate mastery include regular written individual papers and a team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, Human Development in Context, and related majors throughout Northwestern that are interested in leadership, teams/groups or organizational change. Taught with HDC 309-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Learning Organizations for Complex Environments
courses.description: Major change factors, including technology, globalization, and demographics, and their impact on organizations; how organizations are creating and responding to these changes through organizational design, learning systems, and human resource changes.

courses.name: Tools for Organizational Analysis
courses.description: Understanding cause-and-effect relationships pertaining to organizational behavior and performance.

courses.name: Modern Organization and Innovations
courses.description: Advances in technologies, from computation to analytics to new models of management and organizations, has radically transformed both every day work and classic models of management and organization. This course takes a novel approach to understanding these transformations by partnering a SESP faculty member with industry leaders and change agents to identify and analyze changing organizational forms and the implications for work in the contemporary economy. In doing so, this course will expose students to variants in organizational models, for example, from the highly institutionalized, yet ever changing, digital firm to firm-market hybrids that supply branded service yet do not employ the providers or own the assets that provide services. Students will have weekly analytic assignments that prepare for and reflect on industry co-instructor sessions as well as a final team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, social policy, and related majors throughout northwestern that are interested in leadership or organizational change. This advanced, highly interactive course fulfills new Learning and Organizational Change (LOC) requirements and is open to LOC students and beyond.

courses.name: Learning and Thinking in Organizations
courses.description: Examines how human learning and thinking can facilitate organizational growth and change through methods such as instructional design, modeling, and evaluation of learning outcomes.

courses.name: Psychology of Technology & Instructional Design
courses.description: Introduction to theory and practice in the development of technologies for formal and informal learning in the classroom, workplace, and everyday world.

courses.name: Topics in Learning and Organizational Change
courses.description: Advanced work on special topics.

courses.name: Organizational Planning & Analysis
courses.description: Culminating experience involving application of knowledge and skills to analyze real-world problems and solutions in learning and organizational change.

courses.name: Cognition and Action
courses.description: Perspectives on thinking and learning; how individuals reason and accomplish tasks, both on their own and in interaction with each other and with their immediate environments.

courses.name: Culture, Language, & Identity
courses.description: Social and cultural dimensions of learning, particularly how diverse linguistic and cultural tools mediate forms of identity, learning experiences, and participation in and transformation of social life.

courses.name: Culture and Cognition
courses.description: Explore the cultural ground of cognition. How do cultural environments structure and orient our conceptual knowledge, and how do these cognitive processes feedback into cultural systems? Key topics include conceptual development, knowledge organization, causal reasoning, moral psychology, and environmental psychology. Jointly, the topics are integrated through a focus on social and ecological thought. We will engage in cultural artifact analyses, field experiences, and research inquiries. Combined with LOC 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Design of Learning Environments
courses.description: Conceiving, building, and testing products and services to help people learn. Topics include the human-centered design process, principles for designing learning environments, and agile project management and communication techniques.

courses.name: Social Contexts of Education
courses.description: Societal structures that organize, supply, and channel individual learning experiences and how they provide the formal and informal settings in which social interaction takes place, particularly in urban settings. How participation in these socializing settings molds the development of individuals' capacities and forms their goals. Combined with TEACH_ED 302-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Learning with New Media
courses.description: Examines ways to study and learn from social media spaces and how digital platforms shape presentation of content and information sharing practices.

courses.name: Designing Interactive Media and Technology for Learning
courses.description: Building on theory in the learning sciences and a broad set of multimodal technological tools, students develop and test a collection of learning technologies and examine ways to assess the educational impact of their inventions.

courses.name: Redesigning Everyday Organizations
courses.description: Concepts and methods for understanding and studying cognition and learning and putting these concepts and methods to use in a design/change project. Combined with LOC 308-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Inclusive Making
courses.description: Excitement for the Maker Movement continues to grow. Part of this growth stems from the idea that Making provides a means for democratization of fabrication and invention. While this is true, in part, the practices and people that are typically included under this brand are limited. In particular, issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity are seldom at the forefront of the design and implementation of Makerspaces, the tools used or the artifacts created. Hence, the purpose of this course is to bring issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity to the forefront. In particular, the goals of this course are to push students to 1) critically explore Making as a practice that promotes democratization, 2) develop interfaces that allow a broader population of students to participate in digital fabrication and 3) design artifacts that positively impact accessibility and inclusivity. The course will include guest speakers, laboratory portions and a projects that encourages students to develop publishable scholarship and/or functional prototypes, as they work in interdisciplinary teams. This is a hands-on project course. All students will design and implement interactive technologies. For this reason you will be expected to do computer programming and digital fabrication. However, all projects can be completed in teams. Hence, it is not essential that all students come with prior knowledge in computer programming and digital fabrication. Additionally, a portion of class and office hours will be devoted to helping students gain familiarity in basic digital fabrication and computer programming.

courses.name: Tangible Interaction Design and Learning
courses.description: Explores the use of tangible interaction to create innovative learning experiences, including distributed cognition, embodied interaction, cultural forms, and design frameworks. Combined with COMP_SCI 313-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Learning and Teaching with Technology
courses.description: Theory and practice of designing school environments that integrate new technologies and media. Combined with TEACH_ED 338-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Designing and Constructing Models with Multi-agent Languages
courses.description: Exploration and analysis of multi-agent models, which simulate "emergent" scientific phenomena in a wide variety of content domains. Combined with COMP_SCI 372-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Knowledge Representation for the Learning Sciences
courses.description: Theoretical and methodological techniques for knowledge representation, primarily as practiced by cognitive scientists. Application of these techniques to issues of learning that are of interest to researchers in the learning sciences.

courses.name: Social Dimensions of Teaching & Learning
courses.description: Students' relationships with one another and with teachers in school and nonschool settings. Implications for classroom instruction of social learning theory, student diversity, classroom climate, cooperative and competitive goal structures, and processes of attribution and achievement motivation.

courses.name: Foundations of the Learning Science
courses.description: Cognitive and social science theories of how people learn to understand, reason, and solve problems. Implications for the design of classroom learning environments; learning in real scenarios for investigating central issues in cognitive science. Learning in mathematics, science, reading/writing, and informal reasoning.

courses.name: Methods and Epistemologies for the Study of Learning 1
courses.description: This course focuses on the development of research questions and understanding the range of possible methodological approaches to understanding learning based on those questions.

courses.name: What's the System in Educational Systems
Inclusive Making
courses.description: "Excitement for the Maker Movement continues to grow. Part of this growth stems from the idea that Making provides a means for democratization of fabrication and invention. While this is true, in part, the practices and people that are typically included under this brand are limited. In particular, issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity are seldom at the forefront of the design and implementation of Makerspaces, the tools used or the artifacts created. Hence, the purpose of this course is to bring issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity to the forefront. In particular, the goals of this course are to push students to 1) critically explore Making as a practice that promotes democratization, 2) develop interfaces that allow a broader population of students to participate in digital fabrication and 3) design artifacts that positively impact accessibility and inclusivity. The course will include guest speakers, laboratory portions and a projects that encourages students to develop publishable scholarship and/or functional prototypes, as they work in interdisciplinary teams. This is a hands-on project course. All students will design and implement interactive technologies. For this reason you will be expected to do computer programming and digital fabrication. However, all projects can be completed in teams. Hence, it is not essential that all students come with prior knowledge in computer programming and digital fabrication. Additionally, a portion of class and office hours will be devoted to helping students gain familiarity in basic digital fabrication and computer programming."

courses.name: Quantitative Methods I: Probability and Statistics
Tangible Interaction Design and Learning
courses.description: This course will explore the use of tangible interaction to create innovative learning experiences. It will review both theoretical and technological foundations of the field. Topics include creative expression, embodied interaction, cultural forms, and design frameworks.

courses.name: Field Methods
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the world of qualitative research so that they will be able to read qualitative studies intelligently, and learn to design and conduct qualitatively oriented studies themselves. Beginning with an overview of the epistemological assumptions behind different kinds of research, the course will explore various types of qualitative research approaches and the kinds of topics and queries they support. Students will read and critique examples of published research of various kinds. Next, students will investigate the various methods of collecting qualitative data.  The class is designed so that students simultaneously read about and discuss qualitative research, and gather data themselves.  Although the course touches on analysis, the main focus is on developing a qualitative research project and collecting data for it.

courses.name: Introduction to Design for the Learning Sciences
courses.description: Building the skills and knowledge necessary to support the design of educational experiences. Exploration of general design principles and learning sciences theoretical perspectives through examination of existing cases of instructional design. A design project involving needs analysis, specifying learning objectives, and designing a new educational experience.

courses.name: Design of Technological Tools for Thinking and Learning
Design of Learning Environments
courses.description: Issues in designing and studying innovative learning environments. New models of classroom interaction, particularly using technology to enable new cognitive and social roles for students. Topics include simulations, tutors, computer-mediated communication, project-based learning. Theoretical motivations in cognitive and social-interaction learning theories, empirical studies evaluating their effectiveness, and prospects for propagation of such innovations.

courses.name: Teacher Thinking & Learning
courses.description: Recent research on teacher cognition, how teacher knowledge is organized and accessed, and relationship between knowledge and practices. Investigate novice and veteran teachers learning

courses.name: Teaching with Technology
courses.description: Conceptual strategies for integrating technology into effective pedagogy and practical strategies for employing technology in classrooms. Includes hands-on experience with technology and a design project.

courses.name: Educational Policy: Design, Implementation and Effects
courses.description: Introduction to issues in educational reform. Analyzing educational reform; framing educational policy problems; examining reformers' assumptions about the school system, about the roles of school in society, and about teaching and learning. The course is grounded in school decentralization, systemic reform and school choice.

courses.name: Topics in Learning Sciences
courses.description: Discussion of trends in the field of Learning Sciences via articles and other resources.

courses.name: Constructionism Seminar
courses.description: Discussion of trends in the field of Learning Sciences via articles and other resources.

courses.name: Topics in Research Methods
courses.description: Methodological approaches to research on learning- teaching environment implementation. Methods for examining processes of change and adoption of educational interventions in various settings. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Designing and Constructing Models With Multi-Agent Languages
courses.description: Contact the department for further information.

courses.name: Philosophical & Historical Foundations of Education Reform
courses.description: How influential root metaphors for the learner, knowledge, and learning processes become embodied in educational technologies, and how the sociocultural context of their design and use influences their appropriation or rejection.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Research
courses.description: Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit. - SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Education Sciences Research Practicum in the Schools
First-Year Seminar
courses.description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College; can satisfy at most 1 credit towards major or minor requirements in Legal Studies.

courses.name: Law and Society
courses.description: Introduction to the role of law in American society and the influence of society on law. Courts, the legal profession, law enforcement, inequality, and social change. Taught with SOCIOL 206-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Legal Studies Research Methods
courses.description: Introduction to research methodologies used in interdisciplinary legal studies, including jurisprudence and legal reasoning, qualitative and quantitative social science methods, and historical and textual analysis. LEGAL_ST 207-0 and SOCIOL 227-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Legal Studies
courses.description: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Legal Studies
courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: American Immigration
courses.description: Themes in history of immigration, especially from Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Law, racial formation, acculturation, transnational and international contexts, competing notions of citizenship. HISTORY 305-0 and LEGAL_ST 305-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Sociology of Law
courses.description: Sociological analysis of legal institutions such as courts, the police, and lawyers. Law, inequality, and social change. Taught with SOCIOL 318-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Political Theories of the Rule of Law
courses.description: Key documents and debates in the development of theories of law and jurisprudence. From Aeschylus to contemporary democratic and legal theories and major court cases on topics ranging from torture to Title IX. POLI_SCI 309-0 and LEGAL_ST 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Corporation in US Law and Culture
courses.description: Tracing the evolution of the corporate person in the United States from the colonial era to the present: both the evolving legal rights and responsibilities of the corporation and the role that corporations have played in the American cultural imagination.

courses.name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: Colonial Period to 1850
courses.description: Colonial period - 1850. Development of legal institutions, constitutionalism, law and social change, law and economic development. Taught with HISTORY 318-1; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: Since 1850
courses.description: 1850 - present. Law in industrial society: administration, race relations, corporations, environmental protection, civil liberties. Taught with HISTORY 318-2; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The Fourteenth Amendment
courses.description: The Fourteenth Amendment's role in defining and protecting citizenship, privileges and immunities, due process, and equal protection from its nineteenth-century origins to the present. HISTORY 320-0 and LEGAL_ST 320-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: U.S. Refugee Policy & Localities
courses.description: Comparative understandings of refugee policies in liberal democracies and their relation to constitutional and human rights. Street level bureaucracy, constitutional governance, federalism, integration, refugee resettlement policy, citizenship and belonging.  POLI_SCI 330-0 and LEGAL_ST 330-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Politics of the Supreme Court
courses.description: Operation of appellate courts, with emphasis on the US Supreme Court. Decision making by appellate courts and the development of public policy.
courses.prereqs: POLI_SCI 220-0 or POLI_SCI 230-0. LEGAL_ST 331-0 and POLI_SCI 331-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses

courses.name: Constitutional Law I
courses.description: Introduction to interpretation of the US Constitution by the Supreme Court. Judicial review, federalism, congressional and executive authority, separation of powers. Taught with POLI_SCI 332-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Constitutional Law II: Civil and Political Rights
courses.description: Consideration of US Supreme Court decisions dealing with civil and political rights, including equality, freedom of speech, and freedom of religion. LEGAL_ST 333-0 and POLI_SCI 333-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and the Law
courses.description: Examination of the changing role of law in governing gender and sexual relations in America. Legal definitions of gender and sexuality in the household, the marketplace, and the state. GNDR_ST 340-0 and LEGAL_ST 340-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: International Organizations
courses.description: Institutions that govern the interactions of states, including the WTO, UN, ICJ, and ICC; informal norms, such as international intervention, international criminal law, and sovereignty. POLI_SCI 342-0 and LEGAL_ST 342-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Comparative Race & Ethnicity
courses.description: Comparative history of Latinos, Asian Americans, African Americans, and white ethnics in the 20th century United States; role of law, politics, and society in shaping and being shaped by racial and ethnic categories.

courses.name: Race, Politics, and the Law
courses.description: Current role of race and racism from multiple disciplinary perspectives. Application to contemporary legal and political issues. How law deals with racial inequality. LEGAL_ST 348-0 and SOCIOL 348-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.
courses.prereqs: LEGAL_ST 206-0, SOCIOL 206-0, SOCIOL 208-0, LEGAL_ST 308-0, or SOCIOL 318-0

courses.name: Psychology and the Law
courses.description: Examines the application of psychology to law, including topics such as the insanity defense, criminal profiling, eyewitness testimony, and interrogation. Taught with PSYCH 340-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Constitutional Challenges in Comparative Perspective
courses.description: Constitutional controversies and resolutions in liberal democracies. Constitutional traditions and governance, rule of law, legitimacy and authority in diverse societies, human rights, social transformation. POLI_SCI 356-0 and LEGAL_ST 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Topics in Legal Studies
courses.description: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Topics in Legal Studies
courses.description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Refugee Crises and Human Rights
courses.description: Development of international human rights. Comparative state and regional responses to forced migration due to war, conflict, and generalized violence. Humanitarian intervention, international law, and policy issues, such as gender-based violence, migrants at sea, and human trafficking. POLI_SCI 380-0 and LEGAL_ST 380-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Children and the Law
courses.description: Examines from a developmental perspective research on children's involvement in the legal system as decision makers, witnesses, victims, and perpetrators. Taught with PSYCH 381-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Professional Linkage Seminar
courses.description: Varied legal topics taught by practitioners. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Advanced Research Seminar 1
courses.description: Exposure to theoretical and empirical approaches to the study of law and legal institutions in society; preparation of original thesis. Consecutive enrollment required in LEGAL_ST 398-2.
courses.prereqs: LEGAL_ST 207-0 and acceptance to program as major

courses.name: Advanced Research Seminar 2
courses.description: Preparation and presentation of original thesis.
courses.prereqs: LEGAL_ST 398-1 within the same academic year

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Readings and conferences on special subjects for students pursuing a specific area of interest in legal studies.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Readings and conferences on special subjects for graduate students pursuing a specific area of interest in legal studies.

courses.name: Language and Society
courses.description: Introduction to linguistic variation and change from a variety of perspectives on social processes. How language can be connected with social group membership and viewed as a tool used in social practice to construct identity. These issues are explored through the quantitative analysis of linguistic variation in a social context.

courses.name: Language and Prejudice
courses.description: Exploration of attitudes toward different accents, dialects, and speech styles in the US context. The relation between language and thought; how language may reflect or reinforce prejudice. Introduction to methods in linguistic research.

courses.name: Language, Politics, and Identity
courses.description: Role of language in constructing, preserving, and manipulating political and national identities. Topics include language discrimination, linguistic nationalism, language and religion, alphabet issues, dialect issues. Regional content varies. LING 222-0 and SLAVIC 222-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Language and Gender
courses.description: Exploration of socially and linguistically significant differences in the language used by/about/to men and women, focusing on the role of language in constructing gender as part of local communities of practice. Taught with GNDR_ST 234-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Sound Patterns in Human Language
courses.description: Introduction to phonetics and phonology. Description and classification of speech sounds in terms of articulation, acoustics, and perception. Similarities and differences of sound patterns across languages. Introduction to speech technology.

courses.name: Formal Analysis of Words & Sentences
courses.description: Formal structure of words (morphology) and sentences (syntax) in natural language. Biological basis of human language.

courses.name: Meaning
courses.description: How information is encoded in words and sentences and how speakers and listeners use language to communicate.

courses.name: Topics in Linguistics
courses.description: Topics in linguistic theory. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Experimental Sociolinguistics
courses.description: Experimental approaches to the social meaning of language. Discussion of sociolinguistic research questions best suited to the use of experimental methods. Investigation of theoretical and methodological contributions of experimental work to sociolinguistic theory. Social inferences based on language, social expectations’ influence on linguistic perception, roles of experiences, stereotypes and attitudes on language, awareness and control in sociolinguistic perception.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics; graduate standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Experimental Approaches to Word Form Processing
courses.description: Experimental techniques and theoretical models for analyzing perception and production of spoken and written word forms. Access to the mental lexicon in perception and production.

courses.name: Experimental Syntax
courses.description: Experimental methodologies and theories of sentence comprehension. Studies of syntactic structures in sentence comprehension.

courses.name: Experimental Pragmatics
courses.description: Experimental methodologies for analyzing the role of context in utterance production and comprehension. Taught with PSYCH 460-0.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics or consent of instructor

courses.name: Sociolinguistics
courses.description: Overview of classic and contemporary work in sociolinguistics. How quantitative methods in linguistics can be coupled with social theoretic insights to engage questions in linguistic variation and change, stylistic practice, how language reflects, reinforces, or contests social inequalities.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics; graduate standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Bilingualism
courses.description: Cognitive, linguistic, neuroscientific, and computational aspects of the acquisition, representation, and processing of two or more languages in an individual's mind/brain.

courses.name: Language & Sexuality
courses.description: The use of language to construct sexual identity, focusing on the language of and about gay men and lesbians. Topics include heteronormativity, identity labels and categories, gender versus sexuality, and cross-cultural sexual diversity. Taught with GNDR_ST 327-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics or consent of instructor

courses.name: Research Methods in Linguistics
courses.description: Methods of linguistic data collection, management, and analysis with an emphasis on the use of computational, experimental, and statistical methods.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics, graduate standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Introduction to Computational Linguistics
courses.description: Hands-on introduction to computational methods in empirical linguistic analysis and natural language processing.
courses.prereqs: Basic programming experience is required, at the level of at least LING 300-0 (Intro to Text Processing and Programming for Linguists) or COMP_SCI 110-0 (Intro to Computer Programming)

courses.name: Language Typology
courses.description: A comparison of varying and universal features of the world's languages.

courses.name: Structure of Various Languages
courses.description: Phonological, morphological, or syntactic structure of a particular language. May be repeated for credit with change in language.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Laboratory Phonology
courses.description: Sound patterns of diverse languages and their expression in articulatory and acoustic phonetics. Syllable structure, phonotactics, morpho-phonological alternation, stress. Fundamentals of laboratory methods and the quantitative analysis of speech data.
courses.prereqs: any 200-level Linguistics course or consent of instructor

courses.name: Fundamentals of Syntax
courses.description: Fundamental principles of theoretical syntax. Phrase structure, argument structure, movement operations. Emphasis on argumentation, hypothesis formation and testing, and analytic methods.

courses.name: Making a Dictionary: The Northwestern Project
courses.description: Creation of an online dictionary of Northwestern jargon, slang, etc. Learning about the connection between language, society, and identity; sociolinguistic fieldwork; lexicography; politics of dictionaries; culture and power of book form vs. digital. LING 363-0 and SLAVIC 322-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Meaning
courses.description: Theoretical approaches to the study of linguistic meaning. Topics include word meaning, argument and event structure, sentence meaning, truth conditions, and inference types (e.g., entailment, implicature, presupposition).

courses.name: Reference
courses.description: Linguistic and philosophical approaches to the study of reference, focusing on the role of context in the use and interpretation of referring expressions. Topics include definiteness, common ground, genericity, deixis, and anaphora. Taught with PHIL 353-0.
courses.prereqs: any 200 level course in linguistics, a course in philosophy of language, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Pragmatics
courses.description: Introduction to extra-semantic meaning, focusing on the role of context in utterance production and interpretation. Topics include the semantics-pragmatics boundary, implicature, presupposition, speech acts, reference, and information structure.

courses.name: Implicature
courses.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the study of extra-semantic meaning, drawing on primary readings from linguistics, philosophy, and psychology. Topics include conversational and conventional implicature, explicature, impliciture, and the semantics-pragmatics boundary.

courses.name: Spoken English for Nonnative Speakers
courses.description: Conversational English addressing all oral language skills; primarily for international graduate students who are nonnative speakers of English. Content varies.

courses.name: Written English for Nonnative Speakers
courses.description: Written argumentation skills and all aspects of academic writing; primarily for international graduate students who are nonnative speakers of English.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Linguistics
courses.description: By invitation of the department. For students of superior ability, with choice of topic left to the group.

courses.name: Seminar in Linguistics
courses.description: Theoretical issues of current concern to linguistics. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Sociolinguistic Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Foundations of sociolinguistic theory and analysis. How quantitative study of linguistic variation can be coupled with social theory to engage questions in linguistic variation and change, indexicality and social meaning, stylistic practice, language and identities, language socialization, multi-modality of communication, and how language reflects, reinforces, or contests social inequalities.

courses.name: Laboratory Phonology I
courses.description: Sounds and sound patterns of human languages examined in terms of their cognitive representations, physical expression in speech articulation and perception, and in the cognitive processing of spoken words and phrases in speech production and perception. Topics considered from contemporary theoretical and experimental perspectives.
courses.prereqs: LING 250-0 or equivalent, or permission of instructor

courses.name: Proseminar in Sound Structure
courses.description: Detailed study of a particular empirical issue (e.g., intonation, syllable structure) or theory (e.g., Optimality Theory, Articulatory Phonology) in phonology/phonetics.

courses.name: Seminar in Sound Structure
courses.description: Advanced topics in phonological theory.

courses.name: Syntactic Analysis I
courses.description: Formal syntactic analysis within generative grammar, focusing on universal and language-specific properties, argumentation. Topics include phrase structure, sentential complementation, anaphora, island constraints, and the lexicon.

courses.name: Syntactic Analysis II
courses.description: Continuation of LING 460-1.

courses.name: Proseminar in Syntax
courses.description: Detailed study of a particular empirical issue (e.g., clause structure, ellipsis, pronoun/antecedent relations) or theory (e.g., the Minimalist Program, Lexical-Functional Grammar) in syntax.

courses.name: Seminar in Syntax
courses.description: Advanced topics in syntactic theory.

courses.name: Semantic Analysis I
courses.description: Formal analysis of linguistic meaning,with a focus on compositional and contextual aspects of interpretation. Topics include the syntax-semantics interface, quantification, intensionality, anaphora, and dynamic semantics.

courses.name: Proseminar in Semantics
courses.description: Detailed study of a particular empirical issue (e.g., presupposition, quantification, aspect, conditionals) or theory (e.g., dynamic semantics, discourse representation theory) in semantics/pragmatics.

courses.name: Seminar in Semantics
courses.description: Focused study of current issues in formal semantics and their implications for linguistic theory.

courses.name: Seminar in Pragmatics
courses.description: Advanced topics in pragmatic theory.

courses.name: American Academic Culture for Non-Native speakers of English
courses.description: This course explores effective academic communication in the American undergraduate classroom through observation, analysis, and practice.  The emphasis is on developing students' oral English proficiency while preparing them for success as instructors and teaching assistants.  Students will explore communication skills such as: effective lecturing/presenting, leading classroom discussions, leading in-class activities, and presenting administrative information to students.  More generally, students in this course will receive guidance in preparing for The Graduate School's live teaching demonstration assessment.  Those who earn a "satisfactory" grade in the course will be eligible to participate in this demonstration, which is one means of fulfilling The Graduate School's English proficiency requirement.

courses.name: Individual Speech and Language Instruction for Nonnative Speakers of English
courses.description: Individualized language instruction: one-on-one appointments with an instructor to support the learner’s ability to communicate effectively in English in academic and everyday contexts.

courses.name: Supported Online Speech Training for Nonnative Speakers of English
courses.description: Supported online speech and language training is provided through individual work with various software applications for language learning, and is supported by optional in-person drop-in sessions and feedback from the instructor.

courses.name: Applied Linguistics for English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course provides a theoretical and practical knowledge base for teaching English as a second or foreign language. Students will first read and discuss research from the fields of second language acquisition, applied linguistics, and second language pedagogy to become conversant with present and past issues in the field. Students will learn best practices for assessment of second language skills and create course plans for differentiated instruction in individual and group settings, using their own teaching materials and approach. They will observe group classes; lead discussions on current applied linguistics research; complete linguistic analysis and learning goals for individual adult English language learners; apply and present linguistic and pedagogical theory for presentation to non-linguists; develop and conduct group activities. During the SPEAK training sessions and lab sessions, students will become trained to rate English proficiency using the SPEAK test.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Research Seminar
courses.description: Forum for presenting and discussing student research; for second-year graduate students in linguistics working on the research paper requirement. Pass/no-credit registration required.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS

courses.name: Pricing
courses.description: Comparison of the three main ways to set prices-haggling/negotiation, posted price, and auctions. How to choose the best method in a given situation. Customizing the price of the same product or service to different segments, using optimization models to set prices when volume is uncertain, pricing multiple products. Introduction to techniques for gathering information about buyer valuations and demands, including regression, conjoint analysis, and enterprise value creation.

courses.name: Operations and Supply Chain Management
courses.description: Management of business processes-i.e., a firm's recurring activities. Challenges facing operations managers; the language, concepts, insights, and tools needed to gain competitive advantage through operations and supply chains; different strategies for different processes and supply chain structures, and the operational capabilities allowing and supporting them.

courses.name: Topics in Managerial Analytics
courses.description: In-depth examination of selected issues in managerial analytics; topic varies each year.

courses.name: Competitive Strategy and Industrial Structure
courses.description: The course studies the determinants nature of competitive strategy in a variety of industry structures.

courses.name: MS & E Freshman Seminar
courses.description: Laboratory-oriented, with research projects emphasizing use of the scanning electron microscope and other modern apparatus; correlation of structure with other properties of materials. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.name: Introduction to Materials
courses.description: Introduction to atomic and molecular organization in solids, with emphasis on structure-property relations in ceramics, electronic materials, metals, and polymers. Not to be taken for credit with or after MAT_SCI 301-0.

courses.name: Materials Science Principles
courses.description: Bonding, crystal structure, and defects in solids. Phase diagrams in condensed matter systems. Equilibrium and non-equilibrium development of microstructures. Processing/structure/property/performance relationships underlying behavior of metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. Mechanical, electrical, and chemical properties of engineering materials.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 131-0, CHEM 151-0, or CHEM 171-0; major in materials science and engineering or chemical and biological engineering

courses.name: Introduction to Materials Laboratories
courses.description: Labs related to: Bonding, crystal structure and defects in solids. Phase diagrams in condensed matter systems. Equilibrium and nonequilibrium development of microstructures. Processing/structure/property/performance relationships underlying behavior of metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. Mechanical, electrical, chemical properties of engineering materials. To be taken with MAT_SCI 301-0.

courses.name: Thermodynamics of Materials
courses.description: Classical and statistical thermodynamics; entropy and energy functions in liquid and solid solutions, and their applications to phase equilibria. Lectures, problem solving. Materials science and engineering degree candidates may not receive credit for 314 with or after CHEM 342-1.
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132-0, CHEM 152-0, or CHEM 172-0; MATH 228-1 or MATH 230-1; or PHYSICS 135-1 or equivalent

courses.name: Phase Equilibria & Diffusion of Materials
courses.description: Application of thermodynamics to ternary phase equilibria. Defects and diffusion in solids. Interdiffusion. Short-circuit diffusion. Defects and transport in ionic solids. Lectures, problem solving.

courses.name: Microstructural Dynamics
courses.description: Principles underlying development of microstructures. Defects, diffusion, phase transformations, nucleation and growth, thermal and mechanical treatment of materials. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.name: Microstructural Dynamics
courses.description: Principles underlying development of microstructures. Defects, diffusion, phase transformations, nucleation and growth, thermal and mechanical treatment of materials. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.name: Materials Selection
courses.description: Methods of specifying materials and the processes for making them in the context of a given application. Service performance of materials based on their physical and chemical properties. Case studies and use of high-level databases.

courses.name: Soft Materials
courses.description: Different kinds of polymeric materials. Relationships between structure and physical properties; rubber elasticity, the glassy state, crystallinity in polymers. Lectures, laboratory.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 301-0 or equivalent; MAT_SCI 314-0 or CHEM 342-1; MAT_SCI 316-1 and MAT_SCI 316-2 highly recommended

courses.name: Mechanical Behavior of Solids
courses.description: Plastic deformation and fracture of metals, ceramics, and polymeric materials; structure/property relations. Role of imperfections, state of stress, temperatures, strain rate. Lectures, laboratory.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 316-1; MAT_SCI 316-2 (may be taken concurrently); CIV_ENV 216-0 or consent of instructor

courses.name: Chemical Synthesis of Materials
courses.description: The design of materials targeting important properties through processes that break and form primary chemical bonds. Fundamental principles and main methodologies, including polymerization, biosynthesis, self-assembly, solgel reactions, synthesis of nanomaterials, vapor-phase synthesis, and composite synthesis.
courses.prereqs: junior standing in materials science and engineering or consent of instructor

courses.name: Conducting Polymers
courses.description: Fundamentals and applications of conducting polymers. Hands-on experience in synthesizing conducting polymer nanostructures.

courses.name: Ceramic Processing
courses.description: Steps in production of fired ceramic articles. Powder preparation and characterization, compact formation, slip casting, extrusion and injection molding; firing, liquid-phase and solid-state sintering. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.name: Introductory Physics of Materials
courses.description: Quantum mechanics; applications to materials and engineering. Band structures and cohesive energy; thermal behavior; electrical conduction; semiconductors; amorphous semiconductors; magnetic behavior of materials; liquid crystals. Lectures, laboratory, problem solving.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 301-0 or equivalent or consent of instructor; GEN_ENG 205-4 or equivalent; PHYSICS 135-2, PHYSICS 135-3; MAT_SCI 351-1 is prerequisite for MAT_SCI 351-2

courses.name: Introductory Physics of Materials
courses.description: Quantum mechanics; applications to materials and engineering. Band structures and cohesive energy; thermal behavior; electrical conduction; semiconductors; amorphous semiconductors; magnetic behavior of materials; liquid crystals. Lectures, laboratory, problem solving.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 301-0 or equivalent or consent of instructor; GEN_ENG 205-4 or equivalent; PHYSICS 135-2, PHYSICS 135-3; MAT_SCI 351-1 is prerequisite for MAT_SCI 351-2

courses.name: Bioelectronics
courses.description: Development and design of sensors, stimulators, and their medical devices for biointegrated electronics. Materials design and fabrication of passive and active components for sensitive, multimodal, and robust wearable and implantable devices.

courses.name: Bioelectronics Lab
courses.description: Laboratories focused on the practical implementation, instrumentation, and fabrication of wearables and skinsensing. Applications range from vital sign monitoring to rehabilitation.

courses.name: Electronic Materials
courses.description: Principles, models, and characterization of semiconductor materials. Crystal growth and doping. Diffusion, epitaxy, and monolithic processes. Current transport, non-equilibrium processes, thin films, low-mobility materials, and interfaces.

courses.name: Nanomagnetic Materials for Information Storage
courses.description: Overview of materials used for magnetic data storage and of the recording and read processes. Information storage systems, such as optical, solid-state, and probe. Theoretical background for understanding the four energy terms that control the properties of magnetic materials when they are patterned at the nanoscale.

courses.name: Modeling and Simulation in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.description: The course covers the essential methods and principles for modeling and simulating the structure, properties, and behavior of materials. It focuses on constructing models and identifying approaches to test either theoretical descriptions or experimental observations of materials phenomena on a computer. The course balances breadth versus depth of topics with the goal of producing researchers literate in computational materials science and its applicability across different length scales. Students will construct structure-property models of atomic assemblies, molecules, and solids using first-principles electronic structure (such as density-functional theory), deterministic (molecular dynamics), statistical methods (Monte Carlo and (Un)Supervised Learning), and finite elements models. Computational laboratories will give students extensive hands-on experience with several powerful modern materials modeling codes.

courses.name: Introduction to Electron Microscopy
courses.description: Theories and practice involved in application of scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy. Lectures, laboratory. Primarily for undergraduates and for graduate students in other departments.

courses.name: Crystallography & Diffraction
courses.description: Elementary crystallography. Basic diffraction theory; reciprocal space. Applications to structure analysis, preferred orientation. Film and counter techniques. Lectures, laboratory.

courses.name: Biomaterials
courses.description: Introduction to biomaterials from a materials science perspective, focusing on synthesis, structure, and properties. Materials used for human repair (permanent implants, devices, materials for drug delivery, tissue-engineering scaffolds); naturally occurring and engineered materials synthesized through biotechnology; biomimetic materials that copy microstructures from nature. May not receive credit for both MAT_SCI 370-0 and BMD_ENG 343-0.

courses.name: Biominerals: Hierarchical Architecture & Function
courses.description: How biologically based processing of mineralorganic composites used by living organisms inspires new approaches to materials synthesis in many critical applications-locomotion (bones), defense (shells), and sensing (light, acceleration, magnetic fields).
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 316-2 or equivalent, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Nanomaterials
courses.description: Introduction to structure-property relationships of materials processed at the nanometer scale. Highly interdisciplinary course appropriate for undergraduate and graduate students in other departments.

courses.name: Intro Surface Science & Spectroscopy
courses.description: Surface spectroscopy, including Auger spectroscopy, photoemission, and LEED. Surface dynamics and thermodynamics. Electronic properties of surfaces and interfaces. Gas-surface interactions.

courses.name: Materials for Energy-Efficient Technology
courses.description: A materials science approach to the challenges of energy efficient technology: energy content of materials; advanced materials for energy harvesting, transmission, storage, and conversion; materials for energy efficient transportation and housing. Term paper and oral presentation.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 201-0, MAT_SCI 301-0, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Electrochemical Energy Materials and Devices
courses.description: Thermodynamics and kinetics of electrochemical processes. Materials for fuel cells, batteries, and electrochemical capacitors, including electrolytes and electrodes. Electrical and mass transport. Effect of microstructure. Electrochemical characterization. Device configurations.
courses.prereqs: senior standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Electronic and Thermal Properties of Materials
courses.description: Thermoelectric Devices. Solid-state electronic structure from a solid-state chemistry perspective, phonons in complex materials, electronic and thermal transport at room temperature and above (semi-classical) of metals, semiconductors and some insulators. Familiarity with quantum mechanics and the concept of density-of-states for electrons and phonons. MAT_SCI 351-1 or equivalent is recommended but not required.

courses.name: Solar Energy Conversion
courses.description: This course will focus on the design, fabrication, and manufacturing of the next generation solar cells. Topics include: basic principle of cell operation; how charge transport, exciton diffusion, and plasmonic fields can affect cell efficiency; the importance of interfaces between dissimilar materials in optimizing cell performance; internal cell photon management; how to synthesize, fabricate and characterize complex nanostructure materials; protect intellectual properties; and design manufacturing capacity for marketing.
courses.prereqs: senior standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Materials Design
courses.description: Analysis and control of microstructures. Quantitative process/structure/property/performance relations, with case studies. Computer lab for modeling multicomponent thermodynamics and transformation kinetics.
courses.prereqs: MAT_SCI 315-0, MAT_SCI 316-1, MAT_SCI 316-2, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Process Design
courses.description: Processing of materials. Design and analysis of experiments to identify and optimize key parameters to control properties and performance. Resolving conflicting requirements. Statistical process control.

courses.name: Honors Project in Materials Science
courses.description: Independent study and/or research linked to MAT_SCI 396-1 and MAT_SCI 396-2. Comprehensive report on a specific area of modern materials science and engineering.

courses.name: Special Topics in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Senior Project in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.description: To be taken in two consecutive quarters. Independent basic or applied research project, conceived and performed under the direction of a department faculty member.
courses.prereqs: senior standing in the materials science and engineering or materials science program

courses.name: Senior Project in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.description: To be taken in two consecutive quarters. Independent basic or applied research project, conceived and performed under the direction of a department faculty member.
courses.prereqs: senior standing in the materials science and engineering or materials science program

courses.name: Special Topics in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.description: Special Topics in Materials Science and Engineering; laboratory emphasis.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Individual problems, including library and design work; comprehensive report on a specific phase of modern materials science. Credit to be arranged.

courses.name: Chemical & Statistical Thermodynamics of Materials
courses.description: Chemical thermodynamics via analytical and statistical approaches, including chemical potentials, conditions for equilibrium, distribution functions, ideal and regular solutions, and phase diagrams. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Structure of Crystalline and Noncrystalline Materials
courses.description: Descriptors of material structure for crystalline and noncrystalline materials. Constitutive relationships described by tensors of rank 1 to 4. Classes of materials. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Imperfections in Materials
courses.description: Point, line, and planar imperfections in metals and ionic and semiconducting crystals. Diffusion. Interactions between crystal imperfections. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Physics of Solids
courses.description: Reciprocal lattice representation, diffraction, Brillouin zone construction, bonding, lattice vibrations, phonon dispersion, and energy band structure of solids. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Mechanical Properties of Materials
courses.description: Stress and strain tensors, piezoelectricity, elasticity, low- and high-temperature deformation of crystalline and non-crystalline materials, fatigue, and fracture. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Phase Transformations in Materials
courses.description: Surfaces and interfaces, thermodynamics of phase transformations, nucleation, growth of precipitates, coarsening, and spinodal decomposition. Graduate core course.

courses.name: Phase Transformations in Crystalline Materials
courses.description: Advanced treatment of order-disorder transformations, spinodal ordering, effects of stress on transformations, and displacive transformations.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Thin Film Materials
courses.description: Vapor-phase film deposition techniques, adsorption, nucleation mechanisms, selective deposition, structure-zone diagrams, epitaxy, and composition.

courses.name: Kinetics
courses.description: Principles of Irreversible Thermodynamics; Driving Forces and Fluxes; Diffusion in the Presence of Stress; Diffusion Resulting from other Gradients; Diffusion Resulting from Discrete Jumps; Diffusion in Crystals; Diffusion Controlled versus Source/Sink Controlled Kinetics; Surface Rearrangements by Evaporation and Condensation; Coarsening of Microstructures due to Capillary Forces; Growth of Phases in Concentration Gradients; Growth of Phases in Thermal Gradients; Evaporation of Metal Crystals; Vapor-Liquid-Solid (VLS) Growth Mechanism of the Growth of Nanowires

courses.name: High Temperature Materials
courses.description: Current research fields such as environmental effects on mechanical behavior at elevated temperatures, advanced instrumentation, advanced techniques, and surface interactions.

courses.name: Organic Nanomaterials
courses.description: The materials science and chemistry of soft nanomaterials for myriadapplications including nanomedicine. Preparative and synthetic approachesto organized, assembled, discrete nanomaterials will be described. Coursewill include an in depth discussion of advanced characterization techniquesand strategies for this class of material.

courses.name: Special Topics in Advanced Polymer Science
courses.description: Topics include application of statistical mechanics, morphology and crystallinity, spectroscopy, flow theory and molecular motion, and statistical theories of polymer composition and structure.

courses.name: Advanced Physics of Materials
courses.description: Energy bands in solids, electronic conduction processes, dielectric properties, optical properties, semiconductors, magnetism, superconductivity, artificial structures, and amorphous materials.

courses.name: Selected Topics in the Solid State
courses.description: Topics include electrical and optical properties of solids, magnetic properties, theory of solids, and phase transformations.

courses.name: Solid State Physics of Nanomaterials
courses.description: Electrical , optical and magnetic properties of reduced-dimensional materials and nanostructures

courses.name: Functional Metamaterials
courses.description: Ordered composite materials with properties distinct from those of the component building blocks. Structure-property relationships for designing metamaterials with electronic, optical, magnetic, and thermal functionality.

courses.name: Atomic Scale Computational Materials Science
courses.description: Theory and application of atomic-scale computational materials tools to model, understand, and predict the properties of real materials

courses.name: Electron Microscopy
courses.description: Electron optics. Kinematic and dynamical theory of electron diffraction. Introduction to microanalysis.

courses.name: Diffraction Methods in Material Science
courses.description: Advanced theory of diffraction. Diffraction effects accompanying imperfections. Thermal motion, cold-work, formation of solid solutions, transformations, liquids, gases, dynamic scattering.

courses.name: Advanced Electron Microscopy & Diffraction
courses.description: Theories of electron diffraction; theories of diffraction contrast and their application to lattice disorder; phase transformation. Current topics in electron and other charged-particle microscopy.

courses.name: Analytical Electron Microscopy
courses.description: Diversity of analytical techniques in modern TEM, fundamental concepts in quantitative x-ray, EELS, CBED microanalysis, advanced AEM instrumentation, techniques and applications to physical and life sciences.

courses.name: Materials Biology
courses.description: This class is addressed at graduate students with background in Engineering, Chemistry, and Physics, who want to acquire a working knowledge of key concepts in Biochemistry, Molecular, Cell and Developmental Biology. We will read both classical papers and modern literature, drilling down to the essentials hidden behind cryptic acronyms and exotic-sounding techniques. We will primarily work with literature that has relevance to Materials Science, in particular bio-inspired materials, but will also consider suggestions submitted by participants.

courses.name: Electrochemistry for Energy Storage and Conversion
courses.description: This course will focus on Thermodynamics and kinetics of ion and electron transport in solids, with emphasis on processes in electrolyte and electrode materials used in energy storage and conversion. Treatment of electroanalytical characterization techniques including a.c. impedance spectroscopy, voltammetry and d.c. polarization methods. Application areas include fuel cells, electrochemical gas separation membranes, batteries, supercapacitors, and hydrogen storage materials.

courses.name: Electronic and Thermal Properties of Materials
courses.description: Solid-state electronic structure from a solid-sate chemistry perspective.

courses.name: Solar Energy Conversion
courses.description: This course will focus on the design, fabrication, and manufacturing of the next generation solar cells. Topics include: basic principle of cell operation; how charge transport, exciton diffusion, and plasmonic fields can affect cell efficiency; the importance of interfaces between dissimilar materials in optimizing cell performance; internal cell photon management; how to synthesize, fabricate and characterize complex nanostructure materials; protect intellectual properties; and design manufacturing capacity for marketing.
courses.prereqs: senior standing or consent of instructor

courses.name: Advanced Special Topics in Material Science
courses.description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

courses.name: Projects
courses.description: Individual problems, including library or experimental work with a comprehensive report on some specific phase of materials science. PERMISSIONS OF INSTRUCTOR AND DEPARTMENT REQUIRED.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics may be suggested by students or faculty, with the approval of the department.

courses.name: Research
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS - Independent investigation of selected problems pertaining to thesis or dissertation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: MS Thesis Research
courses.description: Research corresponding to MS thesis work for BS/MS students.

courses.name: Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr
courses.description: Intermediate microeconomics.

courses.name: Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr
courses.description: Game theory.

courses.name: Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr
courses.description: Formal models in social science disciplines other than economics.

courses.name: Foundations of Mathematical Social Science
courses.description: Introduction to the core mathematical elements of formal Social Science, including Individual Decision Making, Choice Under Uncertainty, Social Choice and Welfare, Efficiency Concepts, and Dynamic Decision-Making.

courses.name: Algebra
courses.description: Overview of core mathematical concepts that permeate business, science and everyday life. Primary focus is on mathematical tools needed in a variety of degree programs. Topics include: functions and graphs, linear, polynomial and rational equations, inequalities and their applications, modeling, variation, and systems of equations.  This course does not count for credit if taken after any higher mathematics course. May not be audited.

courses.name: Introduction to Mathematics
courses.description: Exploration of the beauty of mathematics through a study of the patterns and properties of the natural numbers. Topics include counting, probability, prime numbers, the Euclidean algorithm, and unique factorization. For students with minimal mathematical background. Students may not receive credit for MATH 110-0 after completing a 200-level MATH course or higher.

courses.description: NPEP course.

courses.name: Precalculus Mathematics
courses.description: Properties and graphs of the basic functions: polynomial, rational, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric. Complex numbers, theory of equations, and selected topics are also included.  May not be audited.

courses.name: Finite Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics from elementary linear algebra and its applications, finite probability, and elementary statistics. For students majoring in the behavioral sciences.

courses.name: Finite Mathematics
courses.description: Foundation of mathematical knowledge targeting data analysis. Topics chosen from set theory, combinatorics (the art of counting), finite probability, elementary linear algebra and its applications to linear optimization problems.
